		<date>2000-01-07</date>
		<username>Ray-107</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Genius with a message..SPOILER</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is hands down one of the best movies I have ever seen. I'm a huge movie fan and I watch 3-4 movies per week on average. And therein may lie the clue to its enjoyment. The average movie goer may see one flick a week at the most and provide the box office fuel for such tripe as Godzilla and Deuce Bigalow. This movie isn't for those kinds of John Doe "block buster" movie goers. This movie is for true fans of film as art in the style of Scorsese and Altman. It isn't your standard movie experience. If a long unconventional movie isn't your thing, avoid avoid avoid.The movie's theme is the tragic result of self centered-ness. The kind that is so prevalent in post WWII America. The theme seems to be lost on so many of the viewers I saw the film with, as well as many of the reviewers here on imdb. That we are shown at least 9 different people going through this self centered-ness is a vital element to the film. It shows the pervasiveness with which this self absorption exists in our society. In the film it occurs within the span of one day, in one city in 9 different lives. To say life isn't this bad, or that people just aren't this desperate or self absorbed in this day and age is to just have blinders in. People will blast this movie and then leave the theater to blow up at someone who cut them off on the freeway, then drop their 2 year old off at all day day care, oblivious to the failure of their own lives. The manifestations of this kind of life are shown in glorious, overblown detail: drug addiction, blind careerism, selfishness, parents pushing their kids to excel, molestation, adultery. The heart is hardened in every way possible and the capacity to truly love is shut out. The results, as shown in brilliant performances by Jason Robards and Phillip Baker Hall, are agonizing regret and guilt towards the end of life. The brilliant Biblical allegory towards the end of the film (which to my utter surprise several people did not get ..."what's with the frogs"? I heard several people say)only goes to hammer these points home. Reprehensible lives such as these are worthy of a plague.At least to me, this film serves to drive the same point home as "American Beauty" did: Love, compassion and beauty are the only things that matter in life, not the careers, material gains and self pleasures we surround ourselves with. There is certainly a stylistic difference between the two films. AB is thoroughly realistic, Magnolia drives its message home with parody and occasional over-acting to brilliant effect. I mean come on people, look at the Tom Cruise seminar in the hotel..the material in the package he sells. It's obvious this over dramatization is not realistic, it is meant to prove a point.I do have one minor complaint, and that is certain parts of the film where Aimee Mann's songs are used. I'm not referring to the cast sing along of Wise Up which I though was brilliant, but to the use of Momentum and One. At certain points the songs are playing top volume, at the same time the score is playing beneath, and then dialogue on top of that. I found this to be very distracting and annoying. This isn't a slight against Mann, who is a songwriter on par with Lennon or Dylan, but the effect was a little too overwhelming.So you will either revel in the overblowness of it all, and get the message, or see the film as a contrived jarring mess. Maybe some of us could open our minds to see the former.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2012-10-15</date>
		<username>ProfessorFate</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Too long, terribly self-conscious</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There's a line Earl Partridge (Jason Robards) says, something to the effect of "Life isn't short, it's long." That was at about the 2 hour mark, and I thought, "Yeah, so is this movie." "Magnolia" was an interesting idea, and there's some good stuff in it. Some of the acting is first rate (Julianne Moore, Philip Seymore Hoffman, Philip Baker Hall, and Melinda Dillon). Much has been made of Tom Cruise's performance, but I think he over-acts, especially in his big scene with Jason Robards.One of the main problems is that the script tries to do too much. Some editing would have helped, like maybe limiting it to 2 or 3 of these stories. I would have cut the plot involving William Macy's character. Focusing on one whiz kid should have been enough. I also thought the subplot with Claudia and Jim the cop was pretty unbelievable. It was difficult for me to care much about their potential relationship since it seemed obviously doomed. There were just too many balls being juggled at once in this story.I also had a problem with PT Anderson's direction. Very showy and self-indulgent, constantly calling attention to himself with his quick cuts from plot to plot and flashy camera angles. He really dragged out the big decisions made by the various characters: Cruise hanging on the phone with his assistant, the whiz kid's big speech, Moore unloading her guilt on everyone. The whole pacing of the film seemed off in the last hour.Then there's the big pay-off, which I found ridiculous. While others attribute lots of hidden meaning to it, I found it pretty pointless. Really the film's message can be simply summed up with "coincidences happen, and you can't escape your past".Basically I think "Magnolia is an over-rated film, worth watching once, but not worth all the reverence.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>What this movie is all about</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There were a couple of people wondering what this movie is about and why it's chopped into pieces of people's lives. This film is about Love and the way people see it, feel it and live it. If you look close enough you'll see that each of us filters emotions different and although we generally gain the same perception about a feeling, we experience it differently, and this whole movie revolves around how a handful of people put their lives for display.You've probably been told at a point that there are no normal people in this world, there's just people you don't know well enough. This movie depicts that, the twisted, ugly, denatured lives of people, each of us has a sum of experiences, feelings, things we've learnt and some things that we don't like about ourselves, we feel there's a monster or some sort of curse on us for having gone through those things or for having been the cause of those things. And then forgiveness comes into play, because I guess that's the first step to Love, forgiving yourself, or forgiving others.So the truth is, until you look deep within you and learn what and who you are, you're probably not going to understand this movie for what it is.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-01-20</date>
		<username>Infofreak</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the most ambitious movies of the 1990s. Not 100% successful, but packs a strong emotional punch.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Magnolia' seems to be a case of Paul Thomas Anderson trying to outdo himself, and make a "better" and more "important" movie than his masterpiece 'Boogie Nights'. In several places it feels contrived, and the much larger canvas and greater number of characters might dazzle the viewer technically but don't always convince. However many sequences really work and have an emotional honesty rarely seen in contemporary Hollywood movies. In fact if I think you approach this movie emotionally and not intellectually you will find it a lot more rewarding. The gimmicky opening sequence narrated by Ricky Jay, and the much discussed Charles Fort inspired climax were dismissed by many, but I thought they were wonderful, and really effective. Better still was the group singalong in the middle of the picture, which literally had me bawling like a baby. Anderson assembled an outstanding cast of actors, some of which he'd worked with before (especially the core of Reilly, Hoffman, Hall and Walters), some not (Tom Cruise, legendary character actor Jason Robards). All of them have some outstanding moments, but I was especially impressed by the scenes between Robards and Hoffman, and those between Reilly and Walters. I also really liked Macy and Henry Gibson's bar scene, and Philip Baker Hall was excellent throughout. If I was being critical I could single out a handful of scenes which just didn't work for me, but overall there are many more good things about this movie than bad ones, and I applaud Anderson for trying to make a serious drama aimed at adults rather than an empty FX filled blockbuster aimed at kids. I don't think 'Magnolia' is 100% successful, but it's heart is in the right place, and when it is good, it is very, very good. A movie that every serious film fan should watch.</fullReview>
	</review>

It enjoys a correct performance and the director shows compassion and even tenderness for his characters. You can also see through his movie a bitter and cynical critic of the American society and more particularly of the American television (what do the kids now?).A good movie? Yes. A masterpiece? Not really...</fullReview>

		<username>matthew wilder (cosmovitelli@mediaone.net)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Parents just don't understand</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In his back-to-back first features in 1997, Paul Thomas Anderson came on strong with HARD EIGHT and BOOGIE NIGHTS to ding the bell as the most prodigious new artist in American movies since the birth pangs of Martin Scorsese. So how did Anderson follow up a masterpiece with a work as misconceived, unfocussed, unconvincing and sheerly interminable as MAGNOLIA? With a chill, one recalls Pauline Kael's words on Mike Nichols' CATCH-22: "It was hugely anticipated and then instantly forgotten."The movie kicks off with a bang, with an anthology of short tales of improbable death and strange coincidence, shot and narrated in a bruising, hurtling style that suggests one of David Mamet's oracular anecdotes given the Scorsese benzedrine treatment. But then the Short Cutsish cast of characters is introduced in a brain-battering, headlong montage, with Aimee Mann's cover of Three Dog Night's "One" covering up the dialogue, and what Anderson must have been aiming at--a dizzying opener in the manner of the montage that begins CASINO--winds up seeming like something from Baz Luhrmann's ROMEO AND JULIET. You can feel that something is off--this isn't the pitch-perfect world of BOOGIE NIGHTS, where every scene seemed right down to the tiniest beats. The "naturalistic" world of this movie, a universe of living rooms, cheap apartment buildings, game-show sets and hotel suites, seems infinitely faker than the porno fantasyland of BOOGIE NIGHTS. And the storylines themselves emerge reality-deficient. Critics who carped that the Sturges-like cast of screwballs in BOOGIE NIGHTS were one-dimensional will shudder to encounter this crew.Without going into the eight or so plots that make up the movie, I'll just note that the "theme" that slowly emerges (somewhere after two hours pass) is that parents are innately bad--they always manage to cannibalize or torment their children to the point of irreversible harm. The fantasy good-guy dads in HARD EIGHT and BOOGIE NIGHTS are nowhere to be found here; instead, there's a game-show producer (Jason Robards) who dumps his cancer-riddled wife for a young chippie (Julianne Moore) and lives to regret it when the Big C comes a-callin'. (Moore's bedside conversion from trophy wife to penitent happens offscreen, and seems no less the ridiculous for it.) And a game-show host (Philip Baker Hall) also gets cancer, and a terrible secret about him and his daughter--can you guess?--is slowly revealed, hours after we've figured it out. The only tangible emotion you can pull out of MAGNOLIA is that Anderson, once a PA for a kids' game show, wishes lymphoma on all the old guys he worked for.There are moments. John C. Reilly is sublime as a good-hearted cop who seems to live to impart tough love on every sad sack in the world; his scenes with a terminally screwed-up Melora Walters have the screwy, awkward tenderness of the great moments of BOOGIE NIGHTS, despite the fact that Walters seems to be playing an amalgam of Amanda Plummer and Fiona Apple. And Philip Seymour Hoffman has a bottomless gentleness as a nurse tending to the fading Robards. And the climactic plague--a ripoff of the earthquake that ends SHORT CUTS, but bettering it--is marvellously directed, though it seems derived from that famous highbrow seventies work, JURASSIC PARK.A creepy feeling sets in about halfway into MAGNOLIA: there's no engine powering the movie forward, and there's only Jon Brien's hammering, Rich Hollywood Movie score faking tension and import. Anderson cuts from one static scene to the next to the next; his editing rhythms have never felt so arbitrary or slack. (The movie feels as if it were picked and picked at in the editing room; lots of storylines are truncated or oddly overprolonged, and loose ends prevail.) The bottom line is that you don't buy anything, and you don't much care about anyone; Anderson stages scenes so inert you can't believe he directed them. (An early one between Reilly and a child rapper knocks the movie cold for about twenty minutes.)And Anderson's power with actors in his first two movies is little in evidence here. Tom Cruise gives one of those jumpy-weirdo performances people always applaud when they're given by a movie-star dreamboat (as when Brad Pitt made googly eyes in TWELVE MONKEYS), but everything he does seems way off. And the director seems so smitten by Julianne Moore's breaking-down-outside-the-courthouse scene in BOOGIE NIGHTS that he's given her a dozen scenes of screaming and weeping. She comes across like an overworked amateur; it's the nadir of her otherwise miraculous career. Even Anderson's favorite actor Philip Baker Hall feels ready to give a great performance, but the thin material robs him of the chance.Paul Thomas Anderson has seemed to me Hollywood movies' last best hope--the guy who might carry the humanist torch of Cassavetes, Scorsese and Altman into the new millennium. He has raised the bar for everyone in a big way. But this movie is a blooper. Anderson's preoccupation with precocious boys is beginning to look a lot like hubris. And if there ever was a movie that proved length isn't everything, this is it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<username>ben wells</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Run! As fast as you can!!!! Don't waste your life!!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I love the concept on the IMDb of plot synopsis. I can't possibly imagine how anyone would describe this misguided hotch-potch of a film in terms of 'plot' or indeed any other yardstick by which we measure films. Watch a bit of it, and it seems fine. Quite well acted, a bit quirky, quite provocative. Each scene ends without resolution like a cliffhanger from a TV show. The fact that each scene takes as long as a TV show could test your patience, but surely it hangs together and means something in the end... The film meanders through these 'vignettes'. Is there a non-diminutive version of the word vignette? Vigns? Cos these are BIG vignettes. They go on and on, still well-acted, carefully thought-out and utterly meaningless. The longer the film goes on, the more you realise that nothing is happening, each mini-story too long for a multi-layered film of this kind but too dense to be resolved in the time they are given so that the mixture of frustration and emptiness you are feeling turns to rage. Do you bail? Do you turn off? You have already wasted 2 hours of your life on this, maybe, like many other films, something will happen to make it all worth it, it will be a true art experience...it rains frogs. Is that the end? It rains frogs? Maybe that's it..no, it's still going. I just watched a bit of this film again to challenge myself. Maybe I was in a bad mood. Is it really that bad? Yes. Save yourself. Don't watch this film.</fullReview>

		<date>2008-05-17</date>
		<username>saraide-rasiel</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Magnolia Performances - The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie itself is a wonderfully ambitious film. If I were to base an opinion on whether the movie was or was not worth the time it takes to watch it, I would definitely vote yes. However, for all its ambition, the film ultimately fails. The segment where the soundtrack music is played throughout all the scenes does not work. Neither do the urban legends that are put into the film - and yes, they are urban legends - no Green, Berry, Hill; no diver in a tree; no suicide made murder. The performances in Magnolia are its strongest and weakest points. For example, Tom Cruise really is awesome as the misogynistic Frank "T.J." Mackey. John C. Reilly is amazing as the Christian cop and Melora Waters definitely holds her own in the scenes she shares with Reilly. However some of the other actors - actors known for their talent - are performing well beneath par. The scene where Jason Robards goes on about the difficulty of dying is not heart-wrenching at all. All I could think about during the scene was William Shatner as Captain Kirk screaming, "The pain! The pain! The pain!" Many people find Julianne Moore's performance one of Magnolia's saving graces. I beg to differ. Her performance was contrived, calculated, and just way over the top. When she is visiting the lawyer and starts going on about her illicit affairs and says, "i sucked other men's c****," I honestly laughed out loud! The riveting scene in the drugstore too, provides Moore with another opportunity to leap off the over-acting ledge. Her bad performance is surprising to me because I think she is a great actress and the "Magnolia" role is not that different from her "Boogie Nights" role. She played the part of a drug addict in 'Boogie Nights" beautifully and with complete understand of an addict's frame of mind. It appears though, that playing the part of a guilt-ridden, loaded, gold-digger just doesn't work for her.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>robot_sex</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Sorry folks</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is one of the most shallow and cynical attempts at making a "great film" I have come across in some time. One can almost see Anderson sitting down with his rented copies of The Shawshank Redemption, It's A Wonderful Life and Short Cuts, studiously taking notes on what a "great film" should be. Instead, the finished product ends up more like Cocoon: The Return, only more manipulative.The film is one that bears all the hallmarks of a bona fide "great film".....various interwoven storylines, lots of talking, lots of "emotional" scenes, lots of crying, some interesting plot turns, and so on. However, bearing the hallmarks of a "great film" does not neccesarily make it one!In my humble opinion, anyone who has watched this film and enjoyed it(which is a lot of you by the looks of things) has fallen victim to an absoloute sucker punch. The whole film reeks of emotional button pushing by numbers.A small footnote: Julianne Moore's performance was one of the most annoying things I have seen in my short time on this earth.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-07-24</date>
		<username>Aw-komon</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A CHINESE WATER TORTURE OF SHAMELESS PRETENSION</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Uggghhh! Man, did this movie suck...If someone wanted to torture me to death Clockwork-Orange style all they'd have to do is force me to watch this embarrassment back-to-back with Kubrick's humiliating final stinker 'Eyes Wide Shut.' I would beg them to put a bullet through my cranium.Talk about cynical...this flick makes Todd Solondz's movies look like romantic dreamscapes (no offense to Solondz whose movies are all fabulous). There was a little old lady a few rows in front of me and I really felt embarrassed for her, something that never happens to me unless a movie is extremely distasteful and just plain WRONG on every front.What could she be thinking, I wondered (that's how bored I was with the film)? I imagined the scenario in my head: From the magnificent male movie stars of her era-- Gable, Bogart, Cagney, Tracy, etc.-- she has come to tolerate, after the '70s revolution in popular cinema, certain hardcore performances of the ilk branded by DeNiro and Keitel (in the name of uncensored art, of course); but to witness the embarrassing spectacle of a bimbo like Cruise trying to ape them so distastefully and in such mercenary fashion (fully aware of the fact that he will be praised by 'critics' for his 'daring')? It must've sent her dreaming of the good old days of John Garfield and Brando, when men were men and certain things stayed private and out of the movies (although, they did see print, if the crucial 'allowable level of profanity' had been found, as in Norman Mailer's books). Censorship may have stifled a few cinematic geniuses but it sure kept the pretentious mediocrities from polluting wholesome Americans with cynical nonsense.And now that Americans are so much 'freer,' censorship of taste and a certain amount of 'snobbism' must be in full effect to offset the damage done by movies like 'Magnolia' and 'Eyes Wide Shut.' 'Correct expression' is and has always been the issue that artists have had to deal with. It is they who claim to have insight into matters of 'expression.' The greatest artists raise the level and range of 'correct expression' and literally force the public to see things their way. Sooner or later the public will have to give in and always does, if history is any indication.In the cinema and in relation to 'Magnolia,' Scorsese and Altman come to mind. They have found the proper modes of cinematic expression for the seamier aspects of life and have integrated that with many other factors. P.T. shows no respect for the crucial balance they've attained by pretending he can do it better any which way he feels like it. He thinks of himself a new pioneer in these matters when he's not even old hat. I suggest he sticks to what he can handle, overrated little 'risque' entertainments like 'Boogie Nights,' and aspire to DePalma territory instead (he'll be lucky if he can ever make a film half as great as 'Blow-Out').Altman, whose 'Short-Cuts' is the obvious model here, uses profanity and a certain amount of lewdness as cynical little details of a broad canvas that goes much deeper. The same details in 'Magnolia' become the whole painting. In fact, the profanity and is so gratuitous and the cynicism so uninteresting it makes David Mamet look like an optimist.As to the acting: I can understand an airhead Scientologist like Tom Cruise agreeing to play a character that could never exist openly in real life (even Hustler magazine never takes misogyny that far since it would completely destroy its credibility as to whatever genuine liberating effects it has had in its own sleazy way), but there is no excuse for a great actor like Jason Robards (did he need the part that bad?) or an Altman veteran like Julian Moore, to play one-sided, cynical cartoons that DO NOT EXIST IN REAL LIFE even among the most depressed of the prozaced population. These characters are certain characteristics of actual persons pretending to be whole persons. That never cuts it; and experienced actors, of all people, should be the ones to know it. Did Moore and Robards bother to read the atrocious, curse-for-no-reason-even-David Mamet-could-think-of dialogue? What justified their faith in this guy to put themselves out ('emotionally naked,' is that the term for using too many idiotic curses per sentence and putting the magnifying glass only on wretchedness?) as they do here? I suggest they be more careful next time to prevent embarrassment to themselves and the dignity of art in general.One final thing before I leave you all to your own questionable judgments. If you want to see how terrible a film can be and also how great a film it's trying to imitate looks by contrast, take one scene as an example: SPOILER ALERT It's when P.T. Anderson tries to rip-off (they call it homage nowadays) the dialogue in the scene from 'Raging Bull' given to Cathy Moriarity, when Jake (DeNiro) is beating her (his wife) because, in his paranoid jealousy, he suspects her of sleeping with his brother Joey (Joe Pesci). Moriarty, to get back at Jake, admits to having performed oral sex on his brother and 'everyone else on the F'n' block.' DeNiro is much more shocked and offended by the revelation of this graphic detail than the graphic admission of the adultery itself. In 'Magnolia,' when Julian Moore sits in her psychiatrist's office and suddenly, completely out of the blue, admits to having performed not only sex but specifically 'oral' sex on many men other than her old dying husband (Robards) while they were married, it is so gratuitous, it makes you cringe in your seat. Why are we being given this specific information, P.T.? Does the graphic information make the adultery look any worse or more degrading or more funny? Do we really care that this woman is so cut-off that she desperately wants to feel guilty but can't even manage that, by evoking pictures of the graphic X-rated details of the life of an adultress? Do we care that she's on the verge of suicide? Hell no! P.T. might be aiming at all that and his aspirations can be commended and pretensions lamented but the result is flat and unaffective. The scene only makes Julian Moore look foolish for having agreed to speak pornographic dialogue when the guilt she feels in having betrayed her dying husband is in no way made believable by previous events! Is P.T. trying to break new ground by doing this? Is this some new existentialist angle revealing the emptiness of modern life? Hell no! He is copying and trying to do what Scorcese did and failing embarrassingly. No extensive character development has prepared us for the graphic confession (though we were certainly expecting more profanity, since every other word in the dialogue is a curse) and we couldn't care less for it.Why is the same type of 'slice of life with all the graphic details' so overwhelmingly effective and tragically funny in 'Raging Bull' and so awfully uninteresting in 'Magnolia?' The answer to that, my cyber-friends, is a long and deeply important one (it has to do with logical progression and fully developed REAL characters to start with), and it is what separates the great directors from the mediocre and establishes the criterion for what is truly valuable art and checks the damage inflicted by all that would be mistaken for it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The Emperor's New Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is, unfortunately, not so much a film as a wreck. I haven't disliked a film so much for being a complete imposter in a long time (Dances With Wolves comes to mind). It's the emptiest of empty vessels: No idea, no vision, no reason to exist. More a grad school thesis project than visionary work, it's a severe stumble in P.T. Anderson's heretofore promising career. Maybe that's why the former Paul Thomas Anderson has reverted to his initials: He, too, knows there's a sucker born every minute. Why else would he inflict such a disappointing sham as Magnolia on movie lovers? Better directors have said more in the opening credits than this movie manages to croak in its 3 1/2 hours.I give it a rating of 1, with the caveat that the Aimee Mann soundtrack is lovely.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Utter waste of time, talent and celluloid</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Three hours of my life that I will never get back.The first fifteen minutes was all I needed to see, to know that the writing wasn't going to get any better. My husband had read some glowing reviews on it, and thought that it would get better. It didn't.The writer/director/producer thinks that if you have the characters yell and use profanity it means that THEY ARE ANGRY.It would be like a symphony composed of only one note, but played VERY LOUDLY.It was suggested to me by a friend that if the writer had lost the "F" key on his keyboard, that he would be unable to write.I believe it.To show anger, you shouldn't always be screaming. You should sometimes whisper malevolently. Or give a knowing smile, showing that revenge will be yours. It is only with variety that a compelling performance is made.It's hard when you're working with such utter tripe of a script.There are a lot of big named actors that participated in this monstrosity, and I don't know why they accepted the part they did.It is the worst movie that I have ever seen. If I can help someone avoid wasting their time watching it, then I will have done a good deed for the day.Of course, if you'd like to use this movie as an example of how bad a movie can be made, have at it.Personally, I think it was far worse than "Heaven's Gate" which I actually saw in the theaters on opening night. 		<date>2003-09-06</date>
		<username>2DawgZ</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>The Worst Film Ever Made</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Paul Thomas Anderson is simply the latest in a long line of over-pretentious, but ultimately talent-free, film makers to be embraced by the critics.The script in this film is ridiculous, the directing is worse than amateur, and the acting, with a couple of notable exceptions is plain awful (especially Tom Cruise's over acting). 	<review>
		<date>2002-02-05</date>
		<username>John Dennison (jtdurden@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A Big Disappointment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't really see the point in submitting a review if all you are going to do is rubbish the movie concerned, but in the case of this particular one I feel an exception has to be made. Why? Because I was strung along by this movie for 3 hours plus in the hope that something may be resolved or indeed something may actually happen. And it didn't. Don't get me wrong, I do not need a film to be linear or all neat and tidy for me to enjoy it, from this database I appear to be one of the few to enjoy "The Ninth Gate", a confusing mess with an similarly abrupt ending. Some people tend to get all snobby about movies, in a "Oh if you didn't like or understand this go and watch Gone in 60 seconds instead" kind of way. Just because a film is touted as a little more cerebral, is 3 hours long, and contains significant analysis of people and relationships it must be art. Is it?There appear to be two camps created by Magnolia, both share the similarity in that they are vocal and strong in their standpoint. They also are equally convinced of their take on how the film should be perceived. It is a good thing if a film does evoke strong reactions, and Magnolia certainly generates extreme opinions from both sides of the coin. Personally, I honestly cannot see, even by reading many others interpretations and by seeing the film all in one go, how this film can be perceived as a classic in any way. This film is pretentious, boring, preachy, maudlin, and eventually vacuous. Some of the acting is indeed quite good but the characters are odious and superficial. The script appears to have been written by an arty Sixth Former who one day decided to write an angst ridden story that would show the whole world where we are going wrong. Surely a film has to have decent characters and a good script before it is going anywhere, this movie has neither, (apart from Tom Cruise's Frank Mackey, who is very amusing in the first hour).Much has been made of the films interlude where the cast are all individually shown singing "Wise Up". I couldn't believe this scene was actually happening, some will find it moving, others will find it utterly laughable. This film annoyed me, I stuck with it as some parts showed promise and it continually makes you feel something is around the corner, but frustratingly it ends up unfulfilled. A poor attempt in my view, but don't take my word for it, if its number #124 on the IMDB chart someone must like it!</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2007-07-24</date>
		<username>n-mo</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>All the effort is on one side</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pretentious moviegoers bill Magnolia a "thinking person's film." There is some truth to that. However, the mere fact of expending effort does not guarantee the reward will be worth the force required, and this film is a textbook example.Are there multiple layers to this film? Clearly. Do the parallels make sense? They do. Do they have religious and philosophical connotations? You bet. Is there any point? Perhaps. Paul Thomas Anderson has obviously read his Bible and his literature handbook.Alas, an educated man does not a good storyteller make, for while it takes a semi-literate viewer to comprehend the subtexts of this bizarre ?uvre, it takes rather little genius to stack a deck of philosophical statements and literary devices without weaving them into a well-written script with an actual plot and sympathetic characters.The police officer is the one exception. He was the one character I actually cared to know about. The rest are whiny, vulgar and disingenuous--in a word, pathetic, and they scarcely rise above that at any point. So the story was about emotions, not about growth. The fact is, they didn't show enough humanity for us to care about their emotions.The script is just as bad. Anderson's inability to constrain profanity to the most feral emotive outbursts, written or spoken, smacks of verbal immaturity. I cannot comment on the plot for the simple reason that there is none, except to say that the late sequence intended to stand in for a climax, while perhaps meaningful as subtext, simply does not fit in any way on a literal level.As an acquaintance said of a similarly bad exercise in storytelling, "What a cop-out." Nice try, Anderson, but when the elementary structure is missing, the volume and weight of a composition have no effect on its quality. Back to creative writing 101.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2016-07-02</date>
		<username>TheLittleSongbird</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The three Ds- dark, daring and dazzling</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Magnolia' is perhaps the most polarising of Paul Thomas Anderson's work. A lot of people have found it thought-provoking, emotionally impacting and dazzling in many ways, while many others have found it dull, self-indulgent, bloated and overlong.This reviewer falls into the former camp. 'Magnolia' perhaps feels indulgently overlong in places, and the final group musical number does feel contrived and out of sorts with the rest of the film. On the whole though 'Magnolia' is a dark, daring and dazzling film, and another winner in a filmography where this reviewer has yet to watch a dud.All of Anderson's films are visually stunning, and 'Magnolia' has some of the most haunting and scintillating arresting images of any of his films, especially at the end. The long takes and tracking shots are distinctively Anderson and look wonderful, the whole film is beautifully shot, very atmospherically lit and the production design is suitably audacious. The soundtrack is rich in emotion and sticks in the head, and all the song choices are well chosen. Some found it intrusive, not to me.Regarding the script, it contains some of the most thought-provoking, layered and poignant writing of all Anderson's films. The story has a long length to work with, and doesn't disappoint with the pacing which is a mix of suitably manic and suitably languid when either extreme is needed, unpredictable, beautifully developed, hugely entertaining, dark and often very emotional scenarios and richly layered characters, remarkable for so much going on. Anderson's direction is also exemplary.Another controversial asset of 'Magnolia' is the ending, something that many will find powerful (again fall into this camp) and others will be perplexed. Whatever extreme you find yourselves, it certainly is not an ending that one forgets easily. Anderson's mastery of direction of actors and their interactions shows through loud and clear, with the whole cast giving superb performances in one-of-a-kind roles, for some among their best.Tom Cruise in particular has an absolute ball, and he is particularly well supported by a gleefully entertaining and charming John C. Reilly, a touchingly restrained William H. Macy, an as always exemplary Philip Seymour Hoffmann and a heartfelt Julianne Moore. Jason Robards and Melora Walters also do brilliantly.In conclusion, dark, daring and dazzling. The most polarising of Anderson's films but incredibly well executed, a flawed masterpiece somewhat. 9/10 Bethany Cox</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2014-12-22</date>
		<username>will-adolphy</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>No Spoilers: Great film.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Firstly I would like to site that I watched this film with no expectations. I stumbled across it on IMDb and added it to my watch list. I wasn't put off by the 3 hr duration because as with any good film I was engaged throughout and the 3hrs felt like very little time at all. The lack of clear linear narrative did not put me off in-fact it made this film even more unique because it became unpredictable and that is what made it so engaging. I wasn't watching a typical Hollywood feel good movie i was watching an artistic exploration of hard-cutting themes like regret, choice, fear and confrontation. Anderson does an incredible job in intertwining these stories in a very subtle manner that doesn't make it seem too unbelievable. And it really does make you think that coincidence is unknowingly a huge part of life. This film got me thinking that everyone has a story, you glance in every car or shop window and behind it is a human, with a story, with a struggle. Not centering the action around one character was key to this. I don't want to give much away because i feel this is a film that you have to watch without too much to know. It will boggle your mind at times but in an engaging manner. If your an action fan and can't stomach a film that requires the audience's interpretation to fulfill the ambiguity the film creates then i wouldn't bother watching this as you would have been one of the many walkers who left the cinema when this film first came out. That's fine, when you have a film that stands on it's own and is special because it doesn't confer with typical story telling rules, not every spectator will be satisfied. Performances: For me there were solid performances all around. Tom Cruise was very convincing at times but i still saw some similar personal quirks and traits that shone through during high intense moments. Julianne Moore was a bit over the top for me at times and didn't stand out as much as Phillip Seymour Hoffman who although had one of the smaller and perhaps minimal parts created a lot of detail and was extremely effective during moments of raw emotion, it all stems from his subtlety he never smothers the audience but rather draws them in to the point of empathy. John C. Reilly really surprised me in this film i didn't think much of him prior to watching this because although i have never seen him play a role that is far away from himself and still haven't it didn't matter in this film. He was very engaging during all his scenes.</fullReview>

Macy , Philip Baker Hall , Melinda Dillon , Emmanuel Johnson , Lillian Adams , Henry Gibson , Felicity Huffman , Ricky Jay , Alfred Molina , Luis Guzman.Directed by one of my top favorite directors, Paul Thomas Anderson. his movies like There Will Be Blood and Boogie Nights are one of the best movies ever.Nominated for 3 Oscars, Best Supporting actor Tom Cruise, Original Song and Original Screenplay. it was a winner of many awards but mostly for acting ensembles and a hit at festivals winning Golden Berlin Bear.one of the most weirdest film making ever. this is a psychological drama movie which is a big mosaic of nterrelated characters in search of happiness, forgiveness and some meaning of their current or past life in California. this movie is literally not quite explainable. it is a deep, sad, depressing and quite complex movie with many stories of many people. i have seen quite these type of movies recently but this is way different than others.running time of this movie bothered me a lot. and the other thing is that even though with many characters and incidents happening to them, many unanswered questions are left. character development was a bit weak for some. 		<shortDescription>overlong but detailed and well-performed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Engrossing portrait centering around a hodgepodge of different characters including a dedicated cop whose day deviates from the norm, an elderly man on his deathbed whose only wish is to see his estranged son, his mercurial younger wife who has a crisis of conscience, a child prodigy pushed too far after being forced to perform on a television game show, each of them confronting their angst and suffering their own demons. A layered and emotionally wrenching story told in visually arresting fashion with believable characters and pitch-perfect performances. Standouts: Cruise, as a worldly Don Juan, Moore, as a promiscuous and grief-stricken wife. A fine showing from all those involved though it would have been more effective had it been shorter. ***</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Spliced Drama</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have to say, I spent most of this movie worrying that all the storylines would be united in a single car crash, or somehow having them all end up in the same building. I was pleased that their connection was more sublimated. The characters seemed to fill roles in each other's lives, whether they physically met or not.I do wonder whether the frogs were necessary, I guess it was nice having one common thread through all the stories, but......i don't know, it seemed like more of a cheep shocker than a legitimate addition to the story. Same goes for the bookend sequences, as much as loved them, I think there was enough meat in the story without them.Last year I watched "Time Code" on IFC, which is basically a failed attempt at a similar structure only with video. Sometimes a clever idea can take over a film, and carry it while the film suffers from other factors. Another example would be "Run Lola Run". Magnolia is the perfection of what one might call "spliced drama", for it still manages to be "about" the characters, and not how they are related.</fullReview>

		<username>Todd</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great Acting - But the frogs...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just finished this movie after seeing it a while ago in the theaters. I must admit that the cast throughout, even small specks of a role are very human and very believable, truly some of the finest collectively you'll find. The Frogs?Plot: One full day in L.A. Parents, children, lovers and nobody's come one step closer to understanding the principles and complications of love and forgiveness. Then Frogs happen.With one to five minute clips of each story passing through the day you don't get as bored as you think you might. What really will draw you in (if you are of the %50 who liked this movie) is the acting. Tom cruise is his typical cocky self, and we watch that character slowly breakdown to the persona of a little boy. To the contrary William H Macy is his normal wimp character who slowly gains confidence (a little at least). Jason Robards fits nicely in to the last breaths of a dying man role. Phillip Baker Hall, is quite frightening portraying the duality of appearance for game show hosts on and off camera. Julianne Moore gives us the full circle of guilt and how it eats at us. Philip Seymour Hoffman is still in his stereo-cast yet he has a hero-esque presence through the film. The true academy award, however, should go to John C. Reily. His role as your nice-guy LAPD officer is too funny to be fake, he had me the most engrossed with his cop mannerism, so text-book and clean cut. Even the supporting roles are executed as if they were at the same level.Bottom line: Directing of course great with Paul Thomas Andersons' famous loud impacts to wake up the audience. The soundtrack cradles the mood too well. But mainly, the merit of the acting is far superior to most movies and deserves at least a once over by every movie connoisseur. Just make sure you don't ave a fear of frogs... or you'll be scared to death.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-12-11</date>
		<username>(davidf15)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I almost liked this movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Strong performances, moody camerawork, and some interesting points on the meaning of life, ambition and forgiveness almost contrive to make a superb movie, but they can't make up for a lack of credibility in some of the tales and a loss of direction towards the end of the piece.The film starts well with plenty of energy and intriguing cuts and you soon realise that you're in for a character piece which isn't necessarily going to have a conclusive, tidy ending. Not necessarily a problem. There are a number of story-lines all connected by a game-show and you do find yourself intrigued to know how the day is going to pan out for each of these characters. And like a good game-show you stay put to find out the result.We hear about the game-show's producer - dying of cancer in the care of a male nurse; the game-show's host - dying of cancer as he performs (cancer seems to be a recurring theme); the game-show's current star player - a child prodigy; and a former child star player but failure in life. Added to this mix are the tales of the producer's son - a misogynistic self-improvement guru; a caring cop in search of love; the producer's mixed up mistress; and the host's mixed up daughter (being mixed up is another recurring theme). All excellently played.At about the halfway point you begin to draw parallel's with Robert Altman's Short Cuts...and it's at about the same stage that the film seems to lose its way. Magnolia suffers by comparison with Short Cuts. It lacks its predecessor's humour, the relationships between the story-lines are somehow less satisfying, and with the exception of the young quiz contestant Stanley, and possibly the policeman, you have very little sympathy for any of the characters. They were too emotional and into their own problems for me to develop anything but indifference to their plights. But where I think it suffers most is that I believed Short Cuts and I didn't believe Magnolia. It stretches synchronicity to the limits of its elasticity, and when all the cast began independently singing the same song, credibility snapped! By the time the shower of frogs came I'd written this one off as an actors' fantasy workout, and I felt slightly cheated by what had started out with such promise.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-04-03</date>
		<username>ciderjam</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Only Slow if Taken for Granted</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After viewing this movie twice in one day (as there is no way whatsoever that one can view this movie once and draw a valid, credible conclusion about it), I can honestly say that this is the most bizarre movie I've ever seen. After seeing it the first time, I said to my friend who viewed it with me, "Umm..." After viewing it the second time with a team of first time viewers (which gave me the opportunity of feeding off their array of perspectives they were voicing throughout the movie) I was able to make a lot more sense out of it.I'd like to say that this movie had possibly the most intriguing introduction to a movie that I've ever seen. And as to the ending, I've GOT to watch the movie again so I can make some kind of sense out of that.As much as I can tell, Earl Partridge (played by Jason Robards) is the central character of the movie. I LOVE how delightfully inadvertently he is responsible for all the goings-on of the movie. He is connected to Cruise and Moore because they are his wife and son. He's connected to the game show host because he personally is the game show producer, he's connected to William H. Macy and Jeremy Blackman because they are both scarred products of the show, and in a very inadvertent way, he is connected to the cop...the "savior" of his game show host's coke-addict daughter. Yes, that was really pushing it, but between the soliloquies of both Robards and John C. Reilly (the cop) toward the end, the movie becomes not only credible, but profound.In short, Magnolia is a wild masterpiece that, in my mind, demands multiple viewings and an honest reckoning (if you can stomach Tom Cruise's great adaptation of the deranged, obsessive sex psychologist)! The movie has a tendency to drag, but I think that it only does this if you can't appreciate the depth of the characters in each scene and if you don't do things like try to figure out why in the heck frogs fell from the sky.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-02-25</date>
		<username>(taxidriver@nycmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>You decide</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>P.T. Anderson paid great attention to detail in this visually superb film. The cast is very well selected, cinematography is outstanding and the writing, unique. The film is not original in the sense of telling several different stories, (though P.T.A. is very particular that this is one entire story, and it is) or shall I say, events, because several films have already done this. But P.T.A. does succeed in giving this brand of film making a new, fresh and quite appealing aspect to it. The events, though seemingly unrelated in the beginning, all come together at the end in a very strange way. There are several moments in the film that had a personal impact on myself, and I think that is the great thing about this movie: no matter how unrelated you are with these characters, you can still find something that draws a relationship between yourself and them. The bottom line is that it's movies like these that are going to and have already changed the art form of film. So see it, though I can't quite judge this work it is something that is truly unique and definitely worth watching.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-02-03</date>
		<username>tob1n</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A review of the reviews (minor spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I take issue with many of the poor reviews for this movie. If you are reading them to determine whether or not to see the movie, don't. But I feel that most people read these reviews to validate their own feelings about a movie they have seen.Somehow, I escaped most of the hype for this movie and knew very little about it before I rented it (I do this semi-consciously so that my enjoyment of my first viewing is not spoiled). Those reviewers that have said that the introductory stories have nothing to do with the picture, the frogs came out of nowhere, the characters' actions were without cause, and on and on and on, clearly did not "get" this movie. I did. In retrospect, I think the theme of the movie is "too little, too late." All of the characters experience a loss, of which most could have been prevented if they had the courage to face their fears and short-comings in time for others to care. Believe it or not, I would have liked Magnolia to have been a little longer. I did not have a full understanding of how the Tom Cruise character became an Andrew Dice Clay style preacher, or why the drug-abusing wife was so self-turmoiled.I think what I liked most, as I have liked in many other movies of the recent past, is the complete abandon that many "mainstream" movies are willing to proceed with. This was almost non-existent in the 80's, a little light peeked through in the early 90's, and we are seeing more of in the past few years. The era we are currently seeing reminds me of 70's movies with promising directors, a blend of experienced acting talent with fresh, young talent, and a boldness of material. I even see it in movies that I don't like (Fight Club). Magnolia would have never seen a reel of film in the 80's. Neither would Fargo, Pulp fiction, The Thin Red Line, Run Lola Run, or American Beauty.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-02-02</date>
		<username>SuperCoop</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Grand Account of Unusual Events</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Usually when critics praise an independent film I end up not liking the film, this movie would be an exception to the rule. What makes Magnolia great would have to be the direction of the film by P.T. Anderson, that alone would be enough to make this movie great but the fact that so many talented actors and actresses signed on to work in this film pushes it over the top. I don't enjoy long movies anything over 2 and a half hours usually annoys me, but this movie is edited so well together with so many stories. The best performance was probably by Tom Cruise as Frank Mackey and John C. Reilly as a good natured cop. At the beginning of the film Reilly is shown to be all good and Cruise is made out to be all bad and throughout the course of this movie you begin to understand where they both are coming from and what they both strive for. The characters in this film are all realistically depicted they are all real people, which means that you see them in their entirety so that there are no villains or heroes just people.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-02-01</date>
		<username>Clayton Bolger</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Just falls short.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Don't get me wrong. I did really like Magnolia, but I felt that it was a big ALMOST. The acting is incredible. Each cast member delivers a fantastic performance that endears you toward their character and their plight. The weaving of the sub-plots are extremely well edited and strung together. When it is engaging, it is very well written.Unfortunately parts of the film feel too long, and some scenes could have been cut in half. And there was the feeling of wanting to see more of Stanley or Mackey, but we got lumped with an endless Partridge monologue, or a tedious bar scene with Donnie Smith. Sometimes the direction was wonderfully clever and quick-moving, and at others boring and slow, for no real reason.The frogs was a unique touch that was unnecessary, and I felt was put into the film out of whimsey. Yes, yes, yes, Exodus 8:2, a plague of frogs in Egypt, but how does that correlate with the plot of the movie? It ultimately affects two of the characters, but it just being 'one of those things' doesn't wash.The overriding triumph of this film is the humanity, and what people deal with while living their lives. It is well worth seeing, bearing in mind that you are really seeing one day in the lives of ordinary (and not-so ordinary) people. PS: In the DVD documentary, Paul Anderson does not talk about Magnolia as being one of top five best screenplays ever. He's talking about the film Network (1976) when viewing it to his team to show what he's looking for in the portrayal of Jimmy Gator. And he talks about what other people think of Boogie Nights, and how Magnolia will (and did) get compared to it.PPS: It is not the most overlooked film of 1999. Fight Club was. At least Magnolia got some awards and critical acclaim.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>'This is a definitely not something that I expected' were my first thoughts after I went out of the movie theatre yesterday, seeing 'Magnolia' for the first time. Indeed, how can you expect something like this - it just can't be describred. In fact, I was speechless after a movie probably for the first time in my life, although there are other films that have moved me over the years. However, I was simply appaled before this display of cinema art that Paul Thomas Anderson has presented us with.I admit that I haven't seen the critically acclaimed 'Boogie Nights', but now I'm sure that P.T. Anderson is one of the people, because of whom cinema deserves to be placed among the other six arts. The whole idea of the movie was beyond anyone's perception - vision (extraordinary cinematography), charachters, music (here I give much to the choice of Aimee Mann to write most of the soundtrack) and of course the story, although it simply cannot be described in a few words. The cast is also magnificent - I did have some doubts about Tom Cruise, especially after the reviews that this was the best part in his career, but I must say that he convinced me that he can play not worse than the remaining great actors. I could give you just a short list - William H. Macy, Julianne Moore, Phillip Seymor Hoffman, Jason Robards and many others, as each one of them contributes to the perfectness of the film.Now I know that this review comes a little bit late - unfortunately we see lots of good movies quite a while, if ever, after the official premiere, but to everyone who hasn't seen 'Magnolia' and yearns for something different from everything else you have seen before - this is the place to go. If you don't feel that way - well, there are always the Farelli brothers and Jean-Claude Van Damme.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-10-19</date>
		<username>DeathByTelevision</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Melora Walters and John C. Reilly outweigh the film's flaws.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I would say that despite the film's flaws, Paul Thomas Anderson continues to prove he is one of the great modern filmmakers with "Magnolia." At best, it displays a poetic quality. The way story lines intertwine emotionally, often times without blending in the actual plot of the movie, creates a desperate, lonely tone. Even though the film doesn't find Anderson at his most focused, his total disregard of typical cookie-cutter Hollywood storytelling is refreshing.With that said, I find some serious flaws with the film. I've heard Anderson saying he relished the chance to create a film around the songs of Aimee Mann. She does indeed add some good music to the soundtrack, but the way it's edited into the film in several scenes is quite annoying. In one of the opening scenes we are introduced to all the main characters as Mann sings "One is the loneliest number." This would work fine, but the song is quite sparse and simple, and the arrangement is quite long. I know this was necessary, since there was quite a bit of story to set up, but by the end of the sequence, I wanted to scream, "turn off that #@%&amp;* song!," especially since it was featured fairly loud in the audio mix. In another scene, Mann's song "Wise Up" is played as we see the characters in their various situations singing along. The lyrics lent themselves to what was happening at that point in the movie, and I don't have a problem with the premise, but for the time being it spoiled my suspension of disbelief. Jason Robards was very ill. Why didn't Anderson leave the singing in that part to Philip Seymore Hoffman, or at least have had Robards mutter the words in a manner believable for someone in his physical condition. I'm sure Anderson intended this musical sequence to have more of an art house quality than the rest of the picture. Still, I've seen sequences where actors have broken into song where, although definitely still the stuff of movies, they worked more effectively (off the top of my head, "Almost Famous" comes to mind). My biggest complaint with the music comes at the end of the picture. In an emotional scene between Melora Walters and John C. Reilly, Thomas has another Mann song so high in the mix you can't hear what Reilly is saying. I'm sure Thomas wanted to us to see how the lyrics related to the moment, but the song would have worked much more effectively in the background. I find myself straining to hear the dialogue when I watch the scene. I want to stress that I don't have a problem with Mann's music, I just think Thomas went overboard with including it in the film. Instead of enhancing Magnolia, it detracted from it.Another complaint I have is that Anderson seemed to force a theme upon the film, when the film already had an unsaid theme of it's own. I'm talking about adding the whole thing about how sometimes the seemingly unimaginable, the stuff of movies, happens to everyday people. I don't see how the scenes that bookend the movie, the stuff about the suicide, the diver and the robbers adds to the movie. And I don't see how the thing with the frogs adds to it, either. They don't drastically detract from it, but Anderson definitely lost focus. The rest of the movie had a theme of its own- This is a lonely world. It can be difficult letting go of the past when it won't let go of us.Although Thomas' use of ensemble casts and multiple storylines are his forte, in this case, he went a little far. In "Boogie Nights" we had Eddie/Dirk Diggler holding the whole thing together. With Magnolia, their is no central character, and the movie drags as a result. Although all of the actors gave great performances, some dead weight could have been cut from the script. Julianne Moore was great in some emotional scenes, but her character in particular seems to have been unnecessary to the movie. The role should have been cut or broadened. It doesn't add much emotionally to the film. When I go back and watch the movie, I find myself fast-forwarding through her scenes. I just don't have any emotional attachment to what's going on. Same with some of the scenes with Robards and Hoffman- great actors, but upon a second viewing some of this stuff just drags. After seeing Hoffman's great performance in "Boogie Nights," his talent almost seems wasted.The Fast-Forward-stoppers, the scenes that I find myself popping this movie in for, are the ones featuring Melora Walters (Claudia Wilson Gator), and John C. Reilly (Jim Kurring). The scenes with these characters have a focus the rest of the movie lacks. I loved John C. Reilly in "Boogie Nights," but I love this character even more. As he attempts to flirt with Claudia, he displays a charming nervousness that goes beyond the script. I can imagine the heartache and loneliness that his character has experienced without the script having to lay it all out for me. Melora Walters came as a surprise. It seems that the performances of Tom Cruise and Julianne Moore have been heralded, but the emotional bulk of their performances don't seem to match-up to the performances of Walters and Reilly (although Cruise did great work, especially in the bedside scene with Robards). The less-famous and consequently less-heralded Walters really knocked one out of the ball park. In a manner that went far-beyond the script, I could believe this lady couldn't function without constant lines of cocaine; I could believe that the past wouldn't leave her alone.This is a good movie that could have been a great one. Anderson could have cut some of the unnecessary characters or scenes. He could have chosen a character or two to feature more prominently as he did with Dirk Diggler in "Boogie Nights." After seeing the great performances of Reilly and Walters, I wish they would have been the ones to get the star treatment.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-10-01</date>
		<username>lupe65</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Very Good Movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" looks and feels a lot like the movies "Grand Canyon" with Danny Glover and Kevin Kline and "Falling Down" with Michael Douglas as the laid-off engineer who flips out and goes on a rampage. All three of these movies are set in Los Angeles."Magnolia" is a good movie, however I do have a few arguments about it. Whether the writer/director intended to or not, he portrays Anglo-Americans in his movie as being the only Americans who have serious morality issues to resolve. The life experience of Black-Americans living in Los Angeles in this movie is clearly dismissed.This is symbolized in the movie when the writer/director reduces the Black experience in America to that of a little black kid in the movie "Magnolia" singing an incoherent rap song as the only way the kid can communicate to a white Los Angeles policeman about a crime the little kid may know about. Naturally, the white cop ignores the little kid. Later, the same policeman does not pay much attention to a suspicious looking guy in a brown jacket running through heavy rain in the kid's neighborhood.If the black kid in this movie has anything to say, it is not as critical to the white experience of life being represented in this movie. Everyone should be well aware by now that Hollywood has always relied on stereotypes to belittle the Black experience in America. Why else would the writer/director of "Magnolia" have the little kid sing a rap song to the white cop in an obvious reference to the days of Black vaudeville?Also, two of the African-Americans in this movie, of which there are only three (in Los Angeles?), are portrayed as disturbed or insignificant characters whose only refuge from a hard life in LA is crime. Witness the same little black kid later in the movie when he takes a load of cash from the purse of an Anglo woman (Julianne Moore) he finds passed out inside of her top-of-the-line Mercedes parked in the pouring rain. The other African-American character portrayed is a poor and obese woman who has a dead body in her closet and the other a dispassionate African-American female newscaster who is interviewing the character played by Tom Cruise.Of course, when the main characters in this movie, who are upper-class whites, have some major frustrations to express, it's okay for them to contort their faces and blow a gasket, curse at family and strangers in public and private, or steal money from their employer (with conscience intact), or preach misogyny (without a conscience) to angry white men, as three of the main characters in this movie will do.If anything is being said in this movie, it is that some people who reside in Southern California are amoral and tend to lead grossly immoral lives and like to wallow in their guilt. I hope that the writer/director of "Magnolia" does not feel this way about all of American society.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2000-09-17</date>
		<username>FlickJunkie-2</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliant, but less would have been more</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is one of those films where less would have been more. In attempting to do so much, the film actually suffered from excessive brilliance. Paul Thomas Anderson gives us a powerful auteur piece that succeeds on most levels, but comes up short of its true potential.The story follows one day in the lives of nine major characters and a host of minor ones whose lives are loosely connected to one man by various threads. Anderson does inspired work, giving us deep character development for each of the nine. Many themes run through the work, but the most pervasive is that of guilt and remorse. Moreover, almost every effort at atonement was rejected or thwarted in some way, evoking great pathos and a sense of despondent fatalism. This is clearly some of the best and most thought provoking dark writing ever done.From a directorial standpoint, the film was a magnificent display of directorial virtuosity. Anderson handled scenes, actors and visual details with the flair of a maestro. The swirl of scenes from character to character, the use of the camera and music, the juxtaposition of scenes, everything was superbly done. Yet, the whole was less than the sum of the parts due to Anderson's inability to let go of elements that encumbered the film (an irony since one of the main themes of the story was about being able to let go). Michaelangelo once commented that inside every block of marble, there is a masterpiece, and the sculptor needs only cut away the right pieces. Editing is one of most excruciating tasks of an auteur since each excision discards part of his soul. However, stoical editing is the area that differentiates great writer/directors from the good ones.This film had everything necessary to be one of the truly great films of our times, but it suffered from excess. There were too many characters. The story would have lost almost nothing by eliminating Donnie (William Macy), Officer Jim Kurring (John C. Reilly) and Claudia (Melora Walters). These characters really didn't add that much to the philosophical points being made in the film and made the film unwieldy. This would have trimmed forty-five minutes to an hour from the film and turned the focus more on the relationship between Earl Partridge (Jason Robards) and his son Frank (Tom Cruise) that was the very best element of the film.Also, Anderson went overboard on the profanity. I am no prude in this regard. I believe that profanity adds realism to a film because people are frequently profane in real life. I disdain the self-righteous prigs who are offended by it. However, overuse of any device to the extent that it starts to burden the story ultimately detracts from it. Anderson crossed that line. It seemed like he was trying to set a record for frequency and volume of vulgar expletives. If all the profanity were edited out, the film would have been 30 minutes shorter and Julianne Moore would have had about five lines.Finally, the plague of the frogs taken from Chapter 8 of Exodus was ill advised, as was the chorus of song by all the major characters at their point of greatest despondency. Anderson was trying to make important points with both of these devices, but in the process, they trivialized an exceptionally powerful drama to the point of eye rolling incredulity.Anderson was so uncompromising about every detail of his artistic vision that he missed the Big Picture (pun intended). The final version that was released would have been better released later as the director's cut. If Anderson had edited the theatrical release effectively, he could have had it both ways. He could have had a commercial success, critical acclaim, and he still could have given people an opportunity to see his entire vision. As to the acting, this is probably the best ensemble performance I have ever seen. Tom Cruise was nominated for a best supporting Oscar and much as I love Michael Caine and his performance in `The Cider House Rules', this was no contest. Cruise was electrifying. This was one of his best performances ever. I also thought Jason Robards' performance was worthy of supporting actor nomination. He was tremendous as the dying patriarch. The rest of the cast was phenomenal without exception.It is easy to understand why this film failed at the box office (at $23M, it grossed $14M less than its $37M budget). It was far too abstruse, intense, dark, philosophical and wry (not to mention lengthy) to have popular appeal. Of those who actually saw it, most either loved it or hated it. I must admit to feeling both emotions. I loved its genius but I hated that its final form didn't do that genius justice. Thus, I rated it an 8/10. It will undoubtedly become a cult classic rather than the true classic it could have been. </fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-09-17</date>
		<username>dzw31475</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Something a bit out of the ordinary</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***** The following text contains a couple of small spoilers**********After watching Magnolia I was left with a feeling that I had been witness to something a bit out of the ordinary, at last after wading through a spate of films that promised so much but failed to deliver I was at last satisfied.The directors ability to take on such issues as child molestation, drug abuse, Cancer etc, with a non-judgmental camera, to be honest left we emotionally stunned and drained. After the some what flawed but nevertheless powerful Boogie Nights P.T. Anderson has given us a movie that screams his existence from the hill tops of Hollywood.What most impresses me about P.T.Anderson is his ability to get such powerful performances from his actors. In Boogie Nights he got from the little known Mark Wahlberg a performance that many seasoned pro's would be proud of and from Burt Reynolds the performance of a lifetime. In Magnolia he got a performance from Tom Cruise that left many viewers rushing to the credits to make sure that this really was Cruise and not some long lost brother who had never been tempted by things like Mission Impossible 2.P.T.Andrson also impressed in his ability to string such long camera shots in seamless scenes that brought powerful and gut wrenching emotions home without having to bash the viewer over the head with each point.I know that certain scenes where viewed with raised eyebrows and slight sniggers. Scenes such as when the whole cast burst into song, " was I suddenly watching a musical" one critic asked. Well the answer is no, what you where watching was a string of very powerful scenes such as a women attempting suicide whilst her husband was lying in bed dying of Cancer that where being narrated by a brilliant song that took over the script. What you where watching was a role reversal, instead of the actors delivering lines with a song in the background, you where watching the song delivering the lines and the actors do the backing song. The music was so important to this film that in several parts it took over to produce such a powerful display of emotions that it truly blew my hair back.The other scene that seemed to produce a certain amount of ill feeling was the end scene between the Jim the Cop (brilliantly played by the much underrated John C Riley) and Claudia (equally well played be Merlora Walters). Critics didn't like that they couldn't really understand what the Jim was saying to Rose. The point is that it doesn't matter what he is saying. The camera is souley looking at the face of Rose because at the end of the unheard Cops speech she smiles. A non-drug induced smile of a tortured lady that for once in her torrid life feels safe and loved. Its that reaction that we should be looking for not the things that the cop is saying. It is a film of reactions and emotions, the last emotion that we see is of one of happiness.I know that these thoughts are very personalised and some may say flawed. However a film such as Magnolia should not be misunderstood and filed under "I'll watch it at some point" just because some people felt that some scenes didn't work for them. I feel that it is a travesty that so many people will never watch this film because they have heard of scenes where the whole cast break into song or scene where they cant hear what it is being said. If you watch and don't like it fair enough, but don't persuaded other people not to see it, because things that you didn't connect with they, like me as a Cancer sufferer, may find so real and touching and heartbreaking that they feel truly touched by a film.</fullReview>
	</review>

Too bad. With some endurance and with some intelligence, they could have tied the story plots together and had a meaningful ending. 		<username>Matt White (movie@1982a.freeserve.co.uk)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An unusual but Great Film.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is a very well crafted film from the writer/director of the excellent Boogie Nights. Although the film is three hours long you never seem to get bored or fed up with it as the characters are interesting and there is more you want to find out about them.The film has a very serious and dark tone through out 2 and half-hours but the end totally changes the tone of the film. (Slight Spoiler) This is one of the most unexpected endings in a film but it isn't a twist. I know that sounds strange but you will just have to watch it to understand. (End Spoiler).There is some fantastic performances from John C Reilly, William H Macy and the Show stealer Tom Cruise (his best film since Jerry Maguire). He deserved the Golden Globe and should have received at least a nomination at the Oscars.Paul Thomas Anderson is one of the best directors around at the moment just behind David Fincher and Ridley Scott. He once again proves this in this film and can easily manipulate the audience emotions form seriousness to comedy in a few seconds, He Is also no stranger to shocking the audience in the ending.The plot is not formulaic in anyway breaking many conventions of typical Hollywood films as of late. The beginning is also a fresh way to start a film as it doesn't have anything to really do with the film but is interesting and even funny in a dark way.This film although not as good as Boogie nights still is a good piece of art and is one of the better films of 2000/1999. I would rate this with a high 8.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Magnolia is a glorious mess</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia, P.T. Andersons third effort is like a train wreck waiting to happen. When you finally reach the scene where the frogs start falling from the sky everything seems to go out of control. For me, it was the moment of clarity, when everything came together perfectly. At more than three hours, Magnolia is a very exhausting film experience. But it is Anderson's stunning directorial virtuosity and incisive script which holds everything together and keeps you engrossed in the characters and their problems. Like Boogie Nights, Anderson has assembled an incredible ensemble cast, with stand out performances by John C. Reily, Philip Seymour and Philip Baker Hall.Aimee Mann provides the haunting score which is integral to the story and characters. Magnolia is a kaleidoscope of colors. It is always changing in shape and form. You find something new every time you watch it. Ignore the detractors for this film and experience it for your self. Thank you P.T. Anderson for keeping cinema alive for a new generation.</fullReview>
