		<username>cousteau</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>new</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First, I will say that I would not rent this movie on a night when I want to have fun w/my friends. I've seen the movie about 4 or 5 times by now, and I know that if you actually want to be watching &lt;Magnolia&gt; the whole way through, it demands too much attention to a 'solemn' and 'earnest' state of mind. And if you watch the entire thing, your mood will stay that way for at least a few more hours after.There are some things, however, that I find hard to believe that anyone could ignore. 2 areas of this film are at its best. (1): The screenplay. This script is so-o-o gut-wrenching, and so very honest, it's almost scary! But the screenplay wouldn't go far either without (2) superb acting. How many of us can say that Tom Cruise DIDN'T deserve that Oscar?! Or any of the other actors, for that matter? It tires me when I hear about how Tom Cruise should never have picked such a 'mysoginistic' part, or whatever. OK, so Samuel Jackson can say mothaf&amp;^%r everytime he blasts someone's head off, Christian Bale can insanely laugh and sing while he throws chainsaws at people, but a character like Frank TJ Mackey(I think that was his name); whose character was emotionally abused as a child(and so has a reason to be the way he is), is so well played by Cruise, I can't believe that would even be an issue. This is a MOVIE. And not even a violent one.I'll admit that I didn't particularly favour the directing style the times that I did see the movie. BUT-And this is important-many innovative director's styles, in the beginning, are frowned upon. It takes a lot of guts for Anderson to sway the camera in this direction, and then in that direction, just because he felt that's a feeling he wanted to evoke to the audience; not caring at how unconventional it looks.All in all, this movie is definitely inspirational for aspiring filmmakers with open minds, seeking a new style, a new way to get your message across.Hey, like some other user comments stated, I don't know that I fully understand the message he was getting across, except that certain things just happen, and they are beyond our control. Yes, THAT's what I got out of it.-Sep</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>The new "must see" movie for art appreciation 101.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>&lt;&lt; ENDING SPOILER &gt;&gt;Where was this movie 12 years ago when I was in college? This thing begs to be over-analyzed, watched again, made into more than it is, and found fault with. Mix in an indie-movie intro, some hip coffee shop music (sell the soundtrack on the side), some A list actors in B movie roles, multiple story lines with not enough connections to each other to be meaningful, an improbable yet controversial climax, and an irrelevant ending, and what do you get?3 hours of trying too hard.This movie could have been 4 great movies, or it could have been woven together into one fantastic movie. It screams out to be directed by someone else, someone who can coalesce all the fantastic performances and plots and emotions into a coherent whole. I know, all the others are saying "well that's the beauty of it, things just happen randomly and that's life", but that doesn't mean that the MOVIE has to be random!The frog scene was, in retrospect, a very meaningful event for the film. But for such a meaningful moment, why do the characters just troddle on with nothing to say? Are they amazed? Are they confused? Do they have a cathartic moment? No, they are simply tired. As are we at this point.I have yet to see a 3+ hour movie that needed to be 3 hours. Please, ye screen gods, at least bring back intermission !!!!I will need to view this film approximately 3 1/2 more times to fully understand all it has to offer.-Toblerone</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-09-01</date>
		<username>ben bellouin (benbell@sfsu.edu)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>flawed, but isn't that a sign of personal filmmaking?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia, as the Los Angeles Times has said, is drunk and disorderly on the pure joy of making movies. We need not look any further than it's trailer to see how original and exciting a movie experience can become. In fact, for all my anticipation, having seen and loved Boogie Nights, having heard and loved Aimee Mann, having watched and loved almost all the cast (especially Mrs. Moore and Mr. Reily) Magnolia was a let down at first; I expected ambition, and found chaos: chaotic to a point of losing it's own ambitious structure. There were weak, forced attempts on Levinson/Tarantino banter (Donnie ranting about his braces, "is this the worm?"), where Boogie Nights had a casual comedy within an original pace, something which, if it had been in Magnolia, might have become a PTA trademark. Mr. Anderson wants to say everything, show everything; and the result is a camera less assured, editing not as crisp, acting less restrained, less subtle, less structured, less -- after a while -- actually becoming more. There's a certain amount of excitement from Magnolia's flaws, wherein the term "perfect" may not be so wrongly labeled. Behind the rip-offs (of which Mr. Anderson even awknoadged in the original DVD of Boogie Nights), behind his show-off style, his Altman-esque ensembles and Godard-esque close-ups (quite beautiful), lies a real love of movies. And though his views may be different, his ideas a bit self-satisfying, Mr. Anderson's grasp of what makes a movie move, shake, rattle, and roll, is something not to be missed. I dislike the term "autuer", I don't even really know how to spell it, but seeing a PTA movie can be like nothing else. As Pauline Kael wrote in her review of Nashville, "Is there such a thing as an orgie for movie lovers?": yes. If it weren't for The Limey, Magnolia would've been my favorite of '99.One last thing: on the basis of the "Paper Bag" video alone, not to mention "Across the Universe", let's hope PTA's next project will be a musical costumed within fedoras, old-style caddies, soda jerks, and the beautiful Fiona Apple; perhaps a joint effort.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A solid film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I found it very strange to look through the comments posted for this film. Seems like most people loved it, and a handful of people loathed it. I suppose I shouldn't see it as strange though, it fits right into the anti-pop mold. People that hate things simply because other people like them. That's probably the most juvenile behavior in the world, and I'll never understand it. Are you that desperate to be different? Compared to most of the c**p in theaters these days, this film is a gem. Even on its own, it's still a gem. Sure, the subject matter may be tired and overworked, but the acting and composition of the film were outstanding.Another comment that I've seen several times is that all the characters, like Boogie Nights, are simply pathetic and/or crazy, and the viewer can, in no way, relate to these people. Everyone is crazy or pathetic in their own little way. If you think you're not, that's your first problem. Most of us may not be as troubled as Julianne Moore's character or the coke addict, but think of how many people there are out there that ARE like that. More than you realize, probably. And that's the point. People get that way, things happen to make them that way.This film was as good as any I've ever seen.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Originality that dies with time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Don't get me wrong, I'm a big fan of P.T. Anderson's work. This movie features an ensemble cast that includes critically acclaimed actors like Tom Cruise, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, John Reilly, Jullianne Moore, and William H. Macy. However, the entertainment of such an original movie with exciting twists and turns along with stellar film editing and original writing and superb acting fades away as the movie drags on and on and on and on. I was left begging for the film to fade to black with twenty minutes left. Now, some of my favorite movies are the Godfather and Braveheart, both with extremely long running times. But this movie really kept me checking my watch periodically. It's a good movie, but if you're the kind of person who watches movies once in a blue moon, don't see this one. Your rear will fall asleep and never wake up.</fullReview>

		<date>2000-08-27</date>
		<username>Spleen</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>about Tom Cruise</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't know what to make of "Magnolia" as a whole. I know I loved it. I know its exuberant display left me purring with pleasure. But I'm not at all sure it was any good. It may, or may not, have been terrible: I really can't tell. (Don't let me sound mean-spirited. It may also have been great.)But I can tell you that Tom Cruise WAS magnificent. Previously, I'd never really liked him. Even in simple roles ("Legend", "Top Gun", "Days of Thunder") he's failed to convince me; he struck me as being out of his depth in things like "Born on the Fourth of July", "The Firm", "Mission: Impossible" and even "Jerry Maguire"; and although he did well in "Eyes Wide Shut" (his best film), I still wish the role had been handed to someone else.But the past is the past. No-one shines more brightly in "Magnolia" than he. When we first see Frank T.J. Mackey he's performing in front of an audience, and doing so brilliantly, expertly manipulating his audience, yet EFFORTLESSLY, too, almost (but not quite) lazily - maximum effect with minimum effort, the self-help guru equivalent of Paganini. Then there's that harrowing interview with a journalist... When he returns to his audience he's no longer Paganini. He still struts the stage and still gets much the same effect, but we can see now that he's straining for it. Cruise isn't too obvious about it. He doesn't telegraph. He just allows one or two cracks to appear in Mackey's performance. And he acts just as well in the remainder of the film. Some critic, commenting on "Eyes Wide Shut", said that Tom Cruise should never, ever, be asked to cry in front of the camera, and at the time I agreed. I no longer agree. -I know there are people out there who think Cruise was actually bad in this role; I think they're nuts.As I say, I don't know what to make of "Magnolia". I certainly don't know what to make of the title. Does anyone have any idea what it means? Any idea at all?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-08-16</date>
		<username>david_rodgers50</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A movie that makes you think.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>CONTAINS SPOILERS Magnolia is more than 3 hours long, the dialog is driven by the word f**k, and the ending turns a lot of people off. However, for a movie of it's length Magnolia moves quickly threw 3 or 4 different stories. The stories are intriguing, and the movie is extremly well acted. The movie is deep to great extents sometimes spilling out almost poetic sentences in the middle of everyday conversation. The most memorable part of the movie is the "surprise" ending that turned a lot of people off from the film. However, i feel that the ending stays true to the film, and indeed conects the stories and characters. To understand the ending you must look back to the start of the film which shows several examples of strange, umexpected occurrences, that are looked at as "coincidences". This is to illustrate that strange unpredictable things happen all over the world. This theme is quietly shown throughout the entire film. One thing that I noticed was that at the start of every day there would be a weather report for the coming day. This is to illustrate that we are always trying to predict what is to come. however, of course no one predicted the weather that comes at the end of the movie. This is to illustrate that we cannot predict what is going to come, because the unexpected is always bound to happen. This is how the characters are connected, throught the THEME. the frogs are a representation of the unexpected, the unexplained that touches and aplies to every main character in the film.It shows that we cannot try to predict the future, we just have to try and do the right thing along the way. This is why the film ends with John C.Reilly's character doing the right thing, by helping his "girlfriend" with her addiction. The movie ends on this note because it sums up the theme and message of the movie. we don't need the stories to connect in the tradition way of all the characters meeting somehow, the movie is driven by theme and symbolism that make it a great movie to watch and think of for a long time to come.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-08-11</date>
		<username>i1mc</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Standing up for one-self</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A film about regret, by Men who have behaved badly in the past, and now that they are dying, seek forgiveness. A Lady racked by guilt because she married for money and now her husband is dying. A boy who pisses his pants in a game show, A daughter who was the victim of child abuse, A couple of life's looser's, and the standout performance by Tom Cruise who plays the part of the boy whose father left him after he found out his mother was dying of cancer. Needless to say, Tom grows up to hate his father with a vengence, but how this makes him into a womans worst nightmare come true is unclear. (unless the woman happens to like Men who exploit them for the sole purpose of having sex)Somehow all these seemingly unrelated characters and scenes all come together in a film which makes some strong statements about the way we treat each other, especially children.In my opinion the most touching scene in the film was when the young boy stands up for himself. Here you have a gifted child, but lacking in confidence. He is taken advantage of by everyone, by his father, adults, and worst of all his peers. Yet he is trying so hard to be accepted that he just keeps taking all the crap. Fortune is on his side however, but in a crafty guise. He begs to go to the rest-room but to no avail. Again and again he begs, but no-one is taking him seriously. Meanwhile because he is concentrating so hard on holding his bladder he stops answering questions. His side start falling further behind in points. Then the ineviatable happens. A kids worst nightmare in ultimate embarrassment... The time comes for him to represent his team for the final round. He refuses to budge and who can blame him. Nothing can be worse that what has already happened, and he has enough common sense not to make it any worse. He has finally seen the light. At last he is standing up for himself.Later that night he tells his disfunctional father that he is going to have to start to be nicer to him. Not a chance that his father is going to change voluntarily, but one can sense, that this is one boy who has will not take any more nonsense.Too shay, Nothing good happens in this life without standing up for yourself and your belief's. The younger one can learn this, the luckier one is.</fullReview>

		<date>2000-08-07</date>
		<username>grazzini101 (grazzini101@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Wonderful Film, but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>...it severally lacks appeal to the "average Joe".I happen to work in a video store, so please don't think I'm "better" than everybody else, but as much as I enjoyed this film, I can't see it appealing to 99.9% of my customers. Most of them might complain about the ending, but that's because they'd be ignorant to the Biblical reference, which was actually fore-shadowed in a brief shot of the "What Do Kids Know Audience" in a sign that read "Exodus 3:8". Subtle inclusions such as that and the length, would most probably turn off most people that walk into the store or the movie theater.Again, I don't think I'm "better" than any of them because I liked it. I just think that it would turn away most people. I also have to say, I don't think it was the greatest film ever made. There are reviewers who think it's perfect, but it most certainly had it's flaws.There were parts were the script and the acting could have been stronger. The inclusion of the "sing-a-long" seemed a bit redundant, for instance.I for one, incidently, did not really notice the length. There's a lot of movies that are half the length that I keep looking to my watch to to find out how much longer I have to endure them, it didn't happen once with this movie.In conclusion, if you like most of the things out in a movie theater, avoid this movie. If you don't, you'll absolutely love it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-08-01</date>
		<username>barberoux</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Could have been great.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I enjoyed most of this movie. There were some great performances by Tom Cruise, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, John C. Reilly, and Philip Seymour Hoffman. I was enthralled with the stories. Then Paul Thomas Anderson decided to insert this musical montage. I had real problems with it. To have two nearly comatose characters lip synch to a pop song blew it for me. I then saw the characters as actors acting a role. I could suspend belief and get involved in the lives of the people portrayed before the montage but afterwards I watched craft. The story no longer touched me. I was just waiting for the final reel to tie up loose ends. This movie could have been a classic. It could have been a contender. Was the music meant to tie the characters together, to link the separate stories. Isn't that what writing is for? Couldn't he use a less obvious device? That montage will look really goofy in 10 years.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-07-21</date>
		<username>moviebug28</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Haunting . . .</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The opening sequence of Magnolia is one that I will never forget.Paul Thomas Anderson's Boogie Nights can best be described as a seedy film about a seedy business (the pornography industry). I loved Boogie Nights. I loved Magnolia, which can be described as a haunting epic about forgiveness.PT Anderson uses much of the same cast members as he did in Boogie Night, including the superb Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Philip Baker Hall, Melora Walters, John C. Reilly . . . to convey his brilliant film about the intertwining lives of several people, including a dying television producer, his beautifully screwy wife, his estranged son, a gameshow host dying of cancer, his drug-addicted estranged daughter, a young genius, a sensitive nurse, an interviewer, a police officer, and a former child genius.Two additions that Magnolia couldn't have done without were Tom Cruise as Frank T.J. Mackey, the man behind the "Seduce and Destroy" method of dating, and Jason Robards, as the dying television producer. The performances of Cruise, Robards, Moore, and Walters were my favorites. They bring such misery to their roles.Memorable scenes: opening scenes, Aimee Mann song "Wise Up," frogs (no further explaination)Also, buy the soundtrack by Aimee Mann (plus a few others). It's haunting and mesmerizing.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-06-29</date>
		<username>Ben Walsh (benwalsh29@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"How To Fake Like Your Nice and Caring," preaches Frank Mackey (Cruise), television guru of female seduction.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"How To Fake Like Your Nice and Caring," preaches Frank Mackey (Cruise), television guru of female seduction. Director Paul Thomas Anderson's (Boogie Nights) mammoth film (200 minutes long) illicits the very best out of his sprawling entourage (12 main characters). Cruise has simply never been better, mocking his narcisstic image mercilessly. The terrifically ambitious Magnolia presents us with a microcosm of American society through nine intertwined stories that each take place on one clement day in Southern California, during which all manner of torrents are unleashed. Obviously, much like Robert Altman's Short Cuts, with so many tales, some characters will grab your attention more than others. An astonishing turn from Stanley Spector as a child genius turned quiz show star stands-out. As does Anderson favourite John C. Reilly as a bumbling LAPD officer. Ultimately, Magnolia is patently too long, but because of its staggering invention it must be forgiven.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-06-28</date>
		<username>brianB-8</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A potentially great film struggling to get out</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's nearly a great movie, but greatly flawed: no. 1, far, far too self-indulgently long (why didn't an editor take the shears to it?); no. 2, just a shade too gimmicky - the frogs work splendidly, the sing-along flops. Some, but not including me, found the music often distractingly loud, masking some of the dialogue. But lurking in those great slabs of fat is a thin, marvellous movie struggling to get out. Anderson handles his vast cast superbly well with much clarity, the links between them are cleverly constructed and the message, while grim, is fair comment. Not to be missed - if you have three hours plus to spare!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-06-07</date>
		<username>Khaled Yafi-01 (kiko_85@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Unpredictable Film That Could Go Either Way</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You either liked Magnolia, or you loathed it. There is barely no one who sits on the fence and claims indifference. It's impossible to be neutral to a film like this because it plays itself out to the very extreme. Some will savor the experience; others will find it unbearable.At over 3 hours, Magnolia comes with a lot of baggage. It is a mighty test of the audiences endurance and sheer stamina. Few films can put you through this type of journey. I found Magnolia to be a well-crafted expose of the lives of various people in and around the San Fernando Valley over the course of 48 hours. During that time, these people have to confront their inner demons and attain some sort of enlightenment amidst this bleak, harrowing life that they lead.This idea is not original, in fact it smells particularly like an Altman dish. Altman's 'Short Cuts' followed a similar plot formula and also lasted 3 hours. The difference with this film is that, unlike Short Cuts, the film's various stories do have a neat and interesting conclusion. Magnolia doesn't end inconclusively; these people's lives will make sense and they will all come together by the end of it.Director Anderson, who brought Boogie Nights to us, uses many of the same actors. Even though these characters are different from those in Boogie Nights, we still feel a certain affinity to them. Scorsese often uses this concept; he casts many of the same actors in his films, thus as the movie opens we already feel like we know them. Like in Boogie Nights, the subject matter dealt with, is not pretty. We have drugs, sex, death, homosexuality...you name it. From that description, many would say American Beauty springs to mind. It's true the issues confronted are often the same, but Magnolia is less subtle, and less sleek. Still, we should not write it off as a fine piece of cinema.The structure of the film is also very similar to Anderson's previous effort. The first half is like the build up to an operatic chorus; the tempo gets more and more dramatic until it reaches fever pitch. There is bang that is designed to really move us and bring out our deepest emotions.The second half starts with the tempo rescinding, but we slowly start to feel the momentum picking up again. And we know the final climax is gonna be even more explosive. This idea is always in fear of being ridiculed if it's not done right. The idea must be to have each climax genuinely meaningful and dramatic. Audiences today are rarely shocked because they've seen it all before, so to succeed in getting their attention, is a very tall order. I, for one liked the way the cookie crumbled; the bizarre denouement was especially memorable.The acting here cannot be faulted. I am not exaggerating when I say that I can't recall a finer ensemble piece ever. The performances all round are dynamic in scope and the range and potential each actor shows is truly remarkable. Cruise, oscar-nominated, as he was, is astonishing. He has never before demonstrated this sort of on-screen captivity; his effort goes unnoticed, and he must now have finally cemented himself as a good actor by everyone's standards. If you are is still not convinced after this performance; you'll never be!!!The stories here are often inter-connected as you may guess but they are far from predictable. This is good because the audience's attention does not wither. You ought to feel curious as to how it will all come together. If not, then the experience is likely to be dire, to say the least. As I said, Magnolia is like a roll of the dice; you don't know what you are going to get. Some will savor the experience, others will feel hard done-by. It is difficult to predict who will and who will not like it. It is certainly not a safe bet. It is a massive gamble that will not always pay off. From the entertainment standpoint, the odds of success are minimal. I say this because your average cinema go-er will be tired and bored and will have finished his popcorn box with 2 hours till to spare.I, for one, managed to get through the experience with some energy to spare. Not a lot, mind you!! I did at times feel exhausted, but ultimately I profited from the experience. The roll of dice had my number on it. I don't even think about arguing with those that hated it because I see exactly where they are coming from. To argue this films worth would also feel like a real ordeal. With Magnolia there is a very fine line you walk between liking it and hating it!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>** 1/4 stars Strange journey that makes you think.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is on of those movies that will lose you and make you go "Huh??", But it was beautifully done and interesting because it does make you think and tests your strength by the length- 3 hours and the confusing stories and the meaning behind it all. Anderson shows things that you must look into and think about, during and after you have seen it. You will get lost in the shuffle but open your mind and you may understand the ending.PLOT: One day and the actions of- A dying father, his young wife, his nurse, and estranged son. A game show host, his strung out daughter. A young prodigy and his father who wants him to excel. A hardworking cop trying to solve a crime and girl. A former gamshow contestant who thinks he has no worth.VIEWS: Again this movie is hard to understand but you watch for the performances rather then the storylines. All the stories do intertwine and mean something. There are hidden things going on. Many were amazed by Tom Cruise's performance which was good but this movie is more about the group of performers rather then just one. Take the time to let your mind go and just watch by what is going on even if it is hard to understand.SCENES TO WATCH FOR: Tom Cruise's stage performance and meeting his dying father, The nurse on the phone, the frogs.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-04-23</date>
		<username>filmfan_01</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>One of my favorites of last year</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MAGNOLIA is a movie about regret, not coincidence as the opening scene tells us in a somewhat caricaturesque manner. What moves this film is about doing wrong things and not thinking about the consequences. There's a song that the characters sing (as odd as it sounds) during a hilarious sequence: "It's not going to stop, till you wise up" or something like that. And that's what I'm talking about. Why losing contact with your family and changing your name? Is it going to help? Why being a drug addict? Why marry an old man for his money? Why doing all this if you are going to regret it someday and live miserably? Why not facing all these problems for once and for all? Those are some of the questions this smart film asks. And while it gives us the answer -to wise up- it does not have a satisfying ending. It's actually funny how surreal the ending is. Like there is no solution to this problem unless something really strange happens.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2000-04-18</date>
		<username>(Guy_T)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Great Premise - Slightly Unsatisfying</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Great premise of a movie - owes an awful lot to Altman, and Short Cuts in particular (attempted suicide in garage, lecherous cop, reunion of relatives in face of imminent death, supernatural occurance etc being the narrative similarities; multiple stories of everyday confused folk being the subject matter; 'aren't folk messed-up' being the common theme...) [If only they'd kept it in the style of the three opening stories (of stuff that just happened) throughout the movie...?]Yet somehow Altman is a better storyteller - P.T. Anderson is a master of issue avoidance - how many times did he dodge the crux of a scene, having a character say "The thing about my problem/idea is..." at the crucial dramatic peak, before cutting away to the next person. We got to see who these people were, and how they were different from each other, but very little about what made these well delineated individuals actually tick.Similarly, inter-cutting several different stories as they reach their little climaxes is no substitute for making any one climax moving/dramatic. A cop struggling around in the rain for his gun is not made any more or less involving for the intercutting with a kid not answering questions on a TV show because he needs the bathroom. And with Tom Cruise sitting out an interview in silence, and a nurse on perpetual hold on a telephone being thrown into the mix, it's more a case of anti-climaxes than climaxes - so why the histrionic, tension building crescendos on the sound-track?!?Only the 'plague of frogs' ending really elevated it onto something wholly original, but it did keep going... and going... (again, anti-climaxes).The performances - well, most of the praise has been given, and the majority has been justified. Cruise got an Oscar nomination, and Philip Seymour Hoffman is flavour of the month with the independent cinema crowd; Julianne Moore has done her best work for both Altman and Anderson. Yet watch how all three have key scenes with Jason Robards, the real pro in the film as far as I am concerned. He demonstrates a sureness of touch with underplaying his scenes to just the right degree, not flinching as the others spit out the sawdust from chewing the scenery by comparison. Alright, it's a difficult role to go wrong with by compared to them, but notice that he neither responds melodramatically when they interact with him, nor lies there completely silently and still like so many other movie-patients - a really well judged physical and emotional performance.Overall, I really liked the detail - so much of it. But what I worried about was that detail had been included at the expense of clarity. It was lovely to finally notice that it was Robards' Earl Partridge that had produced the kids TV show that Philip Baker Hall had been presenting, but wouldn't it have been a tiny bit better if I had noticed that a little earlier on (and how many people were there in the cinema with me who missed it?)A really great film that didn't quite get there, (but continually kept me absorbed), or perhaps two not really spectacular movies mixed together in the hope that they would create a greater impression than the individual parts (which they didn't - two wrongs don't make a right).</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2000-04-17</date>
		<username>c.mccaig</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Crazy movie, the past has not finished with us</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought this was an original and uplifting movie, one that stretches the definition of American cinema with its clever use of narration, music and overlapping themes.This is the first Anderson movie I have seen, and it inspires me to catch the others. It is reminiscent of Pulp Fiction in the way it intertwines the story lines, but it is much more subtle. Walking out of the cinema, I turned to my companion and said, that was a crazy movie but I am not sure what it was about. The event seemed to be bigger than the message.It was the kind of movie you could tell everyone to go and see, but struggle to define. Recurrent themes, I suppose, were coincidence, chance, cancer, dysfunctionality, and above all, hope and redemption. I liked the way the story lines never quite got sorted at the end even with all the coincidental connections, it is not a neat, Hollywood ending and is all the better for that.One clever aspect of the movie was how the direction played with our notions of what characters were motivated by- for instance, when the nurse orders Playboy and Hustler on the phone, and when Earl Partridge's wife orders the drugs to finish him off, we are manipulated into thinking their motives are venal, and perhaps in her case they were- but she either had a Damascene conversion or I read it wrong.It is good to see movies that stretch your mind and trip you up. The plague of frogs scene certainly stretched my mind, as did the scene where all the characters sung the same song as they went about their lives and deaths. Short mentions must be made of the overall music score, the acting and the imaginative use of narration and news clips/historical re-enactions. Bye the way, I think that Tom Cruise guy might have a future in acting- a perfect combination of slimeball sleaze and business seminar delivery, a concept as post-ironic as anything I have seen in American cinema.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>"It's not going to stop 'til you wise up"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Normally I would have taken such a 'wise' lesson for granted but in this case no-one could've said it better than Aimee Mann. It provides one of the most emotional and beautiful scenes of the movie, no of all-time movie history. Characters starting to sing along with this moving song, frogs coming down from heaven. You all simply let it come to you.'Magnolia' with its 190 minutes is a true gem. A moving epic portraying people and the relationships they are in. Emphasizing the fact we are all connected to one another and how much people are capable of and how much people are able to hurt each other.All stories have a common core and it is interesting to see you can create branches starting from each individual character.In advance I read that this movie was hard to follow but I didn't have any problem with it. The characters were real as well as surreal. They are all interesting because of the growth they undergo. This is also what makes this movie so realistic. They all have needs, doubt and worries.Tom Cruise is truly excellent. This time he's not just Tom Cruise playing a character, no it's Tom Cruise playing a character. Julianne Moore is fabulous. An actress of classic allure. And surely she meant to have gotten the Oscar for best actress. I can hardly wait to see her starring as Clarice Starling in upcoming 'Silence of the Lambs' sequel 'Hannibal'. The scene in the drugstore is amazing in its simplicity yet its complicity.These are true emotions we're talking about.And the music of the movie is stunning. I never heard of Aimee Mann but she blasted me away. Some scenes are almost being dominated by music without creating an annoying effect.Breathtaking, very long, but still breathtaking.9 out of 10 points. One of the best movies I've ever seen...</fullReview>

		<date>2000-04-03</date>
		<username>Shrike-10</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Very, very good...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While the "Short Cuts" comparisons are justified (LA setting, multi-story structure, climax with a freak of nature) Magnolia is still a fine film in its own right. Anderson has followed up "Boogie Nights' with an ever better film. While some may call Magnolia sentimental, its a refreshing change from most recent American art movies, which seem to regard any human feeling whatsoever as lamentably unhip. Whatever else happens to him, Anderson can claim that he succeeded where the late Stanley Kubrick failed, by getting something resembling acting out of Tom Cruise. While Cruise's Goebbels of the sex wars is the flashiest example, Magnolia features several other against-type castings. Most notably, Philip Seymour Hoffman finally gets to show that he can play competent and dignified.The only unfortunate thing about the film is the soundtrack. The Aimee Mann songs aren't bad, but the incidental music is some of the most annoying and intrusive I've ever heard, often detracting from the action rather than complementing it.Incidentally, if you want to know what the opening narration and the frogs are about, keep a careful eye on the books Stanley reads in the library... then head to your local "cult" bookshop.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>RAINING FROGS</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Despite having their moments and some strong performances, I felt 'Hard Eight' and 'Boogie Nights' were a little overrated. So I came to 'Magnolia' with few expectations. However, this film just blew me away. Yes Cruise was excellent (surprisingly), but so was everyone else. Anderson has assembled the most talented group of actors in film, since Scorsese in the 70s. The 3 hours+ flew by, and it's a wonderful journey through the valley.</fullReview>

You feel sympathy for them in the end. Magnolia is a film you remember, and are forced to have meanings about. It's a beautiful name as well.The stunt in the theatres is that 10 minutes before the end, it suddenly stops. The lights come on. I didn't know about this before afterwards, I thought it was something wrong - it was thunder outside the cinema. The staff obviously weren't well informed about this, because they came in and were saying something about 'the projector went off!'. Hehe.There are many little clues in the film to notice. Names, etc. from the characters. One of my favourite actors, Philip Seymour Hoffman played the strong nurse Phil Parma, the professional, all-around-good-guy. This guy is amazing, as The Guardian, a UK newspaper said about him once: "He's there. He plays so good you get touched. You remember his face vaguely. But you don't really remember him. He's there, but you don't remember him. That's the thing about him and what makes him such a good actor."My favourite part in the film was the song all the characters knew..that was a beautiful effect. Watch this film and enjoy it.</fullReview>

		<username>Jack Lansing</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best movie I have seen in a long time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Lately I have been on a movie binge, seeing around 30 movies in the past two weeks. Magnolia stands alone easily as the best movie of the last year. I have been seeing a lot of other outstanding movies, from Green Mile to American Beauty to Being John Malkovich, but Magnolia far surpassed all of them.This is a movie about salvation; those who can be saved will be saved, those who cannot are lost. It is also one of the truest movies ever made, delving wonderfully into how so many different people deal with loss and suffering and how everyone has problems, whether they are a beat cop, a multi-millionaire television producer, or a cocaine addict. The emotional level of this film is incredible.I promise you that if you see this film, whether you like it or not, you will walk away from it with a different outlook on life. It touches you and changes you.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-03-27</date>
		<username>zza99tmk (zza99tmk@sheffield.ac.uk)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>enjoyable, but hardly one of the greats</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Again there is an american film which divides opinions in a remarkable way, among critics and audiences alike. And again, as it happens so often, I'm neither hating nor loving this film, I simply think that to a certain degree everyone is right with his judgement about "Magnolia". P.T. Anderson,whose previous films "Hard Eight" and "Boogie Nights" are unknown to me, has made an undoubtedly ambitious film and despite the flaws - and there are some in his new movie - I couldn't help but to admire the effort.The narrative structure of "Magnolia" is comparable to Robert Altmans "Short Cuts": It portrays a dozen of characters, combining and summarize their stories as the events of one day and night in the San Fernando Valley (Julianne Moore also reminds of Altmans film). So you get drama and emotions on a big scale and as it is reflected in the reactions of critics and the public alike, the emotionality of the movie proved too much for some. It is indeed hard to watch, because the pain and the sadness of the characters is shown very explicitly. I must admit that I also had problems with that direction and critics like John Petterson simply can't dismiss other people's reaction to "Magnolia" as unimaginative. Sure, the extent of this emotionality is what makes "Magnolia" so unusual, but also so unpleasant in some scenes. For example, when Frank mackey (Tom Cruise) has to do this interview and the reporter wants him to tell the truth about his family life and to tell what he feels about it - that's a scene where the voyeuristic approach of the film becomes clear. Moreover, in revealing the family tragedies of his characters, Anderson unfortunately sticks with old and over-used incest and exploitation cliches. Some words about the casting: we get a terrific ensemble though not every performance is as good as one might have hoped. I'm not so much talking about Julianne Moore (well, the scene in the pharmacy was bad, but apart from that I think the reaction of most people to her performance was a bit harsh). I must say folks, personally I found Melora Walters way more unnerving: the scene where Claudia goes nuts in front of her father, with Walters really screaming all the time, I was really tempted to shout back "No, YOU shut the f... up!". Philip Seymour Hoffman, Philip Baker Hall and William H. Macy are always worth seeing, but Tom Cruise amazed me most (blimey, he can really act). He was simply unbelievable and I really hope we'll see him in more unexpected roles like this one. Though the film is problematic at times, it also is to the same degree stylish and ingenious in many scenes (particularly in the first hour). "Magnolia" is partly inventive and undeniably intense but it has too many flaws as that I would really recommend it. All in all, not one of the best of the year, but no failure either. </fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-03-26</date>
		<username>Philby-3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>It never rains but it pours in Hollywood</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is an airport novel of a movie, 3 hours long with at least 6 major plot lines involving 10 or so characters, all connected in some way, and told in numerous segments. It was all a bit reminiscent of "Nashville" without the multi-track sound or maybe "Pulp Fiction" without the blood and gore. All the main characters are facing some kind of personal crisis. Earl Partridge, TV producer of the long running quiz show " What Can Kids Tell Us" is lying in his palatial home dying from cancer. His anchorman, Jimmy Gator, has just discovered he too has the big C in terminal form and is trying to break the news to his family. Their brightest kid contestant is revolting over the exploitation of his youthful genius by the show and his father. Donnie, a former top quiz kid on the show now reduced to working in a discount store, has fallen in love with a beefy, boofy barman and is trying to win his love by getting his teeth fixed. Eric and Jimmy, Dads facing Death, are trying to make peace with their estranged children. Eric's son has changed his name, and is now Frank T J Mackie, misogynist motivational speaker who spreads the message that men ought to be bastards, but faces exposure for lying about his background at the hands of Gwenovier, an elegant black lady journalist who is impervious to his charms. Jimmy's daughter Claudia has fallen victim to cocaine but is about to be the subject of a rehabilitation attempt by a kindly (if a little simple-minded) LAPD officer. Earl's second wife Linda, who married him for his money, is in crisis over Earl's imminent demise, since she now realises she loves him. And Earl's kindly nurse Phil is having a hard time keeping order around the deathbed, what with the dogs and relatives and all. And it's raining all the time - in LA!All is resolved, of course, though with the aid of a supernatural event. My problem is that some viewers will see the ending in literal terms when all we really have is a bunch of clever young film makers sending up soap operas. Still, it's very funny at times and the script allows for some very good performances. There's a galaxy of good actors here - Jason Robards as Earl, Julianne Moore as Earl's wife Linda, Tom Cruise as son Frank, Philip Seymour Hoffman as the nurse, Philip Baker Hall as Jimmy Gator, John C Reilly as the LAPD officer, William H Macy as Donnie the ex-quiz kid, and Jeremy Blackman as the present quiz kid. Tom Cruise was particularly good at projecting Frank's bottled up rage behind his insufferable manner and his scenes with Jason Robards are genuinely moving.Movies like this, set in Hollywood with Hollywood types as characters are in some danger of disappearing up their own fundamental orifices - irrelevant to all except voyeurs. But here we can relate to at least some of their characters - their predicaments are not necessarily peculiar to those in show business. Perhaps what the film-makers have done is to show us that Hollywood folk suffer just like the rest of us from the human condition.Just a comment re the quiz show (much of the movie has us watching the making of an episode). The questions were ridiculously difficult eg "I'll give you a line in English from an opera and you sing it back to me in the original language after telling me which opera it's from". The kid answers perfectly. When he later refuses to answer another question the production assistant hisses "You know the answer, you always know." Is the show fixed? Surely that's not still going on? I don't know. Next thing somebody's going to show the Oscars are a fraud.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-03-26</date>
		<username>Azeem Ali Khan</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An endurance test, just about worth it (contains SPOILERS!)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My God this film is a mess! There is so much to admire, but so many miscalculations; the whole thing is self-important and self-indulgent, and not simply because of its great length (Kenneth Branagh's magnificent, full-text version of Hamlet was four hours long but to me worth every minute).The Good: The acting from Philip Baker Hall, Melinda Dillon, Tom Cruise, Philip Seymour Hoffmann and Tome Cruise (and the woman who played his interviewer, of whose name I'm not sure); Aimee Mann's songs; the sheer ambition of it; a lot of the script; John Reilly's underplaying.The Bad: some of the female parts were (as some have commented already) woefully underwritten: I've never seen Julianne Moore in such a one-note performance, and I'm not sure it's her fault; Melora Walters is appealing but similarly hamstrung; the portentousness of the opening sequence is not matched by any great revelations in the script - it's as if Anderson thought nobody had ever done a film with a huge cast of people all linked together, to which the inevitable two-word response is: Short Cuts!The Ugly: The unbelievably obtrusive soundtrack. I've never walked out of a cinema in mid film, despite seeing some dire films like Pret A Porter and Sliver, but I wanted to run out screaming because of that bloody soundtrack, which at one point did not let up for what seemed like hours. It drowned the actors, made some of the dialogue inaudible, and was for me the most serious mistake, even worse than the frog rain - although I'm damned if I can see what that is supposed to be about.I would recommend this film to someone who has patience and a long attention span, and doesn't mind a film whose reach far exceeds its grasp. I think Hard Eight was an infinitely better film!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>I can't remember the last time I was so entertained while being so confused.</shortDescription>

All the performances are superb and Tom Cruise deserves the recognition of the awards and nominations. However the best of the performances goes to John C Reilly. Can this man do no wrong??? Never has a loser appeared so likeable without appearing dumb or being used as comic relief. The only gripe with the movie is that it is so damn confusing. 		<date>2000-03-26</date>
		<username>Steve Baker (s.baker@iig.com.au)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rain, Rain!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At least two thin people striving to burst out of one fat one? At least two two hour films are aching to burst out of Magnolia. But still these would be two very interesting movies. Boogie Nights, with which writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson announced his presence, also took its time. The over ambitious Magnolia, Anderson's latest movie, with its Altmanesque intermingling of at least nine plot lines, still paints a good many poignant portraits. It's worth the effort if you can choose to offer the time. But it's petty to harp on the three hours issue. The Green Mile is two hours seventy five minutes long someone quipped recently and no one is complaining.  Not many winged about the very long Schindler's list, not if they had actually seen it. And the comfort of the seats in a theatre is always inversely related to the quality of the entertainment. The plot elements of Magnolia are linked by the pervasive influence of television (screens are everywhere) by coincidence and by suffering. Magnolia begins with some outrageous real life coincidences and then begins to slip and slide about between its characters, gradually revealing what's interesting Anderson. A cop (John C. Reilly) comments on his job and his aspirations while he's on the job as they do in those TV shows. He unaccountably falls for a coke addict (Melora Walters) and eventually we learn her secret. A television game show host (Philip Baker Hall) is mortally ill as is the bed ridden Earl Partridge (Jason Robards). Their children and wives have a lot of soul searching to do. Tom Cruise plays Frank Mackey a woman hating motivational speaker with venom. Philip Seymore Hoffman portrays a caring nurse for the dying. William H. Macy, who's career has blossomed since Fargo, is Donnie, a miserable former quiz kid. And they there's Julianne Moore who's sorrow is palpable as she battles with guilt as her husband dies. As you can see Magnolia isn't a happy film. Gnashed teeth are everywhere and sometimes this becomes tiresome. But then again much of Magnolia is memorable, sometimes remarkably so. The scuba diver spiked on a tall pine tree, the earnestness of the nurse, the bartender with braced teeth and an astounding "rain" storm made this Magnolia well worth a sniff.</fullReview>
	</review>

It's too diffuse though, and the ending doesn't quite tie the package up as it seems intended to. It's too diffuse to be a masterpiece, and it doesn't have anything as exhilarating as the opening ten minutes of "Boogie Nights", but it's still much better than most of the pigswill that calls itself popular cinema. Nice to see it get such a wide release as well.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-03-02</date>
		<username>Swampfox</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A POINTLESS, BUT FAR FROM BORING, TALE OF THE VALLEY</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My god, what a mess. What a crazy, glorious, inspired mess. Much like the characters who Ping-Pong around the eventually surreal milieu of Paul Thomas Anderson's Let's-visit-the-San-Fernando-Valley-again follow-up to "Boogie Nights," this is a film out of control. Which is not to suggest that "Magnolia" is a bore. Unlike "Three Kings" that seemed to run out of steam as far as innovative and kinetic presentation (come on, who really gave a s**t about Clooney and Co. helping the fleeing Iraqis once the third act limped in?), "Magnolia" goes full-tilt until the credits roll. The only way you know this film clocks in at 188 minutes is to time it.Anderson keeps things moving at a clip that makes your average Joel Silver production seem like Merchant &amp; Ivory. Expanding the use of the techniques he used expertly in "Nights," Anderson zooms around these scenes so energetically you might think you had stumbled into an action film by mistake. Tracks with zooms, tracks with whip-pans propel you into and around scenes. No boring static shots here. A dinner scene between "Nights" alum's John C. Reilly and the wonderful Melora Walters is shot from a low angle so that even though we know that both are flawed, their stature is raised so we can admire their attempts to connect.Fancy camera moves and superb editing can only hold your interest for so long. As with "Boogie Nights," Anderson excels at getting top-notch performances for his characters. With the exception of Burt Reynolds and Mark Wahlburg (who was out underwhelming in the aforementioned "Kings"), almost every actor shows up in "Magnolia." Tom Cruise is good, damn good in his juicy role of a very un-Alan Alda-ish self-help guru for p-whipped males, yet at its core it's still a part we've seen him play before in "Jerry MacGuire" and "Rainman." He's no more impressive than Julianne Moore, and Moore's quite impressive. For my money, the best performance rests either with Walters or Phillip Baker Hall. Until his turn here, Hall has always seemed a bit too arch (like his library detective on a "Seinfeld" episode). Even "Hard Eight" doesn't let him show the character's vulnerable side as he is allowed to in "Magnolia."As for Walters, if nothing else she should certainly have etched her name into the consciousness of a casting agent or two with a performance that manages to be brittle, hard and very endearing. Similar to the character she played in "Boogie," porn neophyte Jessie St. James, here she adds an edginess to what could have been a standard lost waif role. When added to the others, it makes it very hard not to recommend this film. But Anderson never really goes anywhere with his One Day In The Valley story that seems to be more than inspired by "Short Cuts." Unlike the end of "Boogie Nights" that finds Dirk Diggler returning to his "family" having learned some hard lessons about his place in life, it's hard to draw any such points from "Magnolia," although the events of the last half hour are loopy enough to almost forgive that.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-02-26</date>
		<username>Sam_Gray</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>a fine film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A fine, if heavily misunderstood film, with the most profound subtext of any movie I've seen recently. To sum the story briefly, Magnolia is director/screenwriter P. T. Anderson's attempt to adapt the songs of Aimee Mann to the screen through an extended metaphor of Exodus 8:2. Sounds ridiculous I know, but it works extremely, and surprisingly, well. This is the best combination of contemporary music and film I've seen (I haven't seen The Graduate, so I can't compare the two).In fact, a large part of the reason Magnolia works as well as it does is the almost constant presence of background music; it enhances the emotional effect of Anderson's story greatly. And this is a quality ensemble cast, too.But be warned, Magnolia isn't for everyone as it requires great patience for its payoff, which is highly symbolic. Furthermore, it is extremely vulgar and may offend some (several other IMDB users have indicated this very fact).And I do have a couple complaints about the film, myself. First, the opening sequence, while interesting by itself, doesn't seem to fit the context of the movie as it foreshadows a different type of ending from that which we get. Secondly, I think a couple of the characters could of received a little more attention than they did (even in a movie of this length). But, with Magnolia, these are minor quibbles. Definitely one of the better movies of 1999. 9/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-02-26</date>
		<username>Jesse Allen (fidbox@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>An artist's rough draft of perfection</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For most people, Magnolia is like sauerkraut -- you either love it, or you despise it. When I saw this movie for the first time I was torn for the same reasons as everyone else -- good, but too long and too much. But after reflecting on the film, I feel have a better understanding on the whole picture. This movie is a masterpiece with one major problem - It is not cohesive. Magnolia's lack of unity separates it from other classic films that have the same interwoven character plots like "Pulp Fiction" and "Nashville." But this film does, however, have a great "feel." The acting was great, and the cinematography was innovative and truly breath taking -- not obnoxious.This film is NOT perfect, but it SHOULD be seen by everyone. Paul Thomas Anderson is a genius, along with Wes Anderson, I believe he will lead the next generation of filmmakers to great things. Once Anderson stops writing parts for actors (ie. Bill Macy) and starts being true to the basic idea of the script, he will truly produce the "Great American Film."</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-02-25</date>
		<username>(iikearainyday@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Restored my faith in American cinema</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It takes a lot for a film to affect me in any way. Previously, the only film to truly grasp me and violently shake me awake to the harsh and brutal reality of human nature was "Clockwork Orange," and possibly "Amadeus." What truly summed up the brilliance of "Magnolia" for me was when the final scene abruptly ended and my friend who attended the movie with me turned to me, eyes widened, and said, "Oh, my God."This movie is a complete masterpiece from beginning to end. It is the most satisfying saga of associations between people and interpersonal relationships, to say nothing of Paul Thomas Anderson's genius cinematography. Visually, this is the most stunning film I have ever seen. The uses of color and the absolutely brilliant lighting (like Tom Cruise's first scene in the movie, the bright light drowning out his facial features and exposing him completely, foreshadowing how he will be exposed later in the film) is INCREDIBLE.This is the most thought-provoking, beautiful, and intelligent movies I have ever seen. What is the most impressive is that it is almost effortless: every time there is a flicker of genius, it doesn't seem pretentious or intentional; it flows so smoothly that I was in awe of every second.The acting is completely incredible. Every single person in this film fits their role perfectly. There is not a frivolous moment; no wasted dialogue at all. An author once commented that J.D. Salinger loved his characters "more than God does," which can certainly be said about everyone in this movie. The characters are embraced so wholly that this is a surprisingly smooth three-hour long movie.This is an emotional workout: if it seems too long, then it is because it requires a lot of thought to involve yourself in this movie. I didn't hear anyone complain about "Titanic" and I believe it was longer than "Magnolia." Now why the hell did "Sixth Sense" get nominated for best picture</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-02-22</date>
		<username>ovid1</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The Bergman of his generation</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia gets Paul Thomas Anderson further along the road to becoming the Bergman of his generation. The film wrestles with the dark themes of Wild Strawberries and Winter Light in a contemporary American setting but with the same haunting undertones of despair and, one is allowed to hope, salvation. The brilliant, uncompromising script, the solid ensemble acting, the luminous cinematography are the hallmarks of the great Swedish director that Anderson has made his own. To this mix, Anderson adds his own distinct voice and, thankfully, a sense of humor.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>buby1987</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>frog deluge</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After seeing Magnolia a few times, I realized that the black kid is really a prophet. He speaks in riddles that the white cop can't comprehend. He wears a green jacket (which matches the color of frogs). When John C. Reilly loses his gun, the black kid takes it -- he runs up a flight of steps to a higher level. After the storm of frogs, Reilly's gun literally falls from the sky. It may seem strange, but this kid has supernatural powers. These things happen.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-02-19</date>
		<username>Havoj (havoj@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Something didn't quite fit...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I agree with the general view that this is a good movie, but I definitely did not rate it as high as the majority of users seemed to. The performances were good, the story was decent, and all of the cast members sang a little song, which adds even more points to this movie.But this movie lacked something big, though, and I think it was a lack of character development. Although there were an abundance of characters, all of them were basically flat... a single motivation, a single problem. Additionally, the very beginning of the movie sets us up for an ending which just doesn't come through.Converging storylines is a difficult feat to pull off. Although Anderson does a decent job, it is nothing new, and his work falls well short of other previous attempts such as Robert Altman's Short Cuts. Even so, I'm glad I saw this movie, and Cruise definitely deserves the Oscar Nomination for his role.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-02-15</date>
		<username>Palanga</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Long, but I didn't want it to end.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My girlfriend and I took a risk by deciding to watch a 10:30 showing of this 3-hour+ film only to come out of the theater well past 1:00AM wide-awake and marvelously unsettled. We talked about this movie til 4:30AM. This film rocked my world. P.T. Anderson drove his actors to an emotional edge that few films ever allow. His characters were so dynamic that despite the long run-time, the film maintained a dramatic tension that ran the entire length of the film.I have to say that this is one of the best thematically written screenplays in a long, long time, and Anderson's execution could not have been better. Pitting "adults" against "children" on a nationally televised game show (at a time when people are flocking to the quiz show revival in real life) thoughtfully addresses a sad truth in modern society - children are completely marginalized by adults. This same marginalization extends to the whole of humanity, and the film makes us question, "Who are the bad guys?" Can the bad guys really be the good guys, or are any of us really the good guys?Generations of dysfunction have crept into the collective unconscious to produce an entire society of psychologically damaged people. The depth of this film rivals even "American Beauty" in its thematic portrayal of society's misguided but misunderstood bourgeoisie. Anderson brilliantly brings this to a boiling point - aided by a haunting soundtrack powered by Aimee Mann - through the most clever and disturbing deus ex machina in recent memory.I'm seeing this film multiple times. I'm sure I'll catch more subtext on a second viewing, but I am forever changed for having experiencing the beauty of Magnolia.</fullReview>
	</review>

They use neat-o phrases like "exquisite cinematography" and "A work of art!" to describe it.They also bash anyone who doesn't "appreciate" the film and accuse of them of being shallow minded and "corrupted by Hollywoodism."I'm sorry, I just didn't think the film was all that fantastic. I found it too long; I found it boring and tedious in parts; I think it failed to bring together the media of visuals and story telling that Stanley Kubrick became a master at.Not all of it was lackluster, though: the acting in this film was incredible. I can't argue with that. It was amazing. Tom Cruise blew me away. He deserves the Oscar and no one else should even be nominated.It's the actual film that bothered me. Not the individual shots or anything nit-picky like that, but the overall picture.I found myself shifting uncomfortably in my seat. I got extremely restless about half way through. Tears came to my eyes when the frogs came down because SOMETHING FINALLY HAPPENED!!!I hate when someone tells me that such and such a movie is incredible and expects me to agree just because their film professor told them so.6/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Too Long</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Too long?! Did I just say that? Yes, I am certain that Magnolia would have made a better two hour movie than a three hour one. But, I was not bored once through the entire thing. It was just too long because there were some scenes so terrible that they should have been edited out of the movie and burned. I liked the movie. I thought that there were more good scenes than bad. Tom Cruise's scenes (until he started to cry, then it hit bottom) were great, and John Reilly's cop was an amazing character. The game show scenes were also very well done. But the scene where Phillip Seymour Hoffman starts talking about how "this is the scene in the movie where you help me" was ridiculously awful. The group song did not function well on any level. There were also scenes that were utterly unconnected to anything else. What was the point of the little kid's rap about who killed that guy if no one for the rest of the movie will care about who killed him? In short, the movie would not have been too long had he replaced all the bad scenes with less bad scenes, because, as I said, I was not bored at any time. 6/10</fullReview>

		<date>2000-02-10</date>
		<username>(pbrown@itcdeltacom.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Fascinating movie for those who know how to enjoy a movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is a fascinating movie that not only tells a wonderful story but also takes the time to tell it well. A story that is not only a pleasure to watch but also one that requires a true love for art! I have read many of the reviews and I am always amazed at the few critics who take the time to make a comment on a film when it is obvious they do not enjoy watching movies. I sat in a theater for a little over three hours watching a film that was mentally stimulating, fun to watch, beautifully acted and well directed. For those who left the theater early, felt it was too abrasive in language or too long need to seriously re-evaluate their reason for watching movies in the first place. Just as Magnolia did, movies are created to take the viewer to another place. A place that allows you to escape into a world that is not your own. You as a viewer must allow this journey to take place by not over analysing it as the story is being told. Allow your mind to take in all of the visual and audible aspects the movie has to offer without trying to figure out who the killer is, who stole the money, who you like or don't like. Wait untill you have left the theater to put everything together and create your summation. I feel it necessary to say this because it is quite apparent that those who wrote unfavorable reviews about Magnolia or any film like it (American Beauty or Meet Joe Black) didn't watch the movie. Instead they critiqued and analised a film while still supposedly viewing it in a theater. Because of this they missed the story that was being told, missed the beauty of the film., all the while creating a miserable movie going experience. Magnolia gave me a wonderful insight into a group of characters lives that kept me in total awe. I have nothing but praise for all of the people that worked on this film. As for those who did not like the movie, I suggest you watch it again for what it is supposed to be(entertainment)- not as if you are watching it because you have a high school book report due on it or because you were dragged there by your girl/boy friend. Take my advice and you will stop feeling as though you wasted $7.00 every time you see a movie not staring Arnold Swarzennegger.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The best ensemble piece, almost ever made.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am so proud to have seen this movie. I am a lover of films, but I have never felt this proud of a movie and its director for achieving so much. Proud is the only word that comes to mind. PT Anderson is way ahead of his game as an artist and a filmmaker. Magnolia is a work of art.We've seen Pulp Fiction and we've seen Go and many other wonderfully creative films that intertwine the lives of a long list of characters, but none of them do it as unexpectedly and subtly as Magnolia. With as many as nine main characters, each exhausted with the pain they experience in their lives, the film unfolds beautifully in its strange form of storytelling, also avoiding the cliches of "we are all depressed people" movies.I must also add that what I look for most in films of such buzz is good acting. I was overwhelmed by the performances in this film. The standouts are Tom Cruise and Julianne Moore, both of whom deserve oscars, but the rest of the cast was also amazing. Also perfect dramatic subtlety in the music, wonderful lines, and some twisted scenes. Lovers of film NEED to see this movie.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Much more to offer than the average movie. And the acting is superb. I think it's clear that Anderson is an actors' director. But this has a downside too. For my taste, there were one or two many scenes displaying intense emotion. And Anderson, as a writer, seems to bend over backward to avoid on-the-nose dialogue.But the theme (repeated, I think, three times)-- You can let go of the past, but the past won't let go of you -- does come though.Those who liked SHORT CUTS will also like MAGNOLIA. (BTW, shouldn't we at lease see the street sign that explains the title? Maybe I missed it) Like SHORT CUTS, we have interconnected stories. And yes, I note that Earl Partridge was the originator of the kids quiz show. But that mention in rolling credits doesn't exactly tie things together.Basically, MAGNOLIA is a morality tale. And one worth seeing. I plan to rent it.</fullReview>

		<username>mystic80</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A well written epic of human emotions and conflict</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Truly one of the best films to emerge from 1999. Paul Thomas Anderson once again proves how gifted he is at being an adept storyteller. "Magnolia" is the story of a cop, a dying game show host, a dying man and his trophy wife, a self made guru, a coke addict, a male nurse, a washed up genius, and a kid prodigy all of them facing a conflict. "Magnolia" is a three hour epic that tells the story of these unfortunate souls in the San Fernando Valley. Each of them with a dark secret or desire that is eating them from within. Not only is Tom Cruise oscar worthy but the entire cast as well. The performances are first rate from a movie that doesn't waste anytime on it's characters. Anderson regulars Hoffman, Hall, Moore, Reilly, and Macy deliver powerful performances. Grade: A-</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-01-30</date>
		<username>massadvj (massadvj@etown.edu)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Ambitious, Audacious and Uneven - Why You Shouldn't Miss It</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The problem with the Old Testament is all that original sin business. In Genesis, we find the roots of the philosophical view that human beings are born to be bad. We just can't help it. But that's not the half of it. Our real troubles come after we've committed our inevitable sins, and we must live with the anguish and regret. We wander the planet for the remainder of our days, seeking both redemption and punishment for what we've done.Such is the state of every character in Magnolia, and that's why a lot of folks aren't going to like it. Anderson dares to take us to the places we'd prefer to keep hidden below the veneers we see in the mirror, and he rubs our noses in the stuff from which we have been hiding. What makes this movie such an astonishing achievement is that he actually dares to do it; unabashedly, unashamedly, and with an audacity that would cause Andy Kauffman to stand up and take notice. It isn't so amazing that he fails, but that he comes so damned close, given the ambition.Anderson is telling us that our regret is what holds humanity together. It's the one thing that links all of us, and it rains down upon us like, like... well, see the movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-01-30</date>
		<username>DesiKat</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>my thoughts on the movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Many people have been very articulate in sharing their opinions re: the movie. In adding my 2 cents, I thought it was a very thought provoking movie, one of the best I have seen in ages.The movie interweaves many issues, making it difficult to make sense of it at first glance. Exodus 8:2 has been mentioned - where God's people are being held captive by Pharoah and God is raining down plagues on the Egyptians as a consequence of their refusal to release their captives.In the movie, a main point seems to be how some individuals like the 2 older men (as an example) hold others emotionally captive. The point may even be how parents can scar their children, putting them in emotional bondage. The behaviors such as obsession with drugs or sex were possibly part of this. The characters seemed to be trying to free themselves of this bondage in several ways, with the only successful way seeming to be confrontation, as moses did with pharoah. Plagues of cancer and frogs fell on the pharoah types - people can't escape their crimes.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>WOW</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to the movie knowing NOTHING about it. Not even that it was by the same director as Boogie Nights. When I found that out, I could see some superficial similarities, most notably the stable of almost a dozen actors who appeared in both films. But the similarities basically stop there. Boogie Nights, to me, was fun but forgettable, while I was blown away by Magnolia. Of course, I didn't fully understand it from my first viewing, and I may not anytime soon, which is the mark of many great films (Rosencrantz and Gildenstern are Dead, Eraserhead, Lost Highway) and. admittedly, many bad ones (Mission: Impossible comes to mind). Just the sheer power of the characters and the imagery, the frantic pace of the plot, and the startling absurdity of one image (those who have seen it will know instantly what I mean) are enough to leave me satisfied.</fullReview>

		<username>(bigd31944@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>What can I really say???</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've been reading all the comments made by others who have seen this artistic piece of work called Magnolia. Everyone opinions differ and that's a good thing. We can only take from a movie what we get. So don't fret if everyone doesn't have the same view point as you.For me? Well, I'm still trying to figure lots of things out. However, I can say that the film is excellent in that it's different. I'm a big fan of PT Anderson because of the way he tells a stroy, unlike anyone else. I'm not going to sit here and brag to you how intellectually sound this film is or go off on tangents about how it being a masterpiece unlike anything I've ever seen because I don't know that yet. But I find the film fascinating just because I know it's telling a message and it has a theme. What that message and theme is, I really don't know, but it's real, truthful, and unquestionable. Overall, it's a reprensentation of life as either I see it, you see it, or PT Anderson sees it. And that, to me, is what matters the most. All life really is is different people, different stories, different experiences, different goals, and different feelings. And as we travel the road of life, sooner or later, we come to realize that we are not so different after all. And in the end, when it's usually too late, we realize love is all we really need. If you think back to all of the relevant characters in the film, what was the one issue each one had with themselves? Issues of love! With it, we all have something in common, without it, we are all different, lonely idividuals looking up for an explanation when things fall down.Congratulations to the cast of this thought-provoking film. This three-hour plus film would not have been bearable with anyone else. Cruise and Macy made me sit up in my seat with their flawless performances. And of course who could go wrong with Moore? Her work is becoming revolutionary of our time.And most important...PT Anderson, who scares me with his brillance. You are right on the mark!And that's what I got out of the film. And it's not a matter of me being correct, because it's what I feel, not what I know. Try to remember that the next time you see a film. Until then...</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Well made, but needs more discipline and editing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I liked Boogie Nights and Hard Eight, but MAGNOLIA has the feel of a picture whose director doesn't know when to quit. the first ten minutes of this picture seemed like previews for a movie I didn't get to see. Just about everything that worked well in boogie nights -- the large cast, multi-faceted story line, etc. -- worked far less successfully here. This is one of the few pictures I can think of (REDS was another one) where the whole movie would have been improved greatly by removing about 25% from virtually every scene, and removing some of the scenes altogether. For one -- THAT DAMN LIP-SYNCING SCENE. Other than that, I'm not sure. I ENJOYED the scenes with Wm Macy and Henry Gibson, and I can see why PT was loathe to cut them out of the film, but that's why you get the big bucks as the director/producer. In any case, this film is still far superior to, say, 1941, or Heaven's Gate, or Scarface, or any number of other movies where the director got a little undisciplined. PT's a real talent, and I look forward to his next movie.</fullReview>
