	<review>
		<date>2000-01-08</date>
		<username>Matt-193</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent performances, poor plot</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" is a tale of the intertwining lives of 12 or so characters living in Southern California. The film starts out interesting enough, with an explanation of three supposedly bizarre circumstances, which the narrator says must be more than mere coincidence. The film goes on to display ten stories that...you guessed it, all are related. However, some of these connections are minimal at best. For example, take the dying game show host Jimmy Gator (Philip Baker Hall) who cheated on his wife and molested his coke-addicted daughter. His connection one of the other main characters (Earl Partridge) is that Patridge's production company produces "What Do Kids Know," the game show that Gator hosts. This bit of information is revealed as we view the credits of Gator's game show. It's moments like these that make the movie feel forced.The film also has an overwhelming air of pretentiousness. Paul Thomas Anderson tries way too hard to make his movie seem abstract, deep, and complex. The result is wannabe-art-house, neo-eccentric crap. Other problematic scenes include Phil Pharma's (Philip Seymour Hoffman) "this is like a scene in a movie" monologue, which desperately tries to be ironic, the scene in which all of the characters sing the same song, and one scene involving a plague of frogs that is just too long and too bizarre. Anderson is saying, "I'm so brilliant," yet the audience (at least myself) is thinking, "Enough already!"Other problems include subplots that are completely unimportant. Although I usually really like William H. Macy, he was a major detractor in this film. His character, former quiz kid Donnie Smith, seems to stick out like a sore thumb; his story just isn't interesting -- AT ALL. Many have complained that this film is too long (and I'm inclined to somewhat agree -- 3 hrs. and 20 minutes); they could have entirely cut out Smith and his story, and the audience would have been all the luckier.However, there is some saving grace to this movie, and that is the performances. Julianne Moore, Jason Robards, and Melora Walters are all fantastic. So is Tom Cruise in a bold role as sex guru Frank TJ Mackie. In fact, I liked all of the performances (save William H. Macy, but that was mainly because his character incited nothing but boredom). I really recommend that anyone who reads this and hasn't seen the movie skip it. If you really want to see the great acting, wait until this one appears on video.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>jj-127</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>"Artsy:" NO. Art: yes.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>People condescendingly call this an "artsy" film without realizing it IS art. This was a beautiful film along the lines of American Beauty and Eyes Wide Shut. It follows the same path of Boogie Nights and Hard 8 as in the pacing varies quickly yet with such fluidity. I love the idea of coincidences and the seemingly ridiculous way in which people can drastically affect others' lives.The performances were flawless and I couldn't help but be drawn in and feel exactly what each was feeling. Tom Cruise is true to his character as an unwitting but steadfast sexist pig. Phillip Seymour Hoffman is a believable and sympathetic victim. I would have to say that the best performance came from John C. Reilly (P.T. Anderson likes actors with long names it seems :) Simply a man trying to do right by everyone around him and a beautifully honest individual. And in the end with each characters' regret being so painstakingly drawn out, the suspense is built without the dramatic Hollywood score but with incredible acting. Beautiful.I had only one problem with it and that was the bit of drag during Jason Robard's speech to Phil which I think could have been taken in a bit. But I trust the director and just as Stanley Kubrick, I left the film full and satisfied. I think Paul is one of the best directors of the 90s up there with the Coen Bros. "Artsy," no. ART, yes.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Masterpiece? Not quite...but pretty damn great!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The way writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson's name first appears (as P.T. Anderson) will give you a clue as to what you're getting into. P.T. Anderson - P.T. Barnum. What you are about to witness is like a three-ring circus. Try to keep your interest high because it will all pay off.For those who want eye-candy and witless entertainment, go see "Deuce Bigalow". For others who want to be challenged by what they see on the silver screen, drop your ten bucks on the table and enjoy. There's no need to go into the details of what the movie is about, because it'll be different for everybody. Just know this, it's loaded with comedy, high drama, and heart-wrenching tragedy. It's nothing you've seen before or are likely to see again. Three hours long and I was craving for another three. S*** Happens, and that's all "Magnolia" is trying to say. Don't look for hidden meanings and deep thoughts...they're not there. It's a very simple premise, as shown in the first three stories before the actual film starts. Follow along, listen to the narrator, and fit the pieces together. S*** happens everyday!</fullReview>

		<username>Matthew Ignoffo (mermatt@webtv.net)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Operatic crossword puzzle</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is a tour de force in all respects including intricate storytelling, ominous portents, and the sheer test it makes of the audience's patience.It has impressed many reviewers, and I can see why -- great performances and elaborate interweaving of stories about pain, love, and redemption. BUT...The film is also overly indulgent in its longwinded plotting. It has weight all right -- the weight of an opera that seems to be going somewhere, but, like life, seems to get nowhere. Yes, it's like an opera, and at the same time, it's like a crossword puzzle. In other words, it is clever the way all the tiny pieces come together and seem to make words, but in the end, perhaps it was not worth all the ado.And don't miss the heavyhanded hints: watch for the signs reading Exodus 8:2. In case you are wondering or don't have a Bible handy, that's the verse about the plague of the frogs. At the end, I wasn't sure whether to laugh or yawn. Thumbs down on the plot but thumbs up for the actors.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A great fresh new movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was one of the best movies I have ever seen. A lot of people complain that this movie lacked a real plot or storyline and I have seen some reviews that say the characters are not well developed. Well this movie did not intend to do any of that. It was basicly a slice of life and each character had their own story. A lot of "good" movies out there are good because they tell a good story. Saving Private Ryan tells a very good story of epic proportions, but Magnolia is so much better because it does not do these things. It tells a story about average people who make mistakes, average people in which you can relate to. This is a much needed change to other heroic almosy super human characters in other movies. One of the best parts of this movie is its ending. While it has no real ending each character is given a secound chance at fixing their life. Overall Magnolia is the best movie I have seen in a long time and is well deserving of an Oscar for best picture.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I sit here with my movie ticket stub in my hand amazed, shocked and awed. Having heard nothing of the film "Magnolia" before yesterday I am stunned. Almost impossible to wrap into so few words my advice is go and see it. It is without a doubt one of the highest of calibre films I have ever seen. It makes an intelligent man/woman think and keeps everyone else entertained. Seen from the view points of multiple characters the film takes us through the nature of the human condition. We see abuse, we see death, we see depression and we see addiction. "Save me from the ranks of the freaks, who suspect they could never love anyone". These words are spoken straight from the theme song of the movie, Aimee Mann's "Save Me". They describe the movie to a fuller extent then anyone else can in one phrase. Pain is shown. The world is shown. Biblical references and a load of sub-text is thrown at the audience. This is a film that will keep you thinking for hours. Not about the film so much. More about existence, and while that sounds superficial it is unbelievably true. I can't remember when my mind has been so provoked to think. So here's my advice: Go see the film. Then see it again, and while watching the film "Magnolia" keep in mind Aimee Mann's words."Save me from the ranks of the freaks, who could never love anyone."</fullReview>

		<username>BlueNeon-2</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The "Finnegan's Wake" of movies</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's brilliant, complex, and a bit too much. I still liked it.All the criticisms of this movie are right on. It's too long, a bit excessive, and not entirely sure what it is trying to do. The several Exodus references were a bit excessive (okay, PT, we get the point). But I was fascinated nonetheless. Visually, it's brilliant and inventive. (Check out Stanley looking up at the coming rain, the back-and-forth movement of Claudia and Jim, or an oddly hilarious recounting of a suicide shown in the style of an NFL chalkboard instant replay.) The plot has a simple core yet extends and folds upon itself in several wonderful ways.Perhaps I just want to give Anderson more credit than he deserves - he has taken on an absolutely enormous project here, more ambitious than nearly anyone in Hollywood would ever dare to be. "Magnolia" will probably be a commercial failure, and it may teach Anderson to exercise a bit of self-control next time - either that or he'll never work again. (Let's hope for the former; he really is talented.) I'm not sure what to think of this movie, but I know that I want to see it again.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>1999-12-30</date>
		<username>MickeyTo</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fear, betrayal, lies, and bull frogs!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Woo Hoo! Paul Thomas Anderson has created his opus! Magnolia is a gripping, intense, flippant comedy-drama that keeps its motor going for its entire 179 minute run, never once running out of gas. An homage to great films like Nashville, Magnolia tells the stories of several different characters over the course of one fateful night. Unique to this film is the fact that the characters all seem to carry some painful secret that comes to full fruition with the help of some great music. As the film opens, doors to the past are opened and painful memories are slowly revealed. One of the opening scenes has Officer Jim Kurring (John C. Reilly) investigating a domestic dispute. He finds a dead body in a woman's apartment. This story isn't explored, so much as it is used (I suppose) as a metaphor for the stories to come. Open up the closet and the skeletons come pouring out.Magnolia explores a multitude of subjects mostly surrounding family troubles. The characters are intense, emotional wrecks. Some of them may appear strong, however, as their pain creeps up on them they manage to crumble. Anderson plays with our heads a bit in this outing. Characters who we think are gentle beings turn out to be monsters. Characters who we think are selfish pricks turn out to be fragile. I must say that twenty four hours after seeing this film I still haven't got it all together. Scenes are still swirling around in my head. There is no point in running through the plot of this one because there was just so much happening on the screen that it would take forever and it would never make sense. As a matter of fact, I think the narrator of this film warned us that that was the point of this film.The acting here is first rate. Everyone delivers an Oscar calibre performance. Stand outs include Tom Cruise as the 'Stephen Covey for macho men' guru and Julianne more as the frantically guilt-ridden opportunist who's rich older husband is dying. Anderson reminds that Altman's style has been borrowed for this film by including Henry Gibson is a supporting-supporting role. However, this is not an all-out rip off of Altman's work. Somehow I doubt that anyone would have the guts to include some of the wonderfully bizarre plot twists that Anderson uses for this film. I write this on December 30, 1999 and I suspect that those bull frogs will go down as the most indelible film image I have seen this century! --- And I have seen a lot of strange stuff!Just when we thought film makers had done it all, 1999 turns out to be a great year for unusual and original films. Magnolia is certainly the coup de gras!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Elizabeth Anne Nolan, MD, PhD (eanmdphd@eanmdphd.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Sometimes a close up is so close, you don't get the whole picture.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Many will say the acting was great, but the set-up of "Magnolia, " cutting and pasting together the "big" scenes, limits the range of acting. There's no time/space for the aura of a "personality" of a character* who is constantly seen in the "performance" role; otherwise the camera is on a face that fills the whole screen. The spotlight is always on; I'd like to know what is happening on the side, as that can be more telling. But there is no time for subtle transitions or shades of gray here; everything is over the top and hence, a bit much! Sometimes a close up is so close, you don't get the whole picture.  I liked the difference-ness of the movie and would see it again, but I think most would find it somewhat tedious after the initial humor and then going places not very appealing. The cinematography is good with many authentic, life-like scenes (yet no landscapes which often imply great cinematography).*John Reilly's officer is the exception; some of his scenes are more "background" than in your face, and hence more fully developed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not an everyday movie experience</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Characters...elders trying to bury, forget, outrun or live up to their past, with no success...and a pair of clear-eyed youths aiming at mastering their future...and at the center, unexpectedly, a man-child in a policeman's uniform who's been saving himself so he could save others.Settings...a new Valley of kings, subject to bondage, plagues, towers of commerce and mausoleums of futility. We stare at an empty kitchen, we stare out from a burgled safe, we watch a televised interview and a game show and a freak rainstorm from all angles at once, and like a passel of dogs we run back and forth across the floor to see what's happening next.I won't say this is a perfect movie; a couple of scenes slide along at a pace that makes no sense. But anyone who really likes movies should kick themselves into the theatre to see this one...maybe twice. Tom Cruise and Jason Robards join many of the best from the Boogie Night cast in a collection of excellent performances.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>1999-12-18</date>
		<username>Oopy</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>One is the loneliest number</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As P.T. Anderson slips further and further away from the staged drama of "Hard Eight" (Sydney to everyone outside the U.S.) his audiences are rewarded by modern epic masterpieces. In Magnolia, Anderson assembles his most impressive acting troupe yet, in a movie which should hold theaters captive for years to come. If Boogie Nights was Anderson's take on the porn industry, then Magnolia will be enshrined as his take on loneliness. This film is, at it's most basic, the story of 5 lonely people whose inability to find ways to give and take love to and from others winds them into a complicated maze of plots circling around each other like a Maypole. This movie should be seen and re-seen: there's a lot going on inside this film. Most instantly laudable is the best acting of Tom Cruise's career, and more notches in the belt for Julianne Moore, John Reilly and Phillip Hoffman who all turn in Anderson-inspired turns of greatness. Don't miss this film - it will be with you for a long time.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>filmfan-44</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Successful Follow-up</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia was a well-developed film, but there is one aspect that did not work well. There was no one character to identify with, and certain characters were not fully developed. This film is brilliant in its intermingling of characters and stories, but this complexity lacks a defining single character. Each actor performs their role tremendously, and the human drama is extremely powerful in this film. It is interesting and reassuring to see that so many actors from Boogie Nights are included in this film, and each does an amazing job in Magnolia. Philip Seymour Hoffman is one actor in particular that has a bright future. He has done amazing work in the past, and he seems to be headed in the right direction for the future. Despite some minor problems I had with the script, Magnolia proves to be a powerful film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>1999-12-08</date>
		<username>Qbrick</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Give That Man an Oscar</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Lesser film critics may dismiss MAGNOLIA, the new film from Paul Thomas Anderson, as a Robert Altman knockoff, recalling NASHVILLE or the more recent SHORT CUTS. They might even extol MAGNOLIA for the same reason. To do so, will be a disservice to one of this decade's most gifted filmmakers. Yes, there are cinematic nods to Mr. Altman's influence (for instance, in the casting of Henry Gibson from NASHVILLE) But in this wonderful film, about the weird synchronicity of life; Mr. Anderson playfully tosses these kinds of filmic treats throughout the movie. He does this in his choice of casting and even soundtrack music.MAGNOLIA is a funny, mesmerizing display of parallels.of synchronicity. And MAGNOLIA is also an examination of how one person can impact the lives of other. It's like the Kabbalist teach, when we act in a wholly negative manner, that act will create an evil angel. That angel will do its work.There will be lots of blah blah blah about Oscars and it's all deserved, especially for the cast. I've gone this far without revealing the plot(s) of MAGNOLIA. I wouldn't dare. This is film that is rich with surprise from a director who obviously enjoys MOVIES. After spending three hours with MAGNOLIA.I want to spend three more.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Until seeing Magnolia, I thought American Beauty would be the most deeply moving movie I'd see this year. I was wrong. A powerful, profound, sometimes funny and sometimes disturbing film of intertwined lives that centers on the notion that anything can happen - and often does.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>My all-time favorite film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" is a brilliant exercise in creative filmmaking.From it's opening moments in which Ricky Jay's narrator recounts three instances of incredible coincidences and suggests that forces greater than chance play important roles in life, "Magnolia" is a masterpiece.Paul Thomas Anderson has created a work of art, an Altman-esque mosaic of interconnected poignant vignettes in which forgiveness is the common theme. Anderson, the best of modern filmmakers, holds us in his grasp and refuses to let us go.The acting in this film is stellar. Every single actor gives a superb performance especially the late Jason Robards as a dying man and the late Philip Seymour Hoffman as his nurse.The soundtrack composed almost entirely of Aimee Mann songs is spectacular and perfectly captures the mood of the film.Overall, "Magnolia" is a masterpiece with incredibly human performances, tight editing, amazing camera-work, fantastic writing and a spectacular soundtrack. My all-time favorite film. 10/10</fullReview>

		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>complex web of stories</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie recounts incidents of coincidences. LAPD Officer Jim Kurring (John C. Reilly) falls for drug addict Claudia Wilson (Melora Walters). Her father is dying children's game show host Jimmy Gator (Philip Baker Hall). The show's former producer Earl Partridge is also dying of cancer. Phil Parma (Phillip Seymour Hoffman) is his caretaker. Linda Partridge (Julianne Moore) is Earl's wife. Donnie Smith (William H. Macy) was a former champion in the show but now he's broke, got fired from his job and obsessed about getting dental braces. Frank T.J. Mackey (Tom Cruise) is a chauvinist pickup artist guru who is actually Earl's estranged son. These and many others form a web of connections that results in surprising turns of events.The movie starts with a memorable small vignette of a compelling convoluted incident. It may have been too good because I expected even better for the main story. The varied complex story lines interactions are compelling at times. At other times, I get lost and honestly lose interest. Tom Cruise's commitment to his role is admirable. It is possibly too much of a good thing from Paul Thomas Anderson. This is a movie that is about the complexity of the web rather than the beauty of each individual strand. It's a fascinating movie and also a frustrating one at the same time.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2015-01-23</date>
		<username>uptonian</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Review: Magnolia (1999) - A Visually Striking and Heartfelt Drama.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Six months ago, whilst spending some time in Tulsa, Oklahoma, I came across a copy of Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia on Blu-ray?. It has since sat on my media shelf accumulating dust, as well as a couple additional "I'll watch them later's," atop it. With Inherent Vice on the horizon, I decided to watch the very film I've been neglecting for six months, and as some would say, my life. I figured, "I've more or less enjoyed everything that PTA has put his hands on, so I'll make some time to watch Magnolia tomorrow". Three hours after pressing play, I am left happy and genuinely affected by this film. Let me tell you why.Marked by outstanding performances and extraordinary cinematography, Magnolia is one of the last film-making punches delivered by the '90's. Robert Elswit (Nightcrawler, Michael Clayton) brings his coveted expertise to the production. It's no wonder that Anderson has worked with him on most (all but one) of his features. The framing of shots is impeccable and lends itself well into the context of the film. Some of Elswit's shots were so perfect that they felt, to me, otherworldly. That level of attention to detail in a film like this is what sets it far apart from any similar in scale. At 188 minutes, not a shot outstays its welcome. Anderson and his crew have created a water-tight film in many respects, but none more than his cast.This film is one about human beings; people who are trying to make a connection, and the happenstances that bind them to one another, whether they are aware of it or not. There are no weak or one-note performances in this film. The story does not unfold, it is commanded, transition by transition through the performances. Particularly John C. Reilly in his role as Officer Jim, William H. Macy as Donnie Smith, a former child genius, Julianne Moore as Linda Partridge and Philip Seymour Hoffman as Phil. I believed these actors in their respective roles; each seeking something entirely dependent on their connection with another human being. The juxtaposition of Donnie Smith and Stanley Spector is my favorite character oriented decision made creatively for this film. William H. Macy provides something of a window into latter's dismal future, as it would be, were it not to change course. Some proving to be more successful in their quests than others.What I was not expecting when endeavoring into Magnolia was the visual poetry and eloquent little flourishes that pepper this film. I constantly found myself relishing in the genius of some of Anderson's touches throughout the film. Even the most intimately sized scenes in this film, such as Donnie Smith's conversation with Thurston Howell (Henry Gibson) feel organic to the nature of the film's scale and serve the over-arching premise. When other films try their luck at letting small occurrences and scenarios serve to usher the plot forward delicately, it most always comes off as too quick, heavy-handed, or unnecessary, but here, such touches as "BUT IT DID HAPPEN" on the painting in the apartment do more for the story than any human words possibly could. Or perhaps the sequence in which all of the characters, in each of their states of life, sing along to Aimee Mann's "Wise Up". It caters to an almost euphoric tone, which perfectly stages the remainder of the film for the masterful execution it receives.Forgiveness, acceptance, and love take center stage in this somber tale, and culminates in a more than satisfying ending. Paul Thomas Anderson is quoted as saying that Magnolia "is for better or worse, the best movie he'll ever make". I think he set the bar pretty high with his sophomore film, but continues to create great works. All said, Magnolia can be most concisely described as a master stroke on the canvas of cinematic art.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2014-12-02</date>
		<username>avik-basu1889</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Facing the past !!!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am a huge Paul Thomas Anderson admirer. He is one of the very few directors working today who can genuinely be called a master director. Magnolia is considered to be one of his best films and I decided to check it out. It involves a huge ensemble cast. There are a large number of characters all of whose lives are tangentially connected. They deal with their lives in their own ways, while the spectre of melancholy hangs in the air.Like all other Anderson films, Magnolia is thematically very deep. There are a large number of themes that are at work like parental ignorance, parental abuse, sins of the father affecting the child, how a traumatic childhood can have long-lasting and mentally scarring effects on a person even during his/her adult life, the torturing effect that your past can have on you, forgiveness, achieving some form of redemption, searching for a deeper meaning out of random coincidences and last but by no means least, what can be forgiven and what can't.As expected the movie is visually vibrant. The colour blue plays a great role and sort of chases every character as a mark of pain, suffering and melancholy. Like "There Will Be Blood", god is very much present in Magnolia. Like humans, god also makes decisions regarding what actions are worth forgiving and what actions aren't. The film is 3 hours long. But due to the fast nature of the screenplay, the time just flies by without the viewer noticing. The film boasts of tour de force editing. Anderson's love for Scorsese is again very much apparent in the movie with the long tracking shots.The acting is good from all the actors. Tom Cruise, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly and Philip Seymour Hoffman deserve a special mention.While watching I thought there were some scenes which went a bit overboard and crossed the limits of theatricality. However on retrospection by considering how the film ends, I think a film dealing with such larger than life themes has to include some overly dramatic elements. The movie ends with a scene which I consider to be one of the most awe-inspiring moments in cinematic history. That scene has both visual brilliance as well as thematic potency and relevance. That climax alone makes the film worth viewing again and again. The film has religious undertones, but Anderson never allows the characters to get drowned under the weight of the religious themes. He loves his characters.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2014-08-11</date>
		<username>morgan davies</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Uncomfortable and Heartbreaking</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm struggling to begin this review as there are no words that are equal to the experience that is 'Magnolia'.'Magnolia' is a 188 minute extravaganza that interlinks the broken lives of several residents in the San Fernando Valley. Directed by PT Anderson and starring Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Tom Cruise, John C. Reilly, William H. Macy, Philip Baker Hall, Melora Walters, Jason Robards and Jeremy Blackman, this film boasts an endless list of good qualities.First on the list of praise is the story, or should I say 'stories'. The film follows nine different story lines that connect with each other in one way or another. Each narrative creates an impact that induces a range of emotions from empathy to hatred to pain to redemption. I think this goes without saying but the film is very melancholy in its themes and characters. The film explores several themes including impossible love, infidelity, drug addiction, terminal illness, sexual abuse and suicide. The film's 3 hour runtime may throw some viewers off but the steady pace of the stories keeps audiences interested with something always happening.The cinematography is executed gorgeously to make the audience understand the stories and to build a suspense for the film's unique and controversial climax. The song 'Wise Up' by Aimee Mann accompanies one of my favourite scenes in movie history and adds to the sombre mood that this film perfectly portrays.The casting of this film is just perfect. Personally, I dislike Tom Cruise as an actor but he gives an outstanding performance as a televangelist who tries to teach men how to seduce women. He's dislikable and cold which is why it's perfect for this film. Philip Seymour Hoffman gives a great performance as the caring nurse to a dying Jason Robards and Julianne Moore plays Robards' wife who slowly delves into insanity. The rest of the cast play great roles and they all maintain the solemn attitude that this film boasts.The conclusion to this epic strikes a controversy with religion when its weather of biblical proportions throws audiences out of the stories towards the end of the film. It acts as a perfect counterpart to the ten minute introduction on coincidences before the film begins. PT Anderson displays a series of stories that end disjointedly and abruptly to remind audiences that this is the real world and life doesn't always end on resolved issues.Overall, this film is a definite 10/10 for me as it ticks every box technically and emotionally and I'd recommend this to anyone who has a spare three hours. You won't regret it!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2014-06-18</date>
		<username>Jorn Truyen</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliant epic with emotional depth</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Paul Thomas Anderson's third feature film 'Magnolia' is a mosaic account of the intertwining lives of several characters in the San Fernando Valley. It is an interesting storyline and a fascinating study of human emotions. Echoing the great late Robert Altman, this three-hour epic divides screen time between each member of the ensemble cast, among which Tom Cruise, John C. Reilly, Phillip Baker Hall and Phillip Seymour Hoffman. Frank T.J. Mackey (Tom Cruise) has a chequered past, abandoned by his father Earl (Jason Robards) when his mother got cancer, and this scar caused him to become an expert in women manipulation. The emotional depth shown by Cruise is impressive, deservedly rewarded with an Oscar nod. Like in a Magnolia flower, the leaves of all the characters are connected. They are all connected by their scars left behind by terrible childhood experiences. Indeed, the phrase "we may be through with the past, but the past isn't through with us" echoes throughout the film. Insecurity, infidelity, regret are such fascinating themes and they are excellently explored in all of the characters. What's more, coincidence and luck play an essential role in their lives, and that makes you wonder if maybe, just maybe, the hand of God touches us sometimes.When I watched the film for the second time, I noticed the great emotional depth, the tenderness shown by all actors, which reflects on the viewer. 'Magnolia' makes you question yourself and your decisions. We all have something we regret in our past, a breaking of trust, a difficult or sad moment. Thus, the greatness of 'Magnolia' lies in our recognition with the feelings of Frank Mackey, Claudia and others. Aside from being a constructional masterpiece, this film will teach you about movie-making, about how to watch a film, and moreover about life. You just might find yourself humming along with Aimee Mann in one of the greatest emotional scenes: "it's not going to stop."</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Dan Movieman</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>For anyone interested in filmmaking, Magnolia is something you can't afford to pass.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is an unknown gem that few have the pleasure of discovering. This film changed the way I view cinematography, script writing, directing, and the way films are made in general.Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia is an articulately woven film that flawlessly captures the emotional struggles humans face regularly while keeping you enthralled for the whole 189 minutes. The main events take place all in one day and follow many characters who are all cleverly connected in one way or another. These story threads don't ever feel forced and are all equally entertaining/ thought provoking. This film is packed with many riveting subjects with the main theme being regret. All the characters are strangely relatable even if some of them are dealing with very unreal situations. This is partly because of the casts exceptional performances. I was drawn into every one of their stories and actually cared about them as if they were real. This is the best performance I have ever seen from Tom Cruise by far. Aimee Mann provides amazingly unique and emotional songs that are scattered throughout the film flawlessly. This film is impressively written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson. I will continue to be blown away by the films screenplay as long as I live. The dialogue is realistic, clever, and poetic.I am not being dramatic when I say with all sincerity that this is truly the most amazing film I have ever seen. Coming out of it I was in awe, inspired, and emotional drained. For anyone who is interested in the art of filmmaking, you need to watch this, take a deep breath, and watch it again.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2013-11-28</date>
		<username>eddie_baggins</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Paul Thomas Anderson's towering opus to life and love</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Like the petals on a magnolia, we are all connected. Not always directly, our paths don't always cross, and like one facing north and the other south we may never know each other exist, but the emotions that we share are universal and the needs of our hearts often fulfilled just as we feel the wind is stirring and our grip is loosening. Paul Thomas Anderson's grand opus on life, pain and loss begins with vignettes on coincidence, and ultimately fate, and throughout ponders on its recurring theme that "we might be through with the past, but the past ain't through with us" before reaching its now legendary conclusion and having just one thing to say after 3 tumultuous hours? All we need is love.Winner of Best Film at the 2000 Berlin International Film Festival, Oscar nominated for Tom Cruise's fearless performance and Aimee Mann's wonderful original song Save Me and my 26th favourite film of all time, Magnolia is a day long journey through the lives of both tortured and hopeful souls in the San Fernando Valley all seeking a connection, or redemption. Officer Jim Kurring (John C. Reilly), a good man seeking a companion responds to a 911 call for disturbance where he happens upon Claudia Gator (Melora Walters), a drug-addict and victim of child abuse whom he immediately cares for. Claudia's father is Jimmy Gator (Philip Baker Hall), popular host of long-running game show What Do Kids Know? and secret cancer sufferer with a month to live. The current whiz kid on What Do Kids Know? is Stanley Spector (Jeremy Blackman), being used by his neglectful father and seemingly following in the footsteps of 'former whiz kid Donnie Smith (William H. Macy),' who is suffering severely with depression and loneliness. This show is produced by Earl Partridge (Jason Robards), who is currently lying on his death bed being cared for by Phil Palmer (Philip Seymour Hoffman), a nurse desperately wanting to help track down his estranged son Frank T.J. Mackey (Tom Cruise), a raging misogynist and motivational speaker encouraging his audience of men to "seduce and destroy," while Earl's second wife Linda (Julianne Moore) is overcome with regret after finally falling in love with him now that he is dying, having cheated on him a number of times and only marrying him for his money.As the tagline says: things fall down, people look up, and when it rains, it pours.Julianne Moore and Jason Robards Julianne Moore and Jason Robards Around the midpoint of Magnolia, in the audience of What Do Kids Know? a sign is briefly visible curiously reading 'Exodus 8: 2,' referring to a passage in the Bible speaking of Israel's captivity in Egypt: And if thou refuse to let them go, behold, I will smite all thy borders with frogs. Those who have seen this film can understand the frog reference, and I believe that its meaning lies with the feelings our tortured characters are harbouring; grief, regret, sorrow, heartache? if you can't let these go then an incredible act will help dissolve them for you. Of course there are many theories as to Magnolia's ending, and in fact it's very title, and with Anderson refusing to comment whichever you agree with is ultimately that which is correct.With every element conquered with such precision, from the acting (in particular Cruise and Moore who throw caution to the wind with stunningly brave performances), to the lively though lyrically melancholic music of Aimee Mann and Jon Brion and the cinematography, editing, writing, directing and running time, this is a masterpiece I absolutely cherish and hold in incredibly high regard as an example of the story-telling format that is film. The interwoven narratives are not used as a gimmick, but rather essential in conveying a truthful and heart-felt central theme, and the lesser attention paid to the documentary-like opening the better, as although it is indeed an outstanding sequence it quite intentionally promises a different journey leading to a different outcome than what transpires. We can't predict where life will take us, but as Officer Kurring tells us, we can "do good," perhaps leading to not only fulfilment for ourselves but love and happiness for others.Like the petals on a magnolia, we are all connected.As evidenced in Magnolia's final, beautiful shot, these connections can be life-changing.5 Wise Up sing-alongs out of 5 For more movie reviews and opinions check out -www.jordanandeddie.wordpress.com</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2010-08-13</date>
		<username>Eternality</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Magnolia is a symbol of the vulnerability of the American society today, and the hope that the future brings more optimism than bleakness.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Fresh from Boogie Nights (1997), an uncompromising and open look at the American porn industry in the 70s through the story of porn star Dirk Diggler, Paul Thomas Anderson's next film, Magnolia, a three-hour epic tale of a group of dysfunctional people over the course of one day and night, assures his status as the most ambitious and talented American filmmaker of his generation. The Academy Award-winning oil epic, There Will Be Blood (2007), his best work to date, confirms him as a modern film master, and the probable successor to the likes of greats such as Stanley Kubrick and Robert Altman.Magnolia features an ensemble cast which includes Tom Cruise, Julianne Moore, and Philip Seymour Hoffman as the more famous names. There is no leading performance here; every major role is given almost equal screen time and treatment. And each role is written so splendidly and masterfully that the characters take a life of its own, reflecting almost a whole spectrum of personalities that define people as diverse as a celebrity host with health problems to a home nurse who cares for a patient on his deathbed.Magnolia charters the paths of nine people in a small town in America over the course of one rainy day and night. Each character is linked directly or indirectly to one another through blood, shared media, chance, or past history. All of them have their own sets of problems: the fear of dying, fear of what the future brings, and fear of reprisal, as well as the loss of freedom, harboring past guilt and sorrow, and the inability to forgive. All is to change during the final quarter of the film as P.T Anderson pulls a shocker of a rabbit out of his hat, conjuring up an incredible, jaw-dropping climax of almost biblical proportions which changes the lives of these people, for the better or worse. Some will find redemption; others will find themselves more exposed than before.P.T Anderson's tale of chance and coincidence is so keenly observed that it is like numerous undiluted slices of American life interwoven perfectly together into a cinematic quilt that one can pull over and enjoy the warmth that it radiates. Scrupulously edited and filmed with energy, Magnolia is a symbol of the vulnerability of the American society today, and the hope that the future brings more optimism than bleakness. This film is a near masterpiece. Recommended! SCORE: 9/10 (www.filmnomenon.blogspot.com) All rights reserved!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2010-05-30</date>
		<username>bogartcagney19</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the better movies of 1999</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Much like the Right Stuff, this movie is flawed, but great. It has the best ensemble cast you'd ask for, delivering great performances(that's true with Tom Cruise); 9 story lines that converge into 1 major one very well; multiple themes, the most prevalent ones being chance and coincidence and the Exodus 8:2 references; emotion, humor, and beauty all around; its ability to build tension, especially towards the middle of the movie; its great choice of visuals in the set design and cinematography departments; its masterful direction and storytelling by P.T. Anderson; and its ability to run smoothly or not feel long despite its 3-hour runtime. The problem with it is that the "Worm" storyline isn't resolved, and some scenes are slow. I thought that the more memorable scenes (towards the end) were weird but pretty awesome. It's an interesting film, which isn't surprising, seeing as 1999 had many interesting films to offer.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2010-05-18</date>
		<username>knucklebreather</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A nice capper to the 1990s</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" is very much in the spirit of some of the legendary films of the 1990s - sprawling, mixing surreal humor with drama, using pop music as a score, making inventive editing a part of the experience. It holds up well and, while I personally wouldn't rate it above the likes of "Pulp Fiction", I would hardly say this isn't a good movie and very much worth watching."Magnolia" is the story of a bunch of related characters having a very dramatic day and night in the San Fernando Valley. A great deal could be written about the parallels and contrasts between characters, but I think a lot of the fun of a movie like Magnolia is the viewer can notice many of them on their own and have fun thinking things out for themselves. If "Pulp Fiction" is all about the randomness of how the stories interconnect, how those intersections are purely by chance, "Magnolia" is about the incredible and meaningful coincidences that seem to be almost divined in advance. I don't think there's a lot of intellectual depth to Magnolia's fixation on unlikely events, but there's enough to make for a fun movie.The big flaw that many reviewers seem to take issue with is that the characters are all shallow. This is a judgment call that all viewers have to make, and I don't profess to have the "right" answer, but yeah, I found them mostly shallow too. Ironically, the character who shows the most depth is Tom Cruise's pickup guru, seemingly one of the most shallow constructs imaginable, who by the end of the film shows genuine emotional depth and complexity that can't be discounted. Also, I would point out that the characters in "Pulp Fiction" can't really be said to be three-dimensional, fully formed creations for the most part. So "Magnolia" is good enough for me, even if some of the key characters are a bit flat."Magnolia" works, it's that simple. I approached it with utterly no knowledge of what was in it, and I think that worked well for me. It's fun to sit there and try to figure out what on earth is going on, since the format is so clever and unexpected. Above all, this is a movie for people who are bored of formulaic drama. Whatever else it is, it's not like anything else out there.</fullReview>
	</review>

The film again tells us that every profession is hard and that's the profession that helps us build our life no matter what you are: a TV-host or a housewife.</fullReview>

		<date>2010-03-02</date>
		<username>tubby1</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Patches of Greatness overwrought by time</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For all its commendable efforts Magnolia strains under the length of running time. The melancholy at times is overbearing and although the acting is first-class the film does out stay its welcome.The ensemble cast is quite exquisite and they all perform with great aplomb. Tom Cruise does enough to make comment of only because he plays an individual much against his usual character-type, and he delivers a real and powerful display.The cinematography manages to entice and enthrall the viewer in equal measure with its concerted unedited running shots and focus. The screenplay is steady, and when this is merged with the musical score the narrative flows quite nicely. However, the film prolongs its conclusion too long, you do toss and turn, and change your seating position regularly as some character arcs are not as responsive or enduring as others.Magnolia does have a lot to say, coincidence or connections being the main narrative tool. For that very reason it felt rather fancy for the film to have a prologue when it was quite explicit in Magnolia that lives were intertwined. The down-pour of frogs, a biblical reference to veer the story from the possible to the hypothetical was off-key, and much of the melancholy I believe could have been expressed in a much more cohesive structure.The best way I can describe Magnolia is as a failed attempt at greatness. It has its elements of brilliance; the screenplay really grips at times; the original use of the heartfelt song 'Wise-up' by Aimee Mann and the cast of characters is vividly memorable, the intelligent and smart cinematography and the great acting really do plant you into the world. However, the story is rather tiresome, and its running time eradicates the emotional heart of the film. I finished the film rather unfulfilled and disappointed in consideration of its patches of greatness.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2008-09-17</date>
		<username>pcwiz1199</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Magnolia</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At first glance, "Magnolia" (1999) may seam to be merely a nice film to look at. Director of photography Robert Elswit does a wonderful job in presenting the countless characters and locations. And countless they are, which explains the three-hour length of the film. The characters in themselves are extremely complex and well represented, so the viewer is never left with a boring scene. When the credits begin to roll, one might at first see no relation between the different stories or personalities in the characters, but after a few minutes of thought the thread that weaves this complex quilt that is Magnolia slowly becomes apparent.Each character has something going wrong. Frank Mackey, the horny author who wants to enlighten men on the sure-fire pick up strategy, appears to be successful and complete in his life. But when he is being interviewed, his true colors begin to show and his life is not so great after all. One story depicts a boy who is under extreme pressure from his father to get every question correct on a whiz-kid game show. When something happens and he does not want to answer the winning question, the father erupts in anger. The host of the show, whose crack head daughter takes a liking to a lonely police officer in her own story, finds out he has terminal cancer and drowns his sorrows in alcohol. The show falls apart when the host faints, and he returns to continue the show only to find that the young boy refuses to answer his question.Most scene changes of the film are separated by an on-screen weather report that seems to only separate scenes or days, but in reflection on the content of the film we realize that the weather is the only consistent aspect of the character's lives. Nothing is going as planned, but the weather does go on planned. In the end we realize, when something far from rain falls from the sky, that not even the weather can be predicted."Magnolia" outlines the utter unpredictability of life, and how we can meet some people who might change our lives completely or add to the reasons we do certain things. "Magnolia" is beautiful and long, and you might never figure out what it's about. But you'll never stop thinking about what it may be saying.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2008-03-27</date>
		<username>Biglebowski1</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Extremely Ambitious, Almost Perfect</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was pleasantly surprised by this film, as I had heard many complaints about the ending. After seeing it twice, I was shocked that the ending was so heavily criticized. Many lesser writers and directors would not have known how to keep the film's focus intact while such an outrageous event was occurring. Fortunately, Paul Thomas Anderson uses the raining frogs as merely a way of developing the themes of chance and coincidence, while continuing to develop the characters' story lines. On my second viewing, I was more impressed with his directing as I noticed how close he brings us to his characters, to the point where we share their emotions. I actually felt Stanley's discomfort as he had to go the bathroom, and his disappointment with the way he is treated by adults; I felt Phil's hopelessness as Linda destroyed hours of his work by tearing the phone from his hands. Sometimes though, I felt that the characters became too emotional and Julianne Moore overacts in a scene or two. Yet my biggest problem with the film was the scene in which we see the characters singing simultaneously. This scene has no place in this film, and it briefly left my detached and disappointed. Other than that, I absolutely enjoyed this film and would recommend this to anyone who appreciates ambitious film-making.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2007-07-02</date>
		<username>joaocruzferreira</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Best of Paul Thomas Anderson</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In this movie, Anderson's basic dramatic situations (incestuous fathers, lonely singles, children denied their parent's love and provocative material about the unhealthy aspects of hyping whiz kids on TV) are written with depth and played with such overwhelming intensity. His eye is so commanding and accurate, and every angle of every shot so perfect, that we always feel we're in the hands of a true master.Magnolia was a thoroughly life-changing experience, a rarity considering the normal fare in the moviescape. The use of music was exceptionally effective, as the music itself became a character in the movie, and a part of all the characters in the movie. The best Tom Cruise performance I've ever seen after "Born In the Fourth of July" (incidentally, it's a scorching critique of his other performances), some delicate work by John C. Reilly as a sensitive cop. Philip Seymour Hoffman also plays a great role as an extremely sentimental, gentle and hospice male caretaker called Phil Parma, who is one of the main emotional anchors in Magnolia. John C. Reilly, Philip Baker Hall, Michael Bowen, William H. Macy, Jason Robards, Alfred Molina, Jeremy Blackman, Julianne Moore and Melora Walters also deliver great performances.How this movie didn't get honoured for its achievements is beyond me. Like "Boogie Nights" and "Sydney", this is a PTA film to remember. 8/10</fullReview>

		<date>2007-05-21</date>
		<username>RaiderJack</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent!!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is the second movie of Mr. Anderson's that I have watched. The first was the phenomenal "Boogie Nights." "Magnolia" is just as awesome an achievement as "Boogie Nights." The fact that is deals more intimately with familial relationships makes it, in that respect, a bit more difficult to watch than "Boogie Nights." The movie follows certain residents of the San Fernando Valley in a day. To say that they are in the midst of a storm is a masterpiece of understatement. The cast, many of whom were in "Boogie Nights" is again positively first-rate. And as in "Boogie Night" there is no real or structured "plot" but more importantly an observation of human reactions to various intimate stimuli as well as the culmination of those responses. The calming influence in the midst of all the turbulence is John C. Reily as a police officer who is lonely and in need of someone to love, so much so, that we become appalled at the fact, that his need of love is so strong as to cause him to make a monumentally horrible choice.Each relationship depicted has its own fabric that leaves much to be desired. If you are in to character study, this is indeed an excellent vehicle.The cast, again, is positively fabulous. We have Jason Robards, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, and last but not least, Tom Cruise who, generally is not one of my favorites, but his performance, actually mirrors the intensity of Mark Wahlberg's in "Boogie Nights." Tom's performance here is riveting.The movie culminates in one of the weirdest and most disturbing climaxes I've seen in quite a while. This is one of those movies where, if you smoke, you will certainly need a cigarette afterwards, as it is emotionally taxing, but no less entertaining, thought-provoking, and ultimately worthy to be included in any movie collection.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2006-03-20</date>
		<username>Michael_Bolton</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Flawed, Convoluted, and Audacious - In a Good Way</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Nearly everything that can and should be said about this movie already has been, so I will just put in my two cents and skip all plot summary.This film most certainly has flaws. It is drawn out, has uneven pacing and strange unexplained events, and is at times a bit too aware of its cleverness for its own good. The ending I also found unsatisfying for reasons which can be boiled down to "inconclusiveness".But I believe that the REASON this inconclusiveness is upsetting is to the films credit. Mr. Anderson has created an incredibly interesting cacophony of personalities that somehow manage to mesh beautifully, and the viewer cannot help but get caught up in their struggles. This film is a great example of a director creating with complete freedom, letting loose with all the flair and gusto he has. Virtuosity is a word that came to mind many times throughout its towering 3 hours.Magnolia is big in many ways - its length, ambition, and subject matter to name a few; but this sheer ambitiousness of the movie in the end is its most stunning characteristic. The magnitude of confidence (cast and crew alike) required to pull off this movie, whether entirely successful or not, is most admirable, and at its best moments Magnolia could even be considered genius. Admittedly imperfect, Magnolia still manages to be a fantastic film, even if it does lose its way from time to time (and although it has been said many, many times - Tom Cruise delivers an unbelievable performance which I had not even thought him capable of, and is, even on his own, more than reason enough to recommend this movie).</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2005-07-25</date>
		<username>Philip Van der Veken</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>The writer could have made a big mess out of it, but was able to form it into one solid movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've already seen several movies that try to merge different and seemingly unconnected stories into one movie and if I'm honest I must say that that didn't always work for me. Take for instance the French movie "Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages". What happened there is that the writer had added so many different story lines that the entire movie just started to look messy and almost impossible to understand. Knowing that "Magnolia" has been written in the same way, made me doubt about the fact whether I would like it or not."Magnolia" studies the lives of nine individuals, but when you look closer, you will see that the entire movie is in fact divided into two parallel stories. One story evolves around the life of game show host Jimmy Gator. He has cancer, is married and has one daughter who no longer wants to have anything to do with him, but who constantly uses cocaine. The other man is Earl Partridge, he too is dying, he's married to a much younger woman and has lost all contact with his son who has become some kind of guru who teaches men how to get as much sex as they want. Besides these two families you'll also get an insight into the live of the current and past whiz kids on Jimmy's show, the male nurse who takes care of Earl, a nice cop,... And all the time it is raining cats and dogs (and in the end more things than that). All these people have a lot more in common than they ever expected, the only question that remains is: is this a coincidence or not?If I had to give a more detailed description of the story, than I would be writing for hours on this review. Does that mean that it is so complicated? No, not really, although you have to stay focused if you don't want to lose an important part of course, but complicated it is not. I would even say that Paul Thomas Anderson has avoided THE big trap he could have stepped in and which others didn't seem to see: he hasn't made a mess out of it by adding too many different story lines. It's all still manageable and stays interesting thanks to the way the entire story has been merged. Even though it seems like an impossible task to start watching a movie about the lives of 9 different people, this really isn't the case. It has been written so well that you'll automatically be drawn into it (at least I was) and you'll almost certainly be touched by it. And all the surreality in the beginning and at the end, you'll just have to keep an open mind towards it I guess.Of course you can also expect a lot of good acting. People like Julianne Moore, William Macy, Jason Robards, Melora Walters all do a wonderful job in this movie, but if I have to pick one actor out of the entire cast that really astonished me, then I'll not have to think twice. Tom Cruise was absolutely brilliant as the sex guru / lost son. I'm sure that the role had a lot to do with his performance, but I'm also convinced that there wouldn't have been that many actors who could have done better and who would have been able to get more out of that character. This was the Tom Cruise like I would like to see him more often.Overall this is a wonderful and touching movie that has been excellently written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson. I admit that I had never seen any other of his movies, but I'll definitely try to change that. I just hope I'll not be disappointed by them after seeing this masterpiece since I might start to expect too much of those movies. Fact is that I really loved this movie and that's why I give it a 9/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Esben</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>brilliant movie - but difficult with the (almost annoying) music in the first part</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is truly a very good movie, I definitely liked it very much, the story about fate of people. You can can relate to the characters involved because they are not supermen, although they all act "weird" in a certain sense - but who is normal anyway? All characters had a unusual and important event in their past which influences them to the point when the movie takes place and keeps the story interesting to watch until the end of this (quite long) film. BUT what really annoyed me very much during the first hour (or more) and almost made me stop watching the DVD was the unsteady set of the film. For most of the time there is music during the dialogs. It doesn't change while switching from the story of one character to another character's story. After one song is over, there is a new, different song which made it to a point almost unbearable to stand ... plus the often used steady-cam which follows the persons and makes the film very hectic - even "Terminator 2" at least has some moments to calm down a bit! BUT fortunately I kept on watching, and I am sure it was is exactly the conception for the use of the music. It supports the images and the atmosphere/story, the "unsteady" minds of most of the characters - so I excuse the persistent and annoying use of the music as a stylistic device. In the second part of the film the tempo and the continuous use of music changes, it becomes more selective and literally a part of the film - thanks to Aimee Mann for some very beautiful songs. It makes the viewer more involved in the development of the characters to a more peaceful, and steady "state of mind" in the end of the movie. In the end I liked the use of the music and the music itself very much, because it gives this absolute wonderful movie its right atmosphere.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>One of the best films of the 90s</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've now seen Magnolia five times, and I remain convinced that it is one of the best films I've ever seen. PT Anderson crafts such a rich tapestry of human foibles that every time I watch, I find a different "Waldo." The greatest testament to his directorial genius is how he manages to control Cruise's performance. Cruise is insufferable in every movie save this one. The only time he "acts" like Cruise is when he chews up the sheets at Jason Robards' death bed. I figure PT must have gone to the bathroom and missed that part. The framing of the film in the "coincidences" sequence is a work of art. The seemingly disparate tales with no reasonable expectation of convergence (something that turned off a lot of viewers) I find exhilarating. I cry every time.MD</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Very good, but not quite Top 250 material</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>8 out of 10Maybe I just don't get it, but I thought Magnolia was a very, good film, and another solid piece of work by Paul Thomas Anderson. However, I'm in the minority in that I can't score it above an eight. Tom Cruise was outstanding, which goes against the grain because I think he's an overrated actor. He does shine here, showing versatility from his alpha-male speaker to tension during his interview. Also giving top-notch performances (in no particular order) are Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly, Melora Walters, Jeremy Blackman and William H. Macy. I especially liked the chemistry between Reilly and Walters. Yet the movie can drag at times. I thought some of the dialog between Jason Robards Jr. and Philip Seymour Hoffman slowed the movie down, although the movie was quick for fitting on two VHS cassettes (the movie rental place was out of DVDs at the time!) What irked me was it felt like I was force-fed Aimee Mann. Her version of "One" playing at the beginning of the film while the characters was just irritating. I can't stand milquetoast remakes of old songs, and they plopped one in. It felt like neighbors making too much noise when you're ... well ... trying to watch a movie! I also felt that the scene where the actors were singing along to one of her songs was forced and unnecessary. Mann has been a critics darling for years, yet she can't make more than minor waves to the public since she was in Til Tuesday! Obviously the powers that be for this film are in the former category. Still, overall solid work. Anderson hits a triple after a home run with Boogie Nights. Reilly and Walters should work together again.</fullReview>
