	<review>
		<date>2003-07-16</date>
		<username>(cyberwares@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A remarkable and straight-forward film about coincidence</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A critic once said about Magnolia that it was a movie where "Director P. T. Anderson just wanted to masturbate all over film." The same thing was said about Alfred Hitchcock's "Vertigo." It could been seen that way since Tom Cruise, William H. Macy and Julianne Moore are given surprising tasks in their performances... as if it were planned to take the biggest actors and have them do very out-of-character things. It can also be given that criticism because the film is over three hours long with continual shots of beautiful cinematography and subtle film tricks.The tone of this film is somber and reflective. As each story unfolds, each character has made a grave mistake or was "at the wrong place at the wrong time" and takes the rest of the movie to work over it and/or reflect upon it. While all this does not sound like the most interesting storyline for a movie (with no brainless action sequences like Fast and the Furious), the dialogue and the chain of events will keep you glued to the seat. Yes, you will have to "think", but if you are that ignorant of meaningful language you might as well stick to the action movies because this movie is not for you.What must be taken into account is that this film is based on the interesting facet of life called "coincidence." In fact, the film opens with three weird stories, all very remarkable, all interesting and immediately to the point. From then on it sets a tone that weird things do happen at the strangest of times... but sometimes they aren't as surprising as they seem. The story of Magnolia is based on this concept, and with the fact that you have more than seven different storylines going on at once, three hours is a minimal amount of time to display such a story.I won't go into exploring all the storylines as that would take up too much room, but I will credit the film in many cases. First off, the pace of the movie is fantastic. It may seem slow, as many P. T. Anderson movies tend to be, but they are always with poignant moments to keep your attention. Just when you want to nod off you're brought back by another coincidence or intense image. The acting in this movie is some of the best in film history. Each actor gives the best performance they can muster with their given lines. Sometimes you are so caught in the emotion of the performance that you're caught with your jaw hanging open.The dialogue in this movie is incredible. A friend of mine once said that P. T. is able to take the most mundane of conversations heard in reality and screw with it to become an amazingly poignant speech. Magnolia is filled with this. The lines are believable while at the same time off-the-wall, all contributing to the overall madness of this film.There are moments of utter insanity. P. T. is a master of tension, and it builds and builds to the point where you cling to the seat, just wishing the end would come. This is like Darren Aronofsky's "Requiem for a Dream's" climax except the tension is wrought out longer and more excrutiating as the sequence of events coincide with everyone's storyline, making it a long, drawn out process of breakdown. Every character is driven to the edge, every character is holding back, the rope holding the bridge is on its last strand. By the time the climax hits, you're drained, and the events that occur slowly loosen you, like a drawn-out orgasm.Not to be forgotten, Aimee Mann gives this film a wonderful tone. Her voice and her music blend in perfectly, carrying the song through its rough edges and reflective tone. Her song is even sung by everyone in the movie, a very important moment to note.Three hours long with excellent... everything. Many of you will be turned off by having to listen to words the whole time and make sense of things but you must realize there is nothing to figure out, this is no puzzle of a movie. It's all clearly placed for you to see for yourself. There is no mystery or game behind it, there's just a lot of unexplained symbolism and social extremities that you must bear through in order to see just how beautiful this movie is. Give yourself a day where you've slept fine, have a nice dinner, call up a friend or see it alone, just be comfortable and let yourself be taken into the environment P. T. wants to present. It's a breathless three hour trip into the weird events of life and the consequences of our life, as well as the validity of our very existence. Remarkable. 10 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-04-04</date>
		<username>silverzero</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Episodic, elegant and brilliantly performed portrayal of life, love and death.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING: PLOT SPOILERSP.T. Anderson's episodic ensemble drama really is a piece of work. It is a complex, sprawling and gripping character study of hope and destiny. Perhaps it is a bit too strange for the mainstream audience though, and the film isn't flawless.The storyline is that on one day in Los Angeles, the lives of loosely connected people intertwine and interact. The film only vaguely remains true to this plot. There are really only two ends of the story (the Partridges and the Gators) and in the end there is no real link between the two families. At the start of the movie, we see some unusual coincidences that occurred in the past. So the film is supposed to be one long coincidence from start to finish. But the conclusion needs a bit of figuring out and even then it is still a bit unsatisfying.Over the three hours, there are there are eight or nine different plots. All of these are equally entertaining and engrossing. When one plot reaches a climax it switches over to another plot. This keeps you engaged to the actions and wondering what will happen next. The only minorly disappointing plot is the one involving Jason Robards grieving over his inevitable death. This seems a rather soap-opera like and drags on a bit too long. But the strength of the other plots, the originality and unique quality prevent the film from going to far into the realms of TV movie hell.The large ensemble cast work brilliantly together and are well suited to their roles. The most impressive is Tom Cruise as the shallow, arrogant, misogynistic and just plain b***ard sex-guru, Frank T. J. Mackey. Julianne Moore character is a depressive, gold-digging, hysterical and unstable woman. For most of her scenes she is complaining and being paranoid, which is a shame because she gives a terrific performance. I'm surprised she didn't get an Oscar nomination. John C. Reilly probably has the most interesting story and gives a very humane performance as the unloved cop. William H. Macy is brilliant is the disillusioned ex-child prodigy. Jason Robards and Philip Baker Hall are both very good as the distraught, dying sixty something-ers. So the acting standard is indeed, outstanding.The directing styles are strange to say the least. The film starts out as a humane, lightweight and occasionally humorous slice of life. Then it's a drama about disparate people finding a meaning and a place in life. It then escalates into a heavy-handed tearjerker focusing on family relationships. The film finally climaxes with surrealness and a minor degree of horror. These odd directing techniques never quite blend in and the overall effect is uneven. However, this does add to its memorable and one-of-a-kind atmosphere.The film's ending isn't bad, but doesn't make a huge amount of sense and isn't so much an explanation but rather a surprising conclusion. As you can see, the film isn't perfect but flaws are inevitable. The more you think back on it, the more sense it makes and the more you'll probably like it.Overall, I think that `Magnolia' is a brilliant and highly memorable movie. It is an unusual movie experience and for a three-hour movie you don't feel the time going by at all. It should have won the Best Picture for 1999 instead of the blatantly manipulative and much overrated `American Beauty'. I give Magnolia 8.2/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-01-06</date>
		<username>Stefan Stenudd</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Dazed like in a Bosch painting or a Dali dream.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's not that the three hours passed quickly - they really didn't - but I was mesmerized the whole time. It was like not only watching, but being contained inside a painting by Bosch, the Medieval "surrealist", or a dream in the head of Dali, Bosch's 20th century equivalent. Everything in the film - the scenery, the characters, the events - had a heavy scent of higher truth, of outlining the world as it really is.No, I'm not sure that the world according to director/writer Paul Thomas Anderson is more true than anyone else's - but his vision is portrayed with such clarity and emphasis, it is definitely true to him, and believable to us others.We get to follow the absurd situation of several characters, and how their drastic fates get interwoven. It's a sophisticated plot, indeed, which could easily turn it into more of an intellectual construction than a story of flesh and blood. It doesn't happen, though, and don't ask me why not. I guess it's simply too well told.Usually, the writer and the director being one and the same, lessens the end result. When a story is to be realized - on stage or on screen - it gains from the natural conflict between writer and director. Already there, a struggle is introduced. Anderson is one of the few to pull it off - which puts him way up there among Bergman and the like.But can he repeat his feat? I wonder. The width and depth of Magnolia rather suggest that he has, by this movie, told all the stories he had in his head. I hope I'm wrong.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-10-01</date>
		<username>kyle_c</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>**** out of ****</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Paul Thomas Anderson's follow up to "Boogie Nights" follows a series of characters through a day in their lives, showing the strange coincidences that connect their lives. Technically spectacular, and beautifully made, with outstanding performances from every single member of the ensemble cast. It's sprawling, and lends itself to the criticism that it spreads itself to thin. Instead I admire it's ambition, and consider it remarkable that such a massive effort could turn out so cohesively. It's not going to satisfy people who need a film to resolve itself in a nice little package, especially in the now famous climax. This scene, along with several others, while strange, capture the true nature of what cinema is all about.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-18</date>
		<username>Zen Bones</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Heart and Dignity</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>P.T. Anderson is an enigma to me. On both the MAGNOLIA and BOOGIE NIGHTS DVDs, he comes off as incredibly inarticulate and unenlightened, even in clips showing him directing. I keep thinking that there's no way that anyone who seems less intelligent than your average twelve-year-old could make such brilliant movies, but perhaps that's why in part, the characters in his films are so appealing. Take for example, the cast of BOOGIE NIGHTS.What they lack in depth and intelligence, they make up for in heart and dignity. It is heart and dignity that inevitably, make his films work and makes them fault-proof. One can claim that Anderson is overly ambitious, indulgent, or long-winded, or even not as 'deep' or as clever as some people like to think he is. There might be a slight ring of truth to all that but inevitably, to fault him for those reasons is like complaining that your spouse loves you too much. People originally flocked to see BOOGIE NIGHTS to see something about the porn industry. What they ended up seeing was a film about everyday people who have a great deal of charm and dignity, despite their obvious flaws. In MAGNOLIA, Anderson takes us further, back into our roots. He shows us how we have the same needs as adults that we had as children. Those needs are simply, love and respect. Those who don't get enough love and respect usually end up unable to love others, and are unable to respect themselves. This is certainly no deep philosophy. Yet lots of people are messed up all the same, so there is something to the idea of showing it in a variety of ways that are not preachy or didactic. The problem is, often when a director reaches out to an audience's heart and imagination, there are going to be more than a few people who will go on red alert. We get manipulated to feel all sorts of mush by Hollywood. Is this just another trick to pull our heartstrings in artful camouflage?I shudder when I read people complain about how Jason Robards "rambles on" on his monologue. It is certainly not comfortable to stare into the face of a dying man as he agonizes more over his lifetime of insensitivity towards others than over his personal physical pain. Perhaps those people are finding that "insensitivity" too close to home (?). As Anderson shows us, it isn't easy, and it certainly is "messy" (to quote one reviewer here), but we should be grateful that Anderson shows us the untidiness and the occasional lack of cohesion that is life. This film is a cathartic poem, and an opera, which is an audacious thing for a film to be. Because of the low-key acting and the pure simplicity of the action, the film feels realistic. But if we paid attention toward the beginning, we can see that we are being told a fable. Coincidences and odd situations sometimes blend into real life, or at least exist in such strong parallels in our imaginations that it is within the laws of fable-telling (and opera) that one may step over the boundaries of "legitimate" storytelling. So a scuba diver may die in a tree, people may break out of the boundaries of conventional storytelling to sing, and an aberrant rain could fall from the sky. The rule that has not been broken or abused in this film is its theme of dignity. Where most films in Hollywood like FORREST GUMP reduce human dignity to a philosophy that can be summed up on a bumper sticker, this film creates a whole canvas of the human condition. Some characters seem a tad overblown, but if one is looking closely, one can see their whole life and how it came to pass that their condition came to be so extreme.The film starts off with the song "One is the Loneliest Number", but we are then given the opportunity to see how our lives do connect, both directly and indirectly. We are not individuals lost in the wilderness. That is what the film is saying. It is simple, but it is pure in its sincerity. In the midst of individual despair, there is a collective consciousness that can be either destructive or cleansing. Perhaps it will take something like an "aberrant rain" to make us realize just how much whatever falls on each of us, falls on all of us. But watching and enjoying this film will do that just as well!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-10-05</date>
		<username>Jugu Abraham (jugu_abraham@yahoo.co.uk)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Superb editing, good performances, and Biblical allusions do not add up to a great film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched the movie twice in 24 hours, not that I liked it so much but more because I kept dozing off in between and I wanted to check out if I missed out something that was profound or integral to the movie. This is my first and only P T Anderson movie. While I did notice that much of the film revolved around the Bible's Exodus 8:2 (82 on the hanging scene, 82 on the plane, Exodus 8.2 on the street signs, 82% humidity?and finally the frogs) on my second viewing, I could never figure out why this film's script HAD to use the word `f..k' nearly 200 times. Will Mr Anderson answer that one? Especially when the film's leading character the police officer Jim is vocal against the use of foul language and appears as an antidote in the film to excessive use of foul language. Would the film have been less powerful without the profanity spewing out of almost all the characters (including the fat boy on the quiz team)? I found it interesting that Anderson liked to make the film revolve around Exodus 8:2, while another great American director Terrence Mallick made his `The Thin Red Line' revolve around another Biblical verse-1 John 4:4 through tattoos and dialogues in his film made 2 years ago. Actor John C Reilly was a treat to watch in both these films, another common factor between the two movies. As a director, I prefer to watch Robert Altman's cinema?he has more panache than Anderson, (compare Altman's `the Wedding' or `Nashville' with `Magnolia', for instance). Altman has been more successful pulling together diverse situations with a common thread to provide a cinematic essay on a single subject.However, where the Anderson film scores almost a perfect 10 is in the handling of editing of sound and visuals. Take the sequences of Stanley answering the question on Bizet's `Carmen' followed by `Carmen' playing in Claudia's house. Brilliant I thought, but hold on--there's a minor flaw. Claudia could not be playing Carmen-it does not fit in with her character or lifestyle-it is evidently Anderson choosing to play `Carmen' on the soundtrack to suggest a parallel love story and connectivity between the situations. But is it a parallel love story between Jim and Claudia that is emerging? I don't believe it is. The flaw is not in the editing; it is in the direction. Anderson is intelligent and a cut above most Hollywood directors but he does not belong to the class of Mallick, Kubrick or even Altman. There are other such visual editing and sound editing examples (coffee being thrown out by Jim immediately followed by Gator being offered a drink, conversation of previous scenes continuing over other visuals) notable for their intelligent use of the craft. I cannot say if they were the contributions of the director or entirely that of the editor-but in any case the editing was top notch. The use of Richard Strauss's `Also Sprach Zarathustra' to introduce the Tom Cruise character was good but what's new? From Kubrick in his `2001'onwards, dozens of directors have used this aural metaphor. Yet his use of Aimee Mann's songs were good and effective-(again Altman did better with the use of Leonard Cohen's songs in `McCabe and Mrs Miller') but did Anderson have to have all the characters singing along with Aimee to underline the linkage between the characters? Somewhere, Anderson is not confident of communicating and has to use tacky methods to convey what he wants to say-which is what Mallick and Kubrick would not do. There were vignettes of the film, which I thought were absolutely lovely. They include the long shot of Jim the policeman (John Reilly against the police car) over the young black American's head in the foreground, the policeman dropping his baton in front of Claudia's door, the conversation on `difference between children and angels' at the bar. The performances of late Jason Robards (his last role), Julian Moore (the lady looked evil spewing out profanities), Reilly as Jim, and Melora Walters as Claudia, Tom Cruise, Henry Gibson as Thurston Howell, April Grace as the TV interviewer made the film a worthwhile experience for me. Hats off to the editor Dylan Tichenor and the collective sound department. I am sure we can expect better cinema from Anderson and his team in the future but `Magnolia' the flowering tree and the film have not impressed my senses in any exceptional way.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-17</date>
		<username>hungryhippo1970</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Great Flick!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILERS!!! BEWARE!!!I've seen this movie once and it ranks up with my absolute favorites. I saw it in the theatre a while ago and couldn't take my eyes off the screen, although i could hear the complaints of other people in the seats behind me. Up front, you should know that this movie is damn long, and that it's not for everyone (not that any movie really is, I suppose). Afterwards, in talking with friends about this movie, I heard comments as varying as the comments I've read on here. One friend mentioned "What was the point of that movie? Everything's interconnected? So what?" Another friend thought it was amatuerish and far too long. Another was excitedly talking about it for weeks after having seen it, still trying to unearth things she didn't notice initially. Regardless of what the reaction was, it definitely succeeded in eliciting just that, an emphatic reaction, from everyone I spoke with. Which, in a time where some may think we've "seen it all," is something worth noting. It deals with many extremely unhappy people in extremely depressing situations, but it is no way a depressing movie. It's ultimately a movie of hope. And while it's obvious that it's overall message is that of redemption and forgiveness and acceptance of our individual lives and everything that's previously bothered us, as well as the importance of owning up to the lives we've led before we can wholly move on to better things, it's told in such an unconventional way by today's standards that it gets lost for some.As far as the length, I figure there are plenty of movies out there that DID get edited down to a more readily acceptable length. Hell, somebody had to leave everything in to see what would happen. And while there, why not just go all out? I completely respect and enjoyed everything about this movie for not in any way (that I can see) giving in to the idea of what "should be done." Instead it seemed a work of passion. In regards to people I've talked with who couldn't make any sense out of the frog storm, I've said a few things from what I could figure out: Firstly, it's in the bible, which is made obvious throughout the movie by conveying the exact passage countless times to the viewers. If you have a problem simply with the frog storm, it's not with the movie, it's with the preivous book. Secondly, some people I talked to asked why the hell it had to be "frogs"......why not just a gigantic thunderstorm? To that I answer "I don't know." And I don't think anybody should know. If anybody did, it would ruin the effect of the event itself, because it's origins could be traced back to something human and/or earthly and 100% explainable without the existence of another higher power, so to speak. I saw the storm as a big reminder to all the characters in the movie who thought their problems were more overwhelming than any other problems imaginable (which would be pretty much every character). A reminder that, regardless of how bad it might seem to be, there's still something out there beyond our comprehension that/who is watching us and basically letting us know it's okay.......we're not that badly off. Frogs make no sense in the realm of logic, but logic has little to do with faith. All this said, I'm not really extremely pretentious or "arty" or any of that crap. After all, I loved "Happy Gilmore," too. And I guess in the big picture, I usually like a lot of stuff that does what it does wholeheartedly, without pandering or second-guessing what others might like, and stays true to it's focus, whether it's making the longest most message-filled darkly funny movie you can, or the cheesiest dumbest movie you can. Or, in other words, yeah, I liked Magnolia lots and lots.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Byzantine collection of California lives</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, "Magnolia" is absorbing, shocking, grandiose, overwrought...words that only fitfully describe a generally undefinable movie about different characters in California. It is filmed with such sweeping passion, such oddly nuanced grace, that I was willing to overlook some of the nastiness in the handling and the long sections of talk that really don't tell us anything. The acting by the all-star cast is terrific (particularly John C. Reilly as a dedicated cop who wants to be loved), Aimee Mann's songs are haunting, the production is flawless, however it's a difficult picture to sit through. I had to take a time-out in between videotapes just to catch my breath. *** from ****</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The Best movie of 1999</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In a year of beautiful, elegant, powerful films Magnolia stands as the most beautiful, elegant and powerful. Having experienced this film twelve times in th eTheatre and immediately purchasing the dvd upon it's release I feel confident enough to state that movies do not get much better than this. It has exactly what movies should have; believable characters, real situations honest emotion. Every character is somebody we all know or know of. The movie unfolds slowly not allowing ourselves to gloss over the complexities of the characters. P.T. Anderson has made a film that is unabashedly personal, not just to him but to his audience. Many people in my life live with the regret of things gone wrong. "The book says we may be through with the past but the past ain't through with us." These words should be heeded. Words as true as those are rarely heard on screen. For those who dislike the length go and Dude, where's my car which clocks in at below 90 minutes and will not challenge you in any way. Pearl Harbour has just been released and it clocks in at just around the time Magnolia did and yet offers none of the beauty and magistry of P. T. Anderson's directing. Magnolia will forver stand as a movie that people were just not willing to enjoy beacuse, perhaps, it hit a little too close to home.</fullReview>

		<username>cafelife</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Spectacular, although I see the "language" issue has bothered some people.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before I say anything, I'd like to thank 39 steps (see below) as I'm going to take a similar approach. Rather than de-construct the film (and I gave it a 10) I'd like to ask the audience some questions. First, however, I'd like to address the "language" issue. You can either accept that some people actually DO use the "F" word and slang terms for genitalia and go on and enjoy the film, or avoid it. If that aspect of reality disturbs you, you have the right to avoid the movie (movies these days DO have ratings, so don't complain about such things as though you've been victimized).Anyway, some questions: Ever heard of quantum theory; the interconnectedness of all things? You might want to read "The Holographic Universe" then go back and watch the movie again. Perhaps the simultaneous singing part won't trouble some of you so much. As others have cited, the "Sins of the Father" message was pretty strong throughout the movie. I see that's caused some religious discussions. Fair enough. So now then: Ever seen something happen that you cannot explain? Ever seen two people pick up a large person or object using only two fingers? I have and I know others who have, and to this day I cannot explain it. Strange things DO happen all the time. Ever heard about discoveries of scientific significance that happen simultaneously at several places around the globe without any contact between the research groups? Ever seen someone heal another person? Ever seen or heard of spontaneous disappearance of a tumor? I have. How does that happen? I don't know and neither does my aunt, but it happened; overnight. Western medicine and science is at a loss to explain most things. The physical models we build in an attempt to understand life and the universe are just that, man-made models. How many times in the past has science and medicine been proved wrong? If any of us think we have all the answers, then we are without hope. Perhaps there is a reason for everything that happens and we simply cannot understand the reasons for some (or all?) of them.As Dennis Miller says: "That's just my opinion. I could be wrong".Peace.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>paul-298</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Stands out from the crowd</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A large number of excellent films were realised in early 2000, yet this film stood out from the crowd from day 1. It takes great bravery to write a film which incorporates raining frogs into a story of people living their lives, and absolute mastery of filmmaking to present it on screen without simply producing laughter. Paul Thomas Anderson pulls it off with genius.The directors previous film ("Boogie Nights") was a comedy that wasn't very funny, with sections of emotional pain for the characters that was heartbreakingly portrayed and perfectly presented. Magnolia ignores the humour (in the main, though there are lighter touches), and concentrates instead on heaping misery on the heads of its lead characters. Once again the acting performances are uniformly superb, and the audience suffers with them.Each of the performers lives up to the standards they have set themselves, and Cruise goes above and beyond anything I expected of him. The stand out performance, however, comes from Melora Walters, as Claudia, who has been criminally ignored in the acclaim for Cruise.All the Anderson flourishes are in place (long tracking shots, montages of different characters who are apart and yet together), and the add a great deal to the film. Stand out moments? Frogs, it's not going to stop till you wise up, quietly judging, confusing being sick and in love.Truly a great film.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-04-10</date>
		<username>Karl Self</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>

And, as Claudia's smile tells us as we listen to the closing song, we can all be saved "from the ranks of the freaks who suspect they could never love anyone." In short, Magnolia is a movie about everything that matters, and it is, in my humble opinion, not just one of those things. No, it is not just any movie. 		<date>2001-03-15</date>
		<username>great_sphinx_42</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Illumination For the Soul</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>So frequently, movie-goers, myself included, will describe a movie as being 'a waste of time'. Sometimes it's a fun waste of time, sometimes a horrible one, sometimes a pointless one, etc. And then there are movies like 'Magnolia', the exceptions- indeed, the very antitheses. Here is 3+ hours sitting in front of a television that is anything but a waste- 3+ hours of life that serve to enhance the hours afterward. 'Magnolia' is a meditation on life- one of the few movies to seriously shoot for that goal and one of the fewer still to achieve it. Each and every one of the actors give terrific performances, the ties between them bobbing and weaving until it all falls into place, merely great cinema humming along between moments that spark and flare and illuminate in ways seldom seen. May Paul Thomas Anderson always be as inspired and observant as he is now. 'Magnolia' is a marvel.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>One of the best movies ever, perhaps the best - and for the ones who didn't get the frogs...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm visiting IMDB.com very regularly since quite a time, but I never felt like commenting a movie myself, until I've seen Magnolia, it's unlike any movie I've ever seen.I thought it to bee quite like American Beauty (called after a flower, too!), and before I've seen Magnolia I really liked American Beauty. But compared to Magnolia, American Beauty is too soft, too harmless, too shy and too commercial. Magnolia is like a punch into your face (by the way: it has it's name because of the colors beige, red and brown, these are the sad colors of the flower called magnolia and the most used colors of the movie), it shows the real sickness of our western society, how un-self conscious we use to be at the beginning of the third millenium and how unsure our future is.The writing, acting, directing and the music is almost perfect, there is no scene I really don't like. A lot of people complain that it's three hours long. I only realized this the first time I saw it because I had two hours planned in to see this movie and actually would have had other stuff to do, but I just couldn't stop watching this movie.And for the ones who didn't get the frogs: (*** minor spoiler warning ***)What do you think it feels like when you realize that your life is nothing more than crap, when you realize that you have problems which are so old that they seem to be petrified, when you realize that you have been running against a wall for so long and didn't even see it and that you have wasted such a lot of time? This feeling is scary, sad, depressing, incomprehensibly and somehow surreal. That's what the characters are experiencing at the end of the movie. And now, what do you think is it like to see thousands of frogs falling from the sky, spilling their blood right at you? - It's quite the same. So you see, the frog-rain is a perfect visualization of the inner breakdown of the characters and their lives. It's the central scene of Magnolia and it's my favorite movie-scene ever."So Now Then": Did it ever rain frogs for you?</fullReview>

		<username>KDB227</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>brilliant</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It isn't often that movies like this come along. Magnolia is one of the best films of 1999 because of its original characters, ideas, and twists. The only other movie of 1999 that comes close to Magnolia is Three Kings. Magnolia is something special because it takes you into the character's minds and emotions like no other film of recent years. Many people feel the ending was too far-fetched, but if you pay close attention during the movie, P.T. Anderson, the writer/director is setting it up brilliantly. The whole movie you were anticipating something spectacular to happen and I feel that the ending was completely satisfying. It was so nice to see a writer/director make a movie about something. Magnolia has a human substance to it that no other film in 1999 had. Everyone can relate to all the character's different emotions. As far as the ending goes, it was simply amazing...and that is what Magnolia is, amazing. Pay close attention during the movie for the numbers 8 and 2, and then, ONLY AFTER the movie, go read the Bible and look at the Book of Exodus, Chapter 8, Verse 2...that might help explain the ending if you don't understand it the first time.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-02-14</date>
		<username>scottybhoy_2000 (scottybhoy_2000@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Stunning</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Director Paul Thomas Anderson's third feature is by far his best, and is by far the best film of 1999. The basic plot outline doesn't do the film justice, a group of people from different walks of life endure an amazing day in the San Fernando Valley and through the course of the day their lives interconnect and have some sort of influence on one another. Hardly enthralling viewing, you might think, especially given the film's indulgent running time of just over three hours. The real strength of the film is in the great ensemble cast, many of whom starred in Anderson's critically acclaimed "Boogie Nights" (1997), amongst them William H Macy (surely one of the greatest actors of the moment), Julianne Moore, John C Reilly, Ricky Jay (who also narrates the film) and newcomers to Anderson's world, the late Jason Robards Jr and a great performance from Tom Cruise, in surely his most outstanding performance to date. It's such a shame he had to resort to the dirge that was M:I-2 afterwards. Still, money talks. Anderson has already shown that he will be one of the greatest directors since Stanley Kubrick, with such dazzling visual flair and technique and the ability to choose the right actor for each part.Faultless (never have three hours flown by so quickly), Magnolia will surely go down as one of the greatest American films of all time; of course, the academy largely ignored it (I still think i is a better film than "American Beauty") nd if you haven't seen it, please make sure you do. On no accounts let is slip by you, or you'll miss the movie experience of a lifetime.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-02-06</date>
		<username>august (asanchez)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Didn't anyone get the frogs?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>spoiler alert! After seeing this movie on video, I was amazed at the symbolism &amp; all the things I missed when I first saw it in the theater! I was so overwhelmed with the performances &amp; engrossed in the emotion &amp; there was so much going on that it was easy to let things go by.The frog scene was incredible! The first time I saw it it was so absurd yet eerily plausible, especially in light of the beginning prologue of seemingly "coincindental" occurences, that I just started laughing. P.T. Andersen's dark sense of humor definitely shines through &amp; is obvious throughout. This was a wake-up call to the characters that was pregnant with symbolic meaning. A friend of mine who saw the movie referred to frogs as ancient eastern symbolism for spiritual rebirth, which was definitely happening to each character after sinking to the depths of despair &amp; realizing the need to be unstuck and move in a new direction. Each character was so caught up in their "reality" that they couldn't see beyond their petty existence &amp; needed a "sign" from the universe, or god or whatever. There are no coincidences in this world. Everything happens for a reason.Also, the biblical reference to the plagues of Egypt was not lost on this reviewer. There was even a direct reference to the frogs in one of the game show scenes where an audience member is holding a sign with the biblical reference to the plague, which is quickly taken from him by a staff member!Which brings up another theme. . . the game show, which symbolised the games the characters were playing in their lives to live up to others expectations. The flashy, psuedo-happiness expressed in the game show belied the seriousness happening below the surface.Sure, there were excesses in this movie but P.T. is an excessive guy and L.A. is an excessive, surfacey, neurotic place full of vice as well as virtue. You just have to dig deeper to find the virtue than other cities.Although I adore Aimee Mann &amp; her music I thought having the characters all singing "Save Me" at the same time was both corny yet so brilliant a move that I could forgive P.T. for doing it. You can definitely say it has never been done before!Ever notice the use of Paul Thomas Andersen's initials of his first&amp; middle name &amp; how it is a reference to a well known circus owner? Just remember "the greatest show on earth . . . must go on" &amp; you will have greater insight into P.T. Andersen.</fullReview>
	</review>

The awful things we do to ourselves. The inevitable alienation many experience living in a society that *just might* have become ridiculously and needlessly complex and sterile. Drug abuse not as a disease but a symptom of an overburdened people trying to cope in the environment we've created. This movie points out the chains that you should have seen before.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-01-18</date>
		<username>Richie-33</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Frogs?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Magnolia' is too long, in fact it lasts about 3 hours. Everyone (except maybe Kevin Costner) knows movies tend to get tedious after 120 minutes. There are far too many characters, too many sprawling storylines tenuously held together by two men dying of cancer, creating a lack of focus and leaving many loose ends. At one point the whole cast, for no apparent reason, start singing along to the soundtrack. The self same soundtrack features Gabrielle's 'Dreams' for chrissakes! So how come Magnolia works?Paul Thomas Anderson's latest ensemble melodrama doesn't cover the same timespan of 'Boogie Nights' but is more eventful and emotional; and despite all the things listed above, it is essential viewing. The film follows several characters through one day in San Fernando, documenting their lives, loves and losses. The element linking all the storylines together are two men, both dying of cancer and seeking forgiveness for mistakes they committed during their lives. However, Anderson includes many threads that are only weakly linked to this idea, all brought together under the umbrella of bizarre coincidence.Isn't it great when Tom Cruise acts? I don't mean onscreen flashing his perfect smile and tossing his flaxen hair. I mean really acts. Like in 'Rain Man' or 'Born on the 4th of July'. Or 'Magnolia'. His performance here reminds you why he is a cut above the average Hollywood crowd-puller, though I wouldn't say it was outstanding. This is not because he isn't brilliant, rather that the rest of the cast match him every step of the way; despite not being household names, writer/director Anderson knows he is privileged to be able to cast some of the best actors currently plying their trade and they will nail their given character perfectly.Despite Gabrielle's dirge rearing it's ugly head, the soundtrack is otherwise excellent, and Aimee Mann's songs seem to match the events perfectly. In fact, in the album inlay Anderson admits to having written Magnolia to fit Mann's songs, not the other way around. Unusual, but like so much else about the film, it works. So not perfect, but thoroughly recommended, even if just for the scenes with the frogs.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-01-10</date>
		<username>homerjsimpsonn</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>What the hell was that?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was arguably the worst movie I have ever seen. Yes, I understood the story (as vague and simple as it was). It was just too strange to be enjoyable. The plot in itself was weak, many of the characters were absolutely pointless; they had nothing to do with the plot. The scenes, even by the end of the movie, had very little to do with eachother. What is the significance of raining frogs? What did it have to do with the gameshow host's daughter's drug addiction? Or the quiz-kid's attempt to steal money? Two emphatic thumbs down.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-01-01</date>
		<username>(atmvawser@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brilliant on so many levels, it's a must-see</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is an outright masterpiece. Anderson possesses a mastery of the movie camera, as well as an insight into human lives and emotions, like no film-maker today that I can think of (I was disappointed that he missed out on an Oscar, but he's too talented not to be honoured eventually). It's difficult to watch at times, with several painfully intense scenes, and at 3 hours possibly difficult for some people to see through to the end. 'Magnolia' is, however, so ambitious, accomplished and rewarding in so many ways that it should be seen by anyone who appreciates and believes in the power of film. Compare 'Magnolia' to at least 80% of American films being made today, and they just won't measure up. It will probably require a second viewing in order for you to fully appreciate the beauty of the script, themes and characterisation, as well as the brilliance of the direction, photography and editing. A lot of viewers may think 'Magnolia' is too harsh, or long, or grim, or pretentious, or even offensive, but it's a truly beautiful and compassionate film which must be seen to be appreciated.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The best movie of all time, no doubt about it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this movie with my best friend, and i must say i was blown away. I have never felt so moved by a movie then i have when i saw Magnolia. The story was incredible, the acting, and of course the writing and directing, topped all of it off. After i saw this stunning drama i felt a whole world open up to me. I found myself in every character in the film. I must say it scared me, but i think that's what made me feel so moved by Magnolia. There are a few aspects of the film i have yet to realize and understand, my point is see this movie! If you haven't you don't know what you're missing! This is one movie that you cannot just watch and move on to the next, it will stay with you.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2000-12-21</date>
		<username>John Mankin (mankin@rff.org)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Excruciating endurance contest</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If Paul Thomas Anderson is still around making movies in 10-15 years, I have a feeling that he will look back on the excesses of "Magnolia" and say to himself, "what was I thinking?" He may be technically precocious, but he doesn't yet know how to write interesting dialogue, develop believable characters or discipline his actors. I haven't seen so much hysterical over-emoting since the dear dead days (hopefully) of John Cassavetes. This film is three numbingly monotonous hours of mawkishly profane psychodramatics, written by someone who can't put two sentences together without using the "F" word. Everyone in this movie talks the same way, even the children! Everything in "Magnolia" is too much: there can't be one character dying of cancer, there have to be two and they both have long "I cheated on you" speeches. Tom Cruise might have won the Oscar for the scene at his father's deathbed if Anderson had given him anything to say beyond "I hate you, you (expletive deleted)." As it is, Cruise is forced to flail about desperately in the worst awards-pandering manner. The same is true for just about everyone else. Julianne Moore plays another of her frazzled druggie roles so amateurishly that it wasn't till I saw "The End of the Affair" and "An Ideal Husband" that I discovered that she really could act! Skip it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-12-21</date>
		<username>matt caccamo (caccamo.1@nd.edu)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>4 Stars</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Lives intertwine and stories converge in this masterpiece by Paul Thomas Anderson. Deals with several serious human issues without cheating any, and never allows the viewer to stop pondering. Excellent ensemble cast with standout performance by Cruise. This is 28-year old Anderson's second film after "Boogie Nights." Cruise nominated for Best Supporting Actor Oscar, but, overall, film given the shaft by all award-givers.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-12-16</date>
		<username>HanoverF-4</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Not to be confused with the second coming of Christ</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've heard many things about this movie before seeing it, mostly good, and having enjoyed Boogie Nights, I was anxious to see this movie. In the interest of fairness, though, I knew that this movie was so highly rated by critics and IMDB'ers alike, so I watched this movie with a hypercritical eye. It may result in some nitpicking that you might find silly. Deal with it.It is interesting, then, that so many people gave a movie such a good rating. When a movie as plot driven as this one is (the characters are all written so one-dimensionally, the actors are pretty much interchangable with one another), the script becomes as important an aspect as any other. Yet, the story arc is uncommonly forced, moving from one segment to another with an awkardness generally reserved for Jean-Claude Vann Damme films. Characters seem to be so focused on a bizarre goal, to close their own story arcs, they act completely out of sync with whom they are supposed to be (I think that even the cop in The Village People can tell when his date goes to the bathroom for ten minutes and comes back pinching their nose, asking for a second date is not the proper course of action). With so few characters and such a long movie, you would think that the director could keep track of his people better, but they appear and disappear with alarming regularity, in order to set up for an ungratifying ending. Of course, with a film that is this well liked, plot holes automatically become stand ins for angst ridden college age analogies. No doubt the precubescent rapper in the beginning of the movie had a vague enough role that he can stand in for any one of a number of irrational theories as to the directors motivations, from third world labor strife to schoolyard violence. Free Tibet, anyone?As for the actors, Tom Cruise wastes the choice role handed to him as the informercial whore. Jobs like this scream for the shameless over the top treatment, but Cruise chooses a low key point of attack instead, seeming to deliver his lines with a sleepy intensity that makes him seem more an actor than a crazed cult leader. If L. Ron had this little charisma when giving one of his own seminars, we may have been spared the car wreck that was Battlefield Earth. Waifish actress Melora Walters seems to have been chosen by the bounce of her breasts in an opening sex scene rather than any real acting ability (she's quite talented in that regards) It's the actors that are coming in for another go-round, the veterans from Boogie Nights, that fare a little better. Juliane Moore doesn't need to know what her characters motivation is (because the viewer certainly doesn't) as she flips off her lawyer. And, you might not remember John C. Rielly's performace in Boogie Nights (hint: it wasn't that good), but he slips into his role of an insecure policeman so well, I had to be wonder if it was the same person. The luck ran out for poor William H. Macy, who just seems lost in his role as a hard luck closet homosexual. Seeing him fighting for a bartender's affections is an almost painful experience for someone so talented.The bottom line? If you have not seen this movie yet, please don't let my review stop you. For all the things that I wrote, I gave this movie an eight out of ten, a solid showing for such an ambitious project. But, folks, put the oscars (they lost their proper noun status with me after Matt Damon and Ben Affleck each got their copies) back on the shelf. There were more deserving films than this, and this director still has more room to grow yet. Lets see what comes up next.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-11-15</date>
		<username>chichi-3</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>This film is one of the most imaginative in substance and brilliant in form of the former decade...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Hard to tell anything in short about this movie. It has some of the Altman's "Short cuts" (or, for French readers something of Lelouch in the style) in its form but goes well well beyond in its way of interlocking people apparently having nothing to do with one another. Also where Altman films, with a hint of humour, facts and people in their every day life, PT Anderson tackles with not less than... the bible : his characters all facing such a heavy event in their life that God himself will allegedly interfere at the end of the story. PT Anderson does not entirely avoid the reproach of having been megalomaniac and too extreme in the choice of its characters. But if you are aware of this and willing to get over it, this movie is one of the most amazing EXPERIENCES that, as a movie amateur who sees tons of films, I have ever been through. It is not just about a story but also a complete universe (that is buried in our sub-conscience), an atmosphere that is unique and yet close to us, crawling human beens on the face of earth. The film is one of the rare occurences of a realist story that somewhere happens in the twilight zone. See it : you'll either detest or love it, in either you'll think about it and about yourself afterward.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-11-07</date>
		<username>tj_director</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Yes, but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>With the quality of DVD's and my new big screen TV and complete DTS cinema sound system, I've started buying DVD's from america without seeing the movie first, i reckon ?6 of the price would have been paid to go to the cinema anyway, and if i don't like the movie i can always trade it.With Magnolia i decided to get the 2 disc version here in UK, it got delayed by about 3 weeks, but i eventually got it, though immediately sent it back due to the poor packaging. Ordered the american version, got it 3 days later, and loved the packaging. I hyped this film up to myself, i even got the soundtrack, before even hearing a single song. SO basically added on top of the critics' praise, my respect for Boogie Nights, and my struggle for getting it on DVD, this film had a lot to live up to.What did i think then? well the 1st 10 minutes really excited me, i knew there was an unforgettable climax, it obviously had to be a culmination of all the stories, it couldn't be the rain thing, becasue i knew that was going to happen.Anyway 2hrs 30 mins in, and i like it, although i was expecting some surreal moments, but didn't get any - people site the singing along to 'Save Me' as weird, but i didn't, it fitted well into the context, and i thought it was very original. THe film has good pace, but the truth is that none of the stories are really original or amazing, we've seen it all before, but PT ANderson seems to make the stories individual and at least refreshing, and he directs with style and the screen is always a pleasure to look at when he's behind the camera.30 mins towards the end you expect this big culmination, and to me the 3rd act is what defines a movie, the 1st act should get you interested (it did) and the 2nd act should be entertaining and have purpose (it did) and the 3rd should end everything, leave nothing unanswered and show you something you didn't expect (yes, but...) and with the very best movies, the film will carry on even after you've left.I didn't really get bored during the 3 hrs, but i did feel rather dissapointed at the end, sure the rain is unexpected to those who don't know about it, and it sure as heck is exciting to watch - but it doesn't really serve a huge purpose apart from being unexpected, it does affect some of the people, but not to any great extent. Some of the stories just conclude, and that's it, there's no big climax, no big hurrah for the characters, and it becomes a film that just ends, even leaving little things unanswered.I hate it in movies when the credits come up when you don't expect them to, You should know when a film is about to end. American Beauty won best film oscar, it had an amazing 3rd act, and it moved a lot of people, i can't help feeling had Magnolia had a stronger 3rd act, it could have been a favorite of mine, as i hyped it up to be.I'm one of those people who kinda got it, but not really, the movie is still playing in my head 2 days after watching it, and i feel i have to watch it again, to put my mind to rest, maybe i'll love it, second time round, as is the case with many movies.I kind of feel the 1st 10 minutes are there to make the rest of film move quicker, because your mind is expecting something, so you take everything in and think about it. If the 1st 10 minutes weren't there, the film could have been quite unexciting, but at least you wouldn't feel as dissapointed at the end of it all.in conclusion, if you happen to come upon this review amongst the many others (richard E.Zwick's excellent comments on the front page sum it up for me) and want to know whether to watch this film -- it's not a complete waste of time, if like me you generally like movies as a whole, from the corniest family movie to the die-hard drama type movie, then you'll find the 3hrs fly by, and it leaves something inside of you, part annoyance and part happiness.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2000-10-26</date>
		<username>dvideostor (dvideostor@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A brilliant tale from a brilliant filmmaker</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Being the fan of contemporary film as I am, Magnolia along with Hard Eight and Boogie Nights clenched the fact that director Paul Thomas Anderson is my favorite director. He is a hard-hitting film magician. If you think long and hard enough about the techniques he uses you can figure out how he did it. The mystery is how he thought of it. Of course he's been influenced by Scorsese, Altman, even Tarantino, but adds the gloss and refuses to weed out any scenes that most producers would deem unworthy. And that's what makes great filmmakers great. It would be criminal not to mention the incredibly strong performances by a gifted group of actors. I have always been open about my fondness of Julianne Moore, and here she lays it all out on the table until she's out of breath. Jason Robards is heart breaking as a cruel old man coming to his end. Philip Seymour Hoffman is the nurse just trying to help. Tom Cruise is vicious as creator of `Seduce and Destroy.' William H. Macy is touching as an original ex-boy genius who now can't even remember to remove his key from the lock. The current boy genius, played by newcomer Jeremy Blackman, is a child very few people like, even if he's one of the sweetest kids you've ever come across. Philip Baker Hall is the game show host who has worked well with children for thirty years, except his own. Melora Walters is surprisingly brilliant as the drug addict who always has tears in her eyes, as she uses sheets on her windows to hide from the world. John C. Reilly is the clumsy cop trying to do right and falls in love. Magnolia is not for everyone. It's strong, quick, and unlike any other movie you'll ever see. While making the dramatic comedic, and the comedic dramatic, he rarely lets us forget that this is a movie about the strange things that happen to the characters. Their stories and parallel lives weave in and out of each other's in a stretch of 24-hours (3 hours, movie time) ending with a most unpredictable event. Wild horses could not get me to reveal it!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-10-23</date>
		<username>(jacob.rosen@axa-advisors.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Thomas Pynchon Of Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Where "Boogie Nights" found Paul Thomas Anderson's encyclopedic knowledge and dazzling cinematic technique covering up his disdain for the hapless denizens of his porn netherworld, "Magnolia" finds Anderson openly embracing his cross-section of Los Angeles citizens and teaching them about the goodness of the world he sees before him. Anderson's speed-demon style is well at work here--it's as if there isn't enough celluloid to fit it all in--and the depths of his topics are layered and full; he's the Thomas Pynchon of film and one viewing surely isn't enough. Like Pynchon, he can't quite grasp saying "when" and the film is a very long three hours. Still, the viewer has plenty of rewards, from the looniness of Anderson's script (the end has to be seen to be believed and one has to have embraced the film long before then) to the magnificent performances that make one feel as if life is truly being lived in front of the camera. Everyone shines here but special notice must be given to Tom Cruise who finally realizes his potential and turn in a bravura, funny piece of acting as a public speaker making a career out of humiliating women and embracing all things misogynistic. Cruise rises above his (previously) competent abilities to deliver an unwavering, if ultimately touching, performance that is both well-suited to his talents and challenging at the same time. Other great moments are provided by Julianne Moore (treated with far more respect than Robert Altman ever showed her), William H. Macy (getting back at Anderson for his underwritten "Boogie Nights" role), Jason Robards, Jr. and Philip Baker Hall. Anderson's themes of sin and redemption, chance and destiny and the power of love are, at this dawn of a new millennium, welcome and timeless.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-10-22</date>
		<username>ltj36 (ltj36@hotmail.com)</username>

		<shortDescription>A portrait of human lives</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Three hours of length, a lot of stories to follow... at a first look "Magnolia" seems to be a very "strong" movie, probably too much long and boring. But then when it begins with that astonishing introduction, ti takes you in a world full of despair but with a final possibility of hope. The cast does a very great work: the apparently strong Cruise, the suffering Moore and Walters, the good man Reilly but most of all Philip Seymour Hoffman with his sweet Phil and Philip Baker Hall with his Jimmy Gator, a man destroyed by cancer and sorrow. Anderson gives us a very effective portrait of these lives with a strong screenplay and a fantastic soundtrack,. One of the most beautiful movies of the year. To remember the song, sang by all the cast, the tragic confession of Hall and the surprising end.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2000-10-06</date>
		<username>vukodlak</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Three hours of unpleasant stuff.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia takes three hours to describe some very unpleasant things that are happening to people which are either unpleasant or pathetic or both. This does not make for a very entertaining three hours. The film starts off O.K. with a prologue that shows several cases of unusual deaths that feature near incredible coincidences. After that the film introduces about a dozen characters (probably more) and we follow their lives throughout that day. The characters are grouped into about four seemingly unrelated stories. So far so good. What I was hoping for after this is that all the characters and their stories will somehow come together at the end of the film perhaps even through some incredible coincidence - like those that were presented in the prologue. But, it seems that this is where my expectations of the film were too high. The stories do turn out to be connected although VERY loosely through a set of most UNremarkable coincidences. Basically it feels like 3 or 4 scripts for short films artificially pasted together. It is true that certain stories mirror one another showing similar fates with different outcomes, therefore contrasting one another - but on the whole all of this is quite unremarkable. The style of the film here resembles some of Robert Altman's work only without the elegance and without the humour.But the movie, just before the end, comes up with one stroke of originality. The EVENT happens. It is something quite unexpected and in sharp contrast with the realism of earlier events. The sequence showing the EVENT is powerful and visually and audibly compelling. But (and this is a big but) it is completely unrelated to everything that's been happening in the film and on the whole has very, very little effect on the fates of the characters in the movie (the EVENT kills one character but he had been dying anyway).But the film's biggest problem is that it is about people that would get on your nerves terribly if you met them in real life. Most of them are b*****ds and those that are not are so pathetic you couldn't talk to them for five minutes without screaming. There are only two sympathetic characters in the film - the cop and the nurse. The moral of the film seems to be about forgiving and understanding - but by the time we get to that we had to sit through three hours of moaning and unpleasantness.However, to end on a good note, the characters (annoying though they may be) are quite convincingly portrayed by an excellent ensemble cast. Most of them are well established character actors who give fine performances seemingly effortlessly. The standout, somewhat surprisingly, is Cruise who gives by far and away his best performance to date as a self-centred, misogynous seduction instructor. Also excellent are Julianne Moore and Phillip Seymour Hoffman - whom I hope we will see more of in the future.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Well after seeing this movie it was stuck in my head for a few days, it's extremely haunting and at this very moment I still have Aimee Mann's voice going through it. Some of the best movie's ever seen always have great characters that stick with you through time and this movie certainly does that. Everyone seems so intrigued with the frogs, as they should be, it serves a really big purpose in the movie but they shouldn't be the main purpose as everyone seems to be stating it as, it's the message that the movie's trying to send about regret, love, hate and the way we all treat each other and of course about how things just happen that's important, but I'll never forget the scene when Earl was talking to Phil about regrets and Lily, it was the most intense speech I've ever heard. Yeah this one is recommended. Oh by the way, how come everyone that has something negative to say about this movie is so hostile towards positive reviewers? Just an insight.</fullReview>

Some people try to pull out one simple lesson or meaning from the story, but the best way to watch it is to kind of take ALL of the meanings in. The plot sounds very confusing when you read it, but believe me, the movie has plenty of time to go through and explain it. Also, don't get too hooked up on one of the sub-plots, or you'll miss the rest of the movie. Trust me- I've got personal experience. If you haven't seen this movie, I definitely recommend it. 	<review>
		<date>2000-09-15</date>
		<username>evilmatt-3</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Probably the best film I've ever seen</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am not one to just hand this compliment out to random films: _Magnolia_ is the closest thing to a perfect film I have ever seen. I went to the theatre to see it and was so completely blown away that I returned the next night to see it again.There is really not a single bad thing about this movie. The cast, which includes familiar names like Julianne Moore and William H. Macy and lesser knowns like Melora Walters and Jeremy Blackman, is just spectacular. With the sheer size of the cast, a lesser director would be unable to effectively tell the story (in fact, this happened; see _Beautiful People_) yet Paul Thomas Anderson has a uncanny sense of timing that juggles the various plot elements perfectly, so that the entire film flows into one story, rather than nine.Speaking of the story, the script itself is top-notch. Besides being engaging (three hours fly by like 90 minutes), there is an important message to the film with complex social, religious, and philosophical implications. Even better, the movie isn't preachy! You actually have to discover its theme for yourself and decide what each of the characters got out of the film. While some may not appreciate this, I find it highly commendable in an era of hit-you-over-the-head, blatantly obvious, socially conscious films that bombard the audience with already apparent (and self-important) messages about an easy topic like sexism, war, etc.A common objection to this film is that it is long. Well, if you sat through _Titanic_ or _The Green Mile_, this film should not seem long at all. Unlike those films, _Magnolia_ actually uses all three hours and eight minutes of its screen time.There's not much more to be said. The only down side is that it will be nearly impossible for Mr. Anderson to follow this one up.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-09-14</date>
		<username>krumbs (fontanelle@gmx.net)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>awareness of being a film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"A matter of chance" vs. "those things happen all the time". magnolia is first of all a film about film-making. the introduction with the three murderers of greenberry hill - accidents, chance? well-filmed for an accident. suicide: the film stops, and neat little drawings are put upon him. arbitraryness in life, reflected in the film: the line is continually blurred. the stories: we all know them too well. the dying father wants to see his son for a final meeting, donnie seemingly lacked the love of his parents and now has too much of it, frank is the role-model of chauvinism, the good cop (it´s a dirty job but someone´s gotta do it) etc.etc. the first hour of the movie is a hard test for the audience. anderson keeps dragging clichés to their limit, points violently at the conventions of producing emotions out of celluloid, before he can go beyond the cliché, just before one really has to leave the cinema because of all these stereotypes making your eyes and mind bleed. This technique is also mirrored in the editing, which is just about a second faster and therefore steals the next expected picture of the scene away after the general theme of each story is established. I think realising the film´s awareness of being a movie increases understanding and fun, for otherwise it is really too much story and facts. try and look again under these premises. first act for cognition, second for sublimation.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2000-08-31</date>
		<username>TC Candler</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>THE BEST FILM I'LL EVER SEE - THANKS PTA.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>We have all noticed how lists of great films of all time (e.g. AFI's list) tend to have a predominantly older group of films. It seems as if it is a requirement to be 25 years or older to gain "classic" status. With that in mind, I think that this film will age like a fine wine... moving it's way into greatness over the next century. Fifty years from now "CyberEberts", or critics as we now call them, will be discussing whether this film changed cinema forever.Magnolia is utterly unique in it's complexity and layered structure. Altman never did it this well, as great as he is. What Paul Thomas Anderson has done in this film will be legendary when we are all gone. The acting he can pull out of his "repeat" actors is outstanding. Cruise delivers in the role he will be most remembered for... Walters is a standout as the lost little girl we all want to take care of. Reilly imprints his reputation as the best supporting actor of the decade. Moore has played this role before, but she does it so well... and William H Macy is the only one who could pull off Quiz Kid Donnie Smith.The soundtrack is haunting... Aimee Mann may never produce better work. PTA chose her well, as well as he chose everything else. This film is by far the best of the year, and along with Schindler's List, Titanic, The Shawshank Redemption and Pulp Fiction it will go down as the most influential of the decade.This film shows you things you've never seen in ways you've never seen. The boldness of the "sing along" scene, along with the breath taking ending will leave it's mark on you and on Cinema for a very long time.There are no weak links in this tale of family, forgiveness, redemption, coincidence, lonliness, connectedness and hope. PTA's kinetic camera is a joy to watch and I recommend it to anyone with an open mind and a willingness to be taken places they never knew existed.This film is like a deep image poem of the 60's and 70's, it may not make sense immediately... but it will make you feel something even if you don't know what that something is, and someday, down the road, it will all click into place for you.This is a masterwork that all should see. At three hours (such as Titanic, Braveheart, English Patient and The Thin Red Line) some have said it is too long. I just wish it had been longer.This film requires a lot of thought and an old soul. Those who love "film" will love this future classic.99/100 A+ ***** out of *****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>BigE-3 (ezhao@netscape.net)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Something to Be Proud Of</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>May be 30, 40, or 50 years later when the next generation (or the one after that) looks back to our time -- I believe this is a film that we could proudly put forward as one of the greatest achievements in cinematic history in our time.Several quick points. First: Aimee Mann. Her songs and her voice are incredible. The sing-along, which could have been so disastrous, turned out to be such an amazing and powerful beauty on the strength of that haunting "Wise Up." Second: the ending. It's absolutely wonderful. Yes it's a freak accident -- but it perfectly illustrates the stories of people's lives: interrupted, savaged, and ripped apart by "divine interventions," they nevertheless march onward, with a resoluteness that is only matched by their despair. Third: Tom Cruise. What a powerful performance, especially during the interview and on the bedside of his father when he breaks down. Kevin Spacey -- you are not even close. Fourth: the structure of the movie. Many other had commented on this already: it's a slowly blossoming Magnolia, each of its petals slowly reveals itself to us, with incredible pain and heroism.If you still haven't seen it, go see it. And buy the soundtrack CD too.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-08-16</date>
		<username>diakonia_alpha</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Breathtaking Film Experience for those of us who aren't perfect</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>MAGNOLIA is a heavenly slice of filmmaking. Paul Thomas Anderson of BOOGIE NIGHTS fame makes an even more compelling and revelatory feature than his previous two outings. He adeptly handles a day in the life of a dozen or so seemingly disconnected people. Not only does he spin the stories wonderfully together, but he draws some of the best performances out of a major studio production in a long time. Tom Cruise gives a jolting, crude, and ultimately heartbreaking performance as a chauvinistic sex guru. It is surely his best performance, and one that was deserving of the best supporting actor Oscar. John C. Reilly continues to shine in Anderson's films as the God-fearing, love-hungry cop who provides the movie with its emotional balance. Last but not least, relative unknown Melora Walters delivers a raw and emotionally powerful performance as a heroin addict trying to cope with the guilt and shame of her family's secrets. She is what gives the movie its emotional impact.This is truly not a movie for children or casual moviegoers. However, for all those interested in serious filmmaking and top-notch acting, MAGNOLIA is a masterpiece to behold. With wonderful sing-along music provided by Aimee Mann and the most bizarre and exhilarating concluding plot device ever seen on screen, MAGNOLIA finally unravels itself to expose humanity in its most naked and exposed state, as well as to discover redemption "for the freaks who have never loved anyone."</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not Sure Just Why I Loved It</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I rented this movie not knowing that much about or hearing many reviews about it. I'd never talked to anyone who'd seen it, and all I new was that it was about people with connected lives, and that it was supposed to be great. I put it in and began watching, and soon after the mood tone and style of dialague began, I simply dismissed it as an artsy fartsy piece of crap. I watched it to the end though, and afterwards simply felt it a waste of time. I waited a day, and began thinking that it couldn't have been as bad as I thought. I figured it must have something more to it than what I got(which was nothing). So I decide to watch it agian even though I felt I might be wasting my three and a half hours all over again, I began watching, and I decided to pay close atention to evereything and everyone and every word they said.As I watched, I realized just what I had done wrong the first time I watched. To understand this movie, you must first pay strict atention to figure out what is going on, and try and understand why characters are saying and reacting just the way they are. Every line a character speaks, you must understand what they're going through, or what has happened to them in the past that would make them the way they are. Many reasons people might quite understand this movie are things like William H Macy's character the former whiz kid who wants braces like a bartender he sees, and goes on and on about love(what love is, what it feels like, and how he has it to give). People may see him saying in the movie that he has love to give and say to themselves " What the heck does that mean." Now I won't say just what it means, cause someone who hated this film may read this, but if you don't understand, watch this movie again. Try and understand what things mean, what emotions the actors are tyring to convey. Just what each character has had happen to them, and if you begin to do that, you will love this film. Actually thats what I had the most fun doing during this movie was puting it together in my mind piece by piece. After doing this, I began to notice other things about the film. Just how wonderful each actors performance is in this film. While Tom Cruise was nominated for best supporting actor, I really felt many of the other actors equaled his performence. Not to say that his was bad, its just that everyones job was so wonderfully performed that simply the emotions of everyone were so real almost to the point of bringing tears to my eyes. I also noticed how wonderful the soundtrack was. Aimee Mann did a fabulous job at creating a haunting and beautiful mood to the movie that was emphasized at the key parts and incorporated into the film.*Spoiler*(I think)For those of you who have seen the movie, a quick word about the frogs. After watching it the first time and already looking down on the movie, the frogs added to the confusion. But after the second time, I understood that the frogs were no there for any particular purpose because they were frogs, but to show how such a random and mysterious happening can bring some together, and make others get a hold of their situations, and understand just what there problems are.</fullReview>
