		<date>2002-09-28</date>
		<username>Keith F. Hatcher</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Despite all the Hollywood hype......</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After having been taken in by `American Beauty', there was a certain dosis of scepticism about embarking on this film. Another one of those with lots of roudy razzamatazz and all the big names you could wish for, like Tom Cruise, Julianne Moore, Jason Robard (in the film and in real life dying), Willy Macy, and a long list of etceteras, which are usually enough ingredients in themselves for huge box-office takings, as well as a lot of very high voting on IMDb. Added to that, if we take Murphy's Law into consideration - namely that the longer the Special FX credits list and the longer the Stunts credits list - the worse the film is, as these tend to override any story which may be there to be told; and this film has a lengthy list of participants in both categories. So you will understand why my scepticism was preparing itself psychologically for a brash blunt-bladed knife attack of tabloid-sized blaring headlines purporting to be a film.Not so with `Magnolia': a complicated, or perhaps just intricate, story of various people's mishaps in life, at first seemingly unrelated, like disconnected pieces, but which little by little become joined up as the film progresses. Interpretations were mostly fairly good, though the ever-present American tendency to play over the top left no options for subtlety, no possibility for profound perspectives.However, Paul Thomas Anderson's intelligent way of jumping from one story to another, flashbacks included, was indeed successful, even innovative at times; the logical sequencing was not so erratic as may at first seem.What `Magnolia' really needed was a genuine genius for this kind of thing; it's just that, well, you know, ahem, darest I say? - Almodóvar would have improved this film immensely.One final thing: the music was very interesting.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-08-27</date>
		<username>cravenmonket</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Brave, original fable about the nature of forgiveness</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>PT Anderson's Magnolia is a meandering film about love, forgiveness, selfishness, paranoia and introspection. It is very much a movie-lover's movie, so many people will be upset or bored by it, but it does repay repeated viewings and an open mind.The nine stories, all set along LA's Magnolia boulevard, range from a shy, earnest policeman, a coke addict, a game show presenter, a dying man, a nurse, and most memorably Tom Cruise's astonishing TV Sex-Guru Evangelist. Over the course of the film they intertwine - sometimes obviously, sometimes surprisingly - and we are left at the end with one remarkable image of a collection of lives co-dependent. It's rather like driving slowly down a long road, watching the events unfold as you go. Fabulous film-making.The film's climax - the now-famous frog scene - is horrific and bewildering, as it follows the films most brave and cathartic moment. Just before the first frog falls spectacularly from the sky, every charater is shown singing along to aimee mann's terrific pivotal song. The effect is spine-tingling. Wonderful.Many will hate Magnolia for it's indulgent length and drama, plus the apparent lack of redeeming characters. I believe it is one of the most important pieces of film-making in recent years - relying not upon trickery and flash or violence, but an ensemble of terrific actors playing the best roles of their lives. Watch it for Julianne Moore. Watch it for Philip Seymour Hoffman. Watch it for Tom Cruise.Watch it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Chris Marshall (marshallcww)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Strangely Compelling</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I watched this over two evenings, pausing just before the game show collapse. I knew the reviews tended to fall in the 'hate it' or 'love it' camps and so was eager to see for myself. Just so I don't get labelled I love all kinds of movies - from action to period drama and almost everything in between - with the simple judgement criteria being 'Am I entertained?'.Magnolia, for me, is magnificent. Although multi-threaded I felt there was (just) enough link to make the story hold, the acting was faultless and regardless of your opinion on the reason behind the frogs (actually I'm fairly certain they were toads anyway) this was a superb moment that has left me thinking about the whole film constantly.I have a couple of minor gripes - mainly the musical score. Not so much the choice of music which is OK if a little disjointed, but more the level of it in the mix. At times I had trouble following some of the dialogue as it was so loud, while at others it seemed as though someone forgot to stop the scene setting incidental soundtrack and just left it running non-stop. Other than that, the story thread of the dead man in the closet appears to wither on the vine - or did I miss something?You don't need to be an 'Arty' to enjoy this, but it will probably reward a second viewing. Sit in a comfy chair, indulge yourself in the film and remember to turn the volume up when you see the Quiz Kid on the drainpipe!</fullReview>

		<date>2002-08-04</date>
		<username>Charles Gibson</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A radiant drama which leaves you mentally shattered</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I stumbled upon this film when it first came out on video and watched it yet didn't think much of it. I rented it about a week ago because I couldn't remember all about it just that, it was high-quality. I think I watched it maybe 5 times in the past week just analyzing every waking moment of all of the lives along with their rage, dissatisfaction, abhorrence of themselves and masking contempt towards others. It could be seen as depressing for some but, it comes across to me as a gorgeous piece of reflection on why people act how they act. 9 main characters, a daring feat for a film, all interlace in tale of one day in a close area of Los Angeles.We have the cop, gasping for love anywhere he can find it and needing to be successful at his job for his own sake. The drug crazed daughter who hides in her apartment wanting nothing to do with her family or even the world. The game show host, the father who tries to connect with his daughter but, he sees she is clearly on drugs and wants nothing to do with him, he also is accepting the consequences of his decisions in life and is on the verge of death. The dying man, he used to be a television producer but, now is on his death bed with cancer and is drifting in and out of existence. The wife, now thinking of her many choices she has made while being married to the dying man and doesn't want his money because she feels horrible about everything she did to him. The male nurse, struggling with his feelings for the dying man and doing all he can to find his long lost son to help him in granting his last wish in life, to see him. The womanizing self-help guru, he makes up a family history to bury his tragic real life family of a mother who died when he was a young teen and a father who abandoned him. The quiz kid who used to be smart but, now sees himself as stupid, having money issues and loving anyone that he thinks he can latch on to, he confuses sickness and love and he doesn't care. Lastly the current quiz kid who is about to beat the record for being on a game show for the longest but, judges himself through his fathers eyes and seeing how people depend on him and think of him.Somehow the director Paul Thomas Anderson made this movie only 3 hours long. Many people have complained that it is too long, they don't realize that their are nine main character and it's hard to explain the whole story in less than that time. P.T. Anderson is constructing modern classics and Magnolia may be his best he will ever make. As your watching the movie, all track of time is lost and, unless your the kind of person that looks at his watch every five minutes during a movie, you won't care. Another criticism of the film is the ending which can be interpreted in many different ways by many different people. I see it as the hand of god purifying all of their lives helping them to attempt changing their lifestyles and current situations. It could be seen as a phenomenon which makes this story a strange situation which is set up by the prologue that this movie was going to be a strange story. In the end it taught me how people can love and live in this crazy and bizarre world.9/10 "It is in the humble opinion of this narrator that strange things happen all the time and so it goes and so it goes. And the book says "We may be through with the past but, the past ain't through with us""</fullReview>

		<date>2002-07-31</date>
		<username>Charles Gibson</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>P.T. Anderson is a genius in film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is the follow up film to Boogie Nights, the Anderson film that was growing in popularity as he decided he better try and do another film right away. He wrote some of it and finally wrote the bulk of it while as William H. Macys cabin house. The reason he did was for a few days he just wrote and wrote because he was scared if he went outside a snake that had previously been seen would bite him. Magnolia is a stroke of genius that provides the question, "How do people think of stories like this?". Magnolia is a large story with about 9 main people involved in it and all connecting at the end. The quirky sometimes off beat John C. Reilly playing Officer Jim Kurring, a cop that wants to perform his duties as a law officer and find love at the same time. The drug infested emotional roller coaster Claudia Wilson Gator played by Melora Walters who wants nothing to do with her parents and does cocaine constantly. The strong yet vulnerable personality of Tom Cruise playing Frank T.J. Mackey, a motivational speaker who preaches his catch phrase about his method in getting women "Seduce and Destroy". The elderly man Earl Partridge played by the late Jason Robards, a stunning portrayal of a dying man with cancer who is struggling in and out of life. His depressed wife Linda Partridge played by the wonderful Julianne Moore who acts with such feeling and pain that its hard to believe she's actually acting as a woman who harbors the pain of death. The male nurse of Earl played by Phillip Seymour Hoffman who is named Earl Partridge, he sticks with Earl all the way never wanting to leave or not help him find his long lost son. The sick and struggling Jimmy Gator played by Phillip Baker Hall who once was a game show juggernaut and now has lost his steam and just wants to leave show business altogether. Stanley Spector played by Jeremy Blackman, a young genius who is pulling his teams weight on a game show and has a break down and decides two days away from beating a record for being on the game show to give up on trying. And the last main character is Quiz Kid Donnie Smith played by William H. Macy who wants to give love, but he doesn't know where to put it and is also struggling financially.All of these characters intertwine into one story of love, despair, sadness and emotionally draining situations. P.T. Anderson really cares for his characters and it shines through this brilliant piece of film making which shows that not all holly wood marketed films are bad. Most of the actors in this movie were also in Boogie Nights and both films are basically equally great. Everyone can look forward to the masterpieces that Anderson will probably release and this film is not an exception. If your in the mood for great film making and acting, see Magnlia it disappoints no one."When the sunshine dont work, the good lord bring the rain in."</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-09</date>
		<username>Scott Miller</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A Mixture of Real and Surreal</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is in some ways good and in other ways great. Some of the characters and some of the scenes are completely true to life while others are slightly skewed, providing an interesting glimpse into an alternate reality. Where the movie fails, I think, is in the resolution, trying to tie everything together and not quite pulling it off. Not everything is clear in the end, which may have been intentional, but some of the unresolved questions are more frustrating than thought-provoking. The bizarre frog scene manages to mask the dissimilarity of the stories, but we still have a hard time believing these tales could coexist in the same world. And despite the premise and the frame involving "coincidences," the coincidental nature of the stories seems inconsequential. Cruise's subplot is *very* loosely connected to the gameshow storyline, so much so that it could easily have been removed without any effect on the remaining plot.Still, this film is very interesting, beautifully filmed, and emotionally engaging. Anyone who enjoys character studies will not be disappointed with Magnolia.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-06-23</date>
		<username>Jon (jon@hlutke.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Masterpiece!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>`In this life, it's not what you hope for, it's not what you deserve -- it's what you take.'Paul Thomas Anderson's brilliant `Magnolia' has so many great aspects that a true film lover just chews up. His films in the past have been flat (Hard Eight) and overly vile (Boogie Nights) but this film written by him also shows his true talent. In his other two films you see his talent but the fact is they fall short especially `Boogie Nights' because they are overly tacky and drab. `Hard Eight' is a great film it just doesn't do what `Magnolia' does. With his use of brilliant dialogue and useful camerawork you get so much from each viewing. He overtakes his shots like Scorsese does and just leaves the camera in one spot or follows characters for a long period of time. He does this brilliantly. `Magnolia' has a story that follows a day in the life of a large group of people separated by life but in the same zest pool of humanity that plagues our country. Strictly every aspect of American culture is in the fabric of the characters, it in some sorts is like a depressing `Simpsons.' It tells so much about each character that you just seem to know what they will do next but they are so unpredictable they surprise you with each mannerism. I was so surprised that it was so much more tasteful then `Boogie Nights' which bye any standard is a porno. It is one thing to shock and use that to say something about humanity, it is a complete other to welcome that shock into the film as if it were dialogue. `Magnolia' does not say one word that I shouldn't every word is useful and true. It makes you cringe with it's brutality towards truth, but in it's three hours pays off. More than most films that use curse words as if they were spaces between words. This film does have brutal language but offers you something with it. Tom Cruise's (in one of his best roles) character T.J. Mackey is a slime ball in every sense of the word, a man that is what makes this world horrible, and his language is as distasteful as it gets. `Denise. Denise the piece.' However Philip Seymour Hoffman's character Phil Parma, or John C. Reily's character Jim Kurring hardly say one thing that is offensive. The word use even tells the viewer something about the character.` I used to be smart, but now I'm just stupid.'The film's true heart lies simply in its moral. It offers so much truth in the idea that we are all wrong, all of us. We don't do right when we have the chance we only just do and forget. `The book says, we might be through with the past, but the past ain't through with us.' The tagline of the film says `When it rains, it pours.' Society must see this harsh truth or it will suffer, but the film doesn't fix it's characters it doesn't have a happy ending, it knows that people don't and won't change, thus the musical aspect of the film when all the characters are singing `it's not going to stop, so just give up.' That is so true and so real that any person that has half a brain thinks about it. What we are is not right, not good, and certainly not worthy of any after life that may be set for the fraction of good people that exists within our society. Every time we are given a chance to shine we fail, maybe not in all aspects but certainly morally which by any standard is the most important. Paul Thomas Anderson has created a film that maybe supplies a much needed wake-up call to society, but the truth is it won't wake up a soul. The film says that so well, and so respectively. The language is hurtful and harsh but so are people. It's one of those mirror films that just simply show what is going on, what makes this one different is that it has artistic quality. This gets it up to par with some of the great American films. `I will not apologize for who I am.' Neither will society and it will pay it does in this film.`..this is my job and I love it. Because I want to do well -- in this life and in this world, I want to do well. And I want to help people. And I might get twenty bad calls a day. But one time I can help someone and make a save -- correct a wrong or right a situation -- then I'm a happy cop. And as we move through this life we should try and do good. Do good... And if we can do that, and not hurt anyone else, well... then...'</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Just a few first impressions.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Magnolia' is a story of Chance, Coincidence and Chaos.These are presented as features of the world and of human lives.But the lives portrayed are not entirely seen as being at the mercy of chance; there is a strong determinist thread running through each of the characters histories.The controlling past throws our lives into chaos, but the randomness of chance can paradoxically restore some order.All parts are well acted in this movie, but Tom Cruse is perhaps especially good.Why though, does he possess that attitude towards women?</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Another of the great ones</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't consider myself a connosieur of great movies, I just know how I feel when watching a movie, and Magnolia evoked some of the strongest emotions ever from me. I had an impending sense of doom from the opening scene and 2/3 through was absolutely certain that every main character was going to die to escape the horror of it all. Everday life at breakneck speed. I've always been a very empathetic person due to my own personal tragedies and cried throughout this movie because I felt and could understand the pain and agony of the characters. One user comment asked, Did every character have to break down in tears? Each of us is not being true to ourselves if we don't admit that there are unresolved issues in our lives that we want to scream, yell, cry, pound the walls and fall out on the floor about. As for the frogs, a miracle was needed to stop everyones headlong descent into death, despair and oblivion, and I commend P. T. Anderson on his courage to show us a whopper of a miracle. After watching Boogie Nights and now this movie, Mr. Anderson has a true fan in me. THANKS</fullReview>

		<username>indy-39</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>relentlessly bleak...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's always hard to pan a film that has so much ambition but this movie is such an ordeal to watch that you feel you have to warn people ahead of time. Relentlessly bleak, overlong, and played at fever pitch it comes off like a second rate Bergman film with a script by David Mamet. Populated with unlikeable or simple characters, it has a falseness to it. Life is not like this (as the film contends)...at least mine isn't. There are tragedies and mistakes but there is also love and laughter. Perhaps a fair penance for some in the audience it is too harsh a punishment for the rest of us.p.s. Aimee Mann's music is perfect for the film: insipid and whiny. If you like that kind of music, it's a wonder you haven't killed yourself already.p.p.s. Isn't it fascinating that Cruise gives the best performance of his career as a hypermasculine male? Now that's real acting!</fullReview>

		<date>2002-04-23</date>
		<username>midnightrane</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Sins of the Fathers</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'll keep this short, since the movie was long. Most films work that way. The longer they are, the less you need to say, and vice-versa (speaking of which...). I loved this movie. Intense, confusing, inspiring and incredibly well-acted. This is the kind of movie for which actors study.All the technical elements are top-notch. The players are superb and the writing is special. This is a rare film experience. It may illicit adoration or frustration depending upon your perspective. It's out-of-style subtlety demands your complete attention. I can understand why so many people turn their nose up at a work like this, it's so ambitious that it invites it. It's also easy to see why so many love it, it earns it.Finally, the "frogs". There seem to be as many valid opinions on their symbolism as there are viewers. Personally, I interpreted them to be a wide-spectrum response from the heavens on the theme of "Sins of our Fathers". Analyzing how the "frogs" affect each character in respect to their participation in the stated theme brought to light very interesting commentary on the creators' views, and provoked some serious thought on my own. Regardless, it may well be remembered as one of the greatest scenes of all-time.Bottom line: whatever your take, if you have the time and the stomach for it (lots of serious, powerful subject matter), it's worth a look. My score: 9/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-12</date>
		<username>centurymantra-2</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Evocative vibes...intangible emotions</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Magnolia' is, if nothing else, a genuine artistic statement. One that can only be described by evoking it's own name. Although one could consider the film reminiscent, or even derivative of Robert Altman's own unique filmmaking style, we could simply consider this happenstance or even an intended homage and skip right past that particular pointing finger. The ambiance evoked within the film is fascinating and steeped with an intangible &amp; shadowy essence that pushes the tide of the films events along quite nicely. What I found most fascinating about the film is the way in which the character sketches played themselves out. The characters that the film revolved about seemed to exist as stylistic archetypes rather than 'real' people which one would or even should identify with or connect to on an emotional level. I honestly, did not truly 'care' about anyone in this movie. Yet this somehow, in the hands of the filmmaker and his appointed acting crew, worked in it's favor, perhaps because the presentation of the characters simply avoided the melodrama and emotion that would simply side-step the deeper, less tangible &amp; ambiguous soul-searching the denizens of the film are intended to display. The much maligned (and oft-loved) 'amphibian storm' that ties the film together seems to affirm the symbolic bent of the film. Overall, I found it to be a very effective film that stuck with me for quite awhile for reasons I am still unable to pinpoint. There are several lucid moments &amp; scenes in the film that convey much more than the 'here and now' of the image flitting across the eyeballs, acting like little incorporeal time-bombs that hatch in the mind days later. The 'meaning' of it all is still rather cryptic and diffuse. Is the film a shallow and exploitative noir-opera? Is it a film that attempts to splay open the dark side of the American society? Is it a portrait of humanity's endless soul-searching? Is it...? Overall, I feel a film like 'Ice Storm' was able to more explicitly capture the essence that P.T. Anderson was chasing. But in the process, the strange ether-zone he ultimately channeled his cinematic vision into is oddly compelling and highly effective.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Paul Thomas Anderson is revealed as an explorator of taboo subjects of American culture!</shortDescription>

It also shows different love stories. The acting was marvelous, but a little bit shallow. This is definitely the best movie that Tom Cruise has carried out. I don't really care that it lasted about three hours, but it wasn't truly necessary to be that long. The scene of the frogs was quite unbelievable and funny, but I don't deny it was original. The plot is somewhat weak, since it's not clear. Overall I don't think I wasted my time by seeing this movie, but it wasn't as great as I thought it'd be. 6/10</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Like many great dramas Magnolia, with its interwoven tales of broken hearts and damaged lives, is depressing viewing for much of the way yet it is so emotionally powerful that I found it more gripping than almost any thriller or action movie. The actors - including Tom Cruise - are all superb and the climax is one of the most startling and appropriate I've ever seen - it acts as some kind of emotional catharsis after all the turmoil the characters suffered. Perhaps the mark of a great film is that you want to see it again shortly after it finishes. For me Magnolia was like that.It also has an excellent soundtrack, mainly written by Aimee Mann.9/10</fullReview>

I have recommended it to friends, I've watched it three times and for the first time in my life I bought, rather than rent, the tape as well! If you are an expert about movies, Magnolia is a must! Your knowledge would be extremely and inadmissibly lacking if you didn't watch it! It is an epiphany for everybody who hasn't done any kind of soul search in their life before. It is an epiphany for those who have been soul searching all their lives! It is simply for everybody! The plot is excellent, the actors are stunning, Anderson is a genius and trying to explain it would mean spoil its inner message. Plus this is a kind of movie that, more than any other, has different levels of understanding and it is vital that everybody finds their own, as I said before, their own epiphany. I've never had any interest in acting before but, after seeing Magnolia, I've actually started thinking of it. My dream would be to be an extra in one of his movies: it would be such an honour! I definitely give it ten out of ten and I look forward to Anderson's new movie! Congratulations!</fullReview>

		<date>2002-02-27</date>
		<username>Darryl Cox (DD-931)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Two Movies</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yes, it's more interesting than the factory product cranked out by the studios. Yes, it has some good performances, and I appreciate that it's character driven. No, it's not good enough to be in the IMDB Top 250. And no, overall it's not a very good movie.Hell, yes, it's too long! And you can't tell me it had to be. This is two movies here. Think about it. Wouldn't it have been interesting to watch the second movie and catch all the intersections with the first movie? But more importantly, it would show a little more respect to the audience not to make them sit in the theatre for umpteen hours waiting for this movie to get to the point. It's pretty clear to me that Mr. Anderson needed someone to tell him to be a little less indulgent and a little more respectful of his audience. He would have said everything he wanted to say here in two movies, had some interesting fun with the connections between the two movies, and quite frankly made more money. And yes, it's important to show the studio suits that art and character driven movies can make money. That way we don't have to watch CLIFFHANGER, PART NINE.One more thing: Did EVERYONE in this movie have to have a scene where they broke down in tears? Overkill is overkill, no matter how you dress it up.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-02-09</date>
		<username>CBwayo (CBwayo@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>complicated, but pure genius</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>No movie has ever wow'ed me more than P.T. Anderson's Magnolia. It runs long at over 3 hours, but I see no way around it. Ending this movie any second early would take away the superb acting, perfect plot structure, and incredible film technique. I'd say that this movie has one of, if not the best ensemble cast ever. I couldn't believe that the critics had to decide who should get nominated for Best Supporting Actor. They all deserved it, though in my mind, Philip Baker Hall should have won. Overall the film is complicated.. we not only have the theme set up at the beginning about strange coincidences, but the relationship between the parallels between sets of characters in the movie are fascinating. We notice the almost identical struggles of characters like Stanley and Frank, Jimmy and Earl, Stanley and Donny, Claudia and Linda, Jim and Frank.... the list goes on and the relationships overlap. As if these struggles aren't obvious enough by the story line, P.T. Anderson spells them out for us in soliloquoys, seemingly random quotes by the characters, and through music. There is absolutely no way that one could find this movie confusing when everything is presented for you on the screen in such a neat little package. I've heard complaints about the frogs, but I honestly see no way the movie could have gotten around them. This instance ties the story together, gives meaning to the characters lives, and is one of the most daring and brilliant scenes I have ever seen. If I were to give this film a rating, it'd be two thumbs up, 5 stars, 11 out of 10, etc. I definitely see how it is ranked so high on the top 250 list, and if it were my list, it would make the top ten. If you want an exciting, action-packed movie, and have a short attention span..see trashy movies like Fast and the Furious or Rollerball, or a Steven Spielberg picture. If you want to see a beautifully crafted, acted film that is almost guaranteed to change your movie-going experience for the rest of your life, see Magnolia.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-02-04</date>
		<username>hermit58 (hermit58@prodigy.net)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>for movie lovers only. the rest of you, look elsewhere.Four Stars.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a very long film. If you have the attention span of the average viewer, then don't bother. If you are a film lover, then dig in, because this film is as full as it is long. Full of the vagaries of life, the sad, the awful, the tragic, and even the humorous moments that lie in between. As usual Paul Thomas Anderson takes a terrific story, and enlists as many fine actors as one possibly can, to flesh out the tale. This film has many stars, but all are given the chance to shine, and all do, brightly. Jason Robards, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, Tom Cruise, Philip Seymour Hoffman, the list is as long as Magnolia itself. The stories told within could have produced two or three smaller films, but Paul Thomas Anderson chose to combine them all,and remarkably pulls it off. No Car chases, No big budget stunts, just people, and their lives, drawn here with a sometimes cynical eye, the story is the thing. People are cruel, and foolish, and sometimes maddening, but here they are always interesting. Four Stars out of a possible four.Highly Recommended.****.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>there are some people who really like this movie. they are justified in this. the film was very engrossing for me. it was a little over three hours, but because scenes were switching all of the time and you didnt spend much more than five minuets on any one scene at a time...i was not bored. the acting was good, the cinematography was very nice as well. the problem with this movie is that you know what the director, writer, narrator (whoever it is that is attempting to get a message across to us) is telling us within the first ten minuets. really the movie goes no further on its theme in the next three hours. yes it does sidetrack itself into some thoughts on forgivness, honesty, and the relationships between parents and their children, but it does not elaborate on those themes enough to make them major or even noteworthy. what i am trying to say with this review is that yes, this movie is good, but no, it is not as great as everyone has been trying to say. and actually there are some things (like the sing along and the frogs) that might serve their purpose, but are a little cheesy. so that this review does not sound to critical...i just want to say that i did really enjoy watching it and seeing what would happen. i enjoyed the game show parts...i liked the acting of william h. macey and the guy who played the nurse. for all of those who love this movie...i understand. it is hip, stylish and fun to watch. for all of those who dont...i understand. it is often thin and rather predictable (apart from the frog thing). have a beautiful life readers</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A larger audience...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A larger audience could easily have been reached by limiting the vulgarity of the dialog, a few insignificant scenes, and an unnecessary character element.Why do producers find it necessary to breech normal dialog and conduct to deliver a message? At first, I was prepared to shut it down, and take it back to the rental store. But giving it a few more minutes, I was drawn in by the immediate, and deep character development. The three hours that passed were highly entertaining, thought provoking, and I hardly noticed the length.I don't (want to) think I'm the minority here, but why does the language have to be so offensive. Why is there a need to see a couple sexing it up in the opening sequence, and why does Tom Cruise's character have to be demoralizing to a potential 50% of the audience?The situational intensity of the characters does not require these elements. I found Tom Cruises motivational message ridiculous and silly. This part of Tom's character could have been communicated another way.I can handle the drug addiction, and the unfaithful spouses, but the combination of all the elements make the story too dark. I wouldn't have my wife sit through it.This is an extremely artistic production, and bears witness to some great writing and cinematography, but I feel cheated that I couldn't be comfortable sharing this with my wife. Too bad.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-16</date>
		<username>hdorne</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best movie EVER (next to Star Wars)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had always been curious about this film and what it was about, and a friend of mine told me to rent it sometime. Little did I know... Magnolia is basically nine different storylines that are all similar to each other, related to each other, and revolve around a center, like the structure of a magnolia flower. They all, in my mind, dealt with forgiveness, regret, love, and the idea that everything happens for a reason. I say "in my mind" because it's what I got from the film, and what I got may differ slightly from the director's original artistic intentions. Anywho... The acting in this film is astonishing, with Tom Cruise, Jason Robards, and John C. Reilly being the main scene-stealers. Director P.T. Anderson shows us that he truly cares for his characters. The music is excellent, as well, which is performed by the amazingly talented singer/songwriter Aimee Mann. Supertramp also jumps in with some classics, which adds a nice flavor to the film, but Aimee Mann destroys the competition with "Save Me" and the tear-jerker "Wise Up". The interesting thing? P.T. Anderson actually wrote this film as an adaptation of Aimee Mann songs, of which he put on the soundtrack. Granted, this movie is not for everybody. If you're the type that sees movies for cheap thrills, big explosions, fast cars, and hot chicks, then go see that disposable hunk of crap known as "The Fast and the Furious". However, if you're into films that require thinking, such as American Beauty, Memento, Requiem for a Dream, etc., then you will most likely enjoy this film. Don't let what people say about the length bother you. They make it sound like if it's any more than 3 hours, then it's garbage. Folks, it's 3 hours and 8 minutes. Come on. 8 freakin' minutes. Stop your belly-achin'. Best part of the movie? Easy. The scene where all the characters are singing along to "Wise Up" is easily the most emotionally draining scene I've seen in a long time. It centralizes the idea of the film. It makes the film what it is. It is the center of the magnolia, so to speak. I highly reccommend this film. It will leave you breathless and drained of all emotion. You will be contemplating this film in your head for a very long time. And the frogs? Well, you'll just have to see and make your own conlusions from it. There is no one explanation to it. HUGE props to P.T. Anderson for crafting the best film in the past 10 years.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-11-12</date>
		<username>thomases</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrific performances</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>NOTE THIS REVIEW CONTAINS A FEW SPOILERS. I would definitely recommend this film. The stories it tells are compelling and the performances are first rate. The obvious parallel in structure is to the movie Shortcuts." This movie lacks the narrative cohesion of Shortcuts and I would comment that this very ambitious movie's reach exceeds its grasp to some extent. But I would say that it differs from Altman's film in genre in important ways which make its focus different &amp; I therefore don't feel it is productive to dwell too much on the comparison. I would label this a "generation x" movie(Anderson would probably dislike that) for lack of a better term -- if there isn't a more accurately descriptive label for these types of movies there should be. The movies in this genre have an "off the wall" quality(again, a crude categorization). Examples that come to mind are "Clerks," "Henry Fool," or "Buffalo 66"(I see a kind of parallel to the group singing of "Wise Up" to, for example, the dance sequence by Christina Ricci in "Buffalo 66." These movies mix humor with pathos--one of the important techniques in "Magnolia." The performances are truly powerful and would not be possible without the screenplay. Jason Robards' performance is all the more moving because he himself died the next year of cancer. Tom Curise's performance may be the most memorable and seems even more authentic when I learned that he felt the pressure of close parallels in his life as regarding his strained relations with his own father. I think this is one of Cruise's finest acting jobs. And then there are the frogs--see Exodus 8 in the old Testament. Also it has been rumored to me that this phenomenon really does occur! They get sucked up into the atmosphere due to unusual wind conditions --or something like that. Note quiz kid Jeremy Black's comment to himself that this sort of thing does happen. And Melora Walters' weak smile at the end is the most touching moment in the movie for me--a faint affirmation in the face of the total adversity of life, a ray of hope.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-11-11</date>
		<username>DiLuBe</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Beautifully Crafted and Performed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am not one to praise movies lightly. Yet I find it very difficult to find anything wrong with this movie. It is difficult to watch it and not see a reflection of oneself in any of the characters, if not with all, as it was in my case.Although the "wise up" seen is one of the most criticized, I believe that it is the one that truly captures the essence of the film. Who has never sang along to a depressing song that fit the mood of the particular situation that he or she was in. It proves how although everyone may feel alone, this loneliness is one of the fundamental things that brings individuals together. It saddens me to see people that do not realize the merit of this scene. IF it is too difficult for someone to understand, maybe they should watch the REM video "Everybody Hurts" and see the same theme on a level that appeals to the lowest common denominator (This is not a slur towards that excellent video).The other most criticized scene is the biblical one. It is another excellent scene, not only for its obvious biblical allusion but in keeping with the "anything can happen" theme presented at the film's start.It is very hard for me to summarize into a few words how much I enjoyed this film. It is very depressing that people disregard its obvious merit based on its length, which is not even a factor in my mind.The final thought that plagues me as I read through the user comments and the top 250 movies. This excellent movie was in the low hundreds, while a movie like sixth sense is 47.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-06</date>
		<username>Jarred (jarred@burningpaper.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Appalling drivel, attempting to create sympathy by endless shouting at the camera</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film has received a lot of acclaim since it was released in 1999, and I finally got around to renting it on DVD a few weeks ago. Sunday evening, 8pm. Bad idea.To begin with, this film is long, more than 3 hours. That alone doesn't make it bad, but it certainly helps. We simply weren't prepared for the sheer length of it.Then there's the acting. For some reason, there is a kind of director who directs a kind of film where there is a lot of shouting. Magnolia is one of those films. There is barely a single scene in this film that doesn't involve someone screaming out their lines, frequently crying at the same time. It is a film that is all loudness and fury, to the point where you can no longer distinguish any emotion at all. It becomes strangely bland and unemotional, a victim of the director's failure to vary the intensity at all.Some performances are good -- Tom Cruise has his moments as the motivational speaker Frank T.J. Mackey, in particular -- but in general every part is so overplayed and overstated, and repeated over and over and over, until you're screaming "I get it! You're upset, you're depressed, you're dying. I know, I know. I understand goddamit!"Having seen, I'm sure, Robert Altman's "Short Cuts" six years earlier, the director could hardly have failed to notice the similarities between this and that film. Indeed, they have a lot in common, but where Short Cuts weaved interesting, intricate connections between the characters, Magnolia simply states them, and the tiny sense of surprise near the end as to the overall connection between the events is of no particular interest. It certainly does nothing to live up to the promise made at the start of the film of a story about strange co-incidences.This film is one damn thing after the other, in a meaningless sequence, begging to finish from about an hour-and-half in, and only getting it's appeal met in double that time.Yes, there is a scene where frogs fall out of the sky. So what? It wouldn't make a difference if there was a scene where the entire cast of Jurrasic Park fell out of the sky. It's all just one more tiresome event in a movie that is full of them. The only reason anyone gets excited about this scene is because something finally HAPPENS in this film other than people shouting at each other.The film has its good points -- there are some well acted and amusing scenes, and it is possible to find some humour here and there. But overall this is one of the longest, most exhausting films I have ever watched, and in my opinion, would only really appeal to people who require a four-pound hammer to make a point where a toothpick would do just fine.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-10-31</date>
		<username>tomcantwell</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Soap</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I can only comment on the first seventy minutes of this movie as by then I was bleeding from the eyes through boredom. I loved Boogie Nights and looked forward to Magnolia so much that I bought it, unseen, on DVD. The intro was very good and promised an intelligent, thought provoking drama. Instead there was only tedious soap style vignettes with unconvincing swearing standing in for a script. Throughout all this was the most annoying and intrusive music I have ever heard in a film. The songs just went on and on and on while the dialogue, for what it was worth, got lost like inane conversation in a disco bar. The previous evening I treated myself to a rerun of the 1956 version of Invasion of the Bodysnatchers which only lasts ten or so minutes more than I gave Magnolia, yet Magnolia had me yawning and looking at the clock, dreading yet another two hours of this drivel. Paul Thomas Anderson has shown great promise but will sink himself completely if he thinks this pretentious nonsense has any depth, merit, or even simple entertainment value. It doesn't. And by the way, Tom Cruise's over the top performance was simply an embarrassingly transparent act that he couldn't pull off. To see how this is done properly, check out John Tutturro in The Big Lebowski.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-10-26</date>
		<username>Richard Brunton</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Slow in parts and involved, yet thoroughly rewarding.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A wonderfully shot movie, with moving camera, warm lighting and interesting characters. Add to that a hugely experienced and talented cast and you have the makings of a fantastic film.There are a few instances where I found myself wishing the story along, and wondering what the possible outcome of the intricately weaved stories could be, and in the end I felt slightly disappointed when this was not as amazing as the build up, and perhaps my own imagination, had made this.However, the ending was extremely well done, and mirrored real life, with as many unanswered questions as completed tales. In fact, I don't think you could say that any of the tales are, in fact, complete. Again, much like real life. Which is a hugely satisfying thing to see from Hollywood.Tom Cruise will stun you in this, possibly, as I've heard, this character is somewhat close to his real character. Who knows, I don't. Jason Robards, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Julianne Moore are wonderful too, and not just because I have the biggest crush on Ms Moore...Watch this, stick out the few short periods where you wonder what's going to happen and get a sore bum, and you will have a hugely rewarding experience. In fact, I think I'll watch it again this week.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-10-19</date>
		<username>lot49</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Better than "the Blair Witch Project"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" has plenty of great actors giving good performances, and it has more than a few memorable scenes. Unfortunately, after 100 minutes have passed, we're waiting for the movie to end. When the end finally comes, we're wondering why it took so long. As others have said, Robert Altman did a better job telling a similar story in "Short Cuts" (1993). Altman's protege Alan Rudolph even did a better job in the flawed "Welcome to L.A." back in 1977.P.T. Anderson tries to impress us with details, but minutiae are no substitute for good writing. At least two of the three examples of odd coincidences in the prologue are urban legends that have been debunked on the Internet (The dead scuba diver in the tree and the suicidal jumper who was shot by one of his parents). Perhaps the prologue warns us that the movie is going to waste our time much like these tall tales did.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-10-03</date>
		<username>travisrose</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Misfire</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Paul Anderson is a bright guy. If you read any further you will not find another compliment. Magnolia is a dizzying siege of agonizingly misspent emotion and talent. The only thing that upset me more than the movie is the arrogant pseudo-intellectual faction that followed it. Several critics, who have replaced Citizen Kane with Magnolia in the theater-house Parthenon, have been so bold as to say that if you didn't like Magnolia, you're not intelligent or sophisticated or deep. B******t. Some scenes of Magnolia are interesting or even brilliant as they stand alone, but collectively there is an unhappy disjointedness to the pace and continuity. Along these lines, Magnolia is one of the most bizarre and frustrating moviegoing experiences I've ever had. The acting is fantastic (Cruise gave a career performance), the concept is interesting, and the writing is excellent, yet the amalgam is almost incoherent. I read that Anderson says that Magnolia is the best movie he will ever make. Not true. Boogie Nights was better and, if he continues to make movies, Anderson will best his own expectations. B-</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-09-01</date>
		<username>criticboy1 (cultfetishkid@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Interesting character portraits.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>**** = A masterpiece to be recorded in the books and never forgotten***1/2 = A classic in time; simply a must see*** = A solid, worth-while, very entertaining piece**1/2 = A good movie, but there are some uneven elements or noticeable flaws** = May still be considered good in areas, but this work has either serious issues or is restrained by inevitable elements deemed inescapable (e.g., genre)*1/2 = Mostly a heap of nothing sparked by mildly worthwhile momentsBOMB = Not of a viewable quality- Magnolia = ***1/2- Rated "R" (for pervasive strong language including some vulgar, coarse dialogue, drug content, and for some sexuality/nudity and violence)The movie introduces itself with a narrator explaining how "strange things" happen all the time, and gives examples, with the rest of the film as one long final example of characters strangely woven into one who all save each other and go to hell and back together... without really knowing it. These characters range from a lonely cop who only wants to do good in life, the drug addicted woman who he falls for, her incestuous, cancer-stricken father/game show host, two starring brainiac contestants (one a winner from way back in the 60s, the other a neglected child), the dying man who produces the show, and his regretful wife, caring nurse, and long lost son. Somehow all of these people share their emotional extremes together in waves of misery and nirvhana all on one full moon-ish day.Director Paul Thomas Anderson tells us a heartfelt story with pain and joy to spare. Although utterly bizarre, "MAGNOLIA" miraculously rings truth, despite several odd moments of an almost science-fiction nature. At a staggering 3+ hours, it manages to interest the audience and all those who are willing to put in the time and observe three dimensional characters interacting realistically for once. A triumph, it still never manages to have a clear emotional climax, it all sort of runs together in a big blotch of sorrow and every sinful situation you can think of. But lets ask ourselves: does that really matter? If you just want to connect with a handful of people without a phone or modem, no. This is the type of movie you will walk away from hoping for a part 2, like a favorite soap opera where you save a certain part within yourself to care and hope for these imaginary characters. Wrenching and brilliant, if even flawed at times.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Loved it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is a movie involving a number of different stories that all seem to be connected by the sadness and loneliness involved in each one of them. I've talked with people about this movie and for the most part it's a movie you either love or hate, like the Blair Witch Project and Eyes Wide Shut that have that same dinamic. I loved this movie. I thought this film did a great job in connecting the stories and playing them so they don't feel sloppy. Tom Cruise gives one of his best performances ever, and the others from Williem H. Macy's character to Julianne Moore's are interesting and for the most part believable. It's long but it kept my attention well. I won't give away the ending but I don't think it's as bad as some people say. It's totally unexpected, very strange, and fairly compelling. I can't quite give this movie a 10 because I felt it could have come together a little better. Still it's a wonderful movie. 9/10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-24</date>
		<username>(skeetscollins@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the three best films of the 90's</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Along with Wes Anderson's Rushmore, and P.T. Anderson's other masterpice, Boogie Nights, Magnolia is one of the best three films of the 90's. Magnolia is a series of interlocking stories: The characters include Stanley Spector( an amazing performance by young Jeremy Blackman), a current quiz kid champion who wants to be loved by his father; Frank T.J. Mackey( Tom Cruise), a sexist motivational speaker who gives speeches on how to "seduce and destroy" women, former quiz kid Donnie Smith( William H. Macy), now a middle-aged homosexual who is only kept going because of his love for a bartender, a religious cop, Jim Kurring( John C. Reilly) who wants to help people, Claudia Wilson Gator( Melora Walters), a troubled drug addict who is asked out on a date by Jim, who has no idea of her problem; Jimmy Gator( Philip Baker Hall), a dying game show host who is Claudia's father; Earl Partridge ( Jason Robards), a TV producer who is also dying of cancer; Linda Partridge( Julianne Moore), Earl's pill-popping wife; and Phil Parma ( Philip Seymour Hoffman)a kind nurse who goes beyond his career, and actually feels his patients pain, but who really has no life beyond his job, and has a problem communicating with the outside world. Magnolia happens all in one random day, and the characters lives play out with Aimee Mann music in the background( the characters sining "Wise Up" is truly a brilliant cinematic moment). Although Magnolia may be a little too long( 3 hours, 8 minutes), for some viewers, Magnolia takes you on an experience like few other movies do.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-20</date>
		<username>supafly323</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Overall, an enchanting movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is one of those movies that are just difficult to review - perhaps primarily because most people either hate it beyond belief or cherish it as the best ever. I fall in neither category. Instead, I think it is a cinematographic masterpiece laden with magical performances and stunning, unforgettable scenes, but it's bogged down by some severe overacting, boring plot lines and way way way too many F-words. I saw Goodfellas and thought Joe Pesci swears a lot. Never underestimate the power of P.T. Anderson and the F-bomb.Anderson works to create some incredible characters here. John C. Reilly is amazing as a lovable but goofy cop. Jeremy Blackman is superb for a young boy. Melinda Dillon portrays Jimmy Gator's wife with elegance and grace. And Tom Cruise gives the performance of his career. But then you have Julianne Moore, who's just painful to watch (evidence the silly scene at the pharmacy, the lawyer's office, et. al), Jason Robards (how many hours did i spend watching that movie, hoping he would just die already), Philip Seymour Hoffman (liked him a lot in State and Main but couldn't stomach his sniveling nurse here), and, perhaps worst, Melora Walters, whose overacted, coked-up Claudia just clashes.I loved the frogs, especially because Anderson made them gross with the sound and visual effects. I thought the reference to Exodus 8:2 was strong, and I feel it is strong enough to tie together all the vignettes. But the scenes with Robards, Hoffman and Moore (how can Anderson put them all together at once!?) were unbearable. William H. Macy (who I usually love) was only OK as Quiz Kid Donnie Smith, perhaps because Anderson wrote his role too over-the-top.I also really liked the black kid from the projects as "the prophet"... added a nice touch to the movie. It would have been even better if I could understand what the $(#@ he was saying.I guess my review isn't poised to champion or insult this film (and i have way too much respect for P.T. Anderson and Boogie Nights to insult Magnolia, which he calls the best movie he will ever make) but I do feel there are positives and negatives. Plot isn't as tight as Boogie Nights or Hard Eight, and I suppose at the end of it all I would have to say this is the worst of his three movies. That doesn't mean it's bad, because Anderson is the most promising American director I've seen in years, but just a little... rough.7.5 or 8 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-28</date>
		<username>(tantrum@shreve.net)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>dissecting the frog</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have been trying to figure out "Magnolia" ever since I saw it. I immediately thought of John Guare's "Six Degrees of Separation," and saw a parallel philosophy with "Magnolia."As far as the frog scene goes, I know it must have something to do with the eighth chapter of Exodus; the whole, "Let My People Go," proclamation. In that chapter, everything is infested by a plague of frogs because the Pharaoh wouldn't release the people. I suppose there is a connection of the freeing of all those hurt souls in the climax of "Magnolia," but, remember, the Biblical plague was executed as punishment because the people WEREN'T liberated. So that kind of counteracts any sense of resolution...Another possibility involves this Southern urban legend about vanishing ponds. I'm not a meterologist and never will be, but I AM Southern and that's enough for me to perpetuate fantastical folklore. The legend is that, with the extreme weather changes in the South, (weather that is loyal to NO season) there have been environmental conditions---that have oscillated so wildly from dry and sunny to humid and cloudy---that water evaporates alarmingly quickly. So quickly, that fish &amp; frogs have been dragged into cloudwater and have fallen from the sky. Or something like that. It IS fantastical, but it's supposedly happened. (And in Shreveport, Louisiana in the 50s, there was a thing about peaches falling from the sky that everybody's grandparents remembers and talks about ad nauseum. I am not making this up.)The whole idea of water makes sense too, as there were a lot of water images in the movie. The weather, for one. They keep giving us written forecasts and then it rains---and it rarely ever rains in Southern California---so that might have been a harbinger of the folklore. Also, water is the most profound expression of life beyond, of course, the voice. We use water as an expression for many things: the little boy peeing under stress as the host of the show, Jimmy Gator, is crying after drinking too much (again with the water) and the whole time everybody's sweating (water), and then they're giving Jimmy Gator water----replacing water with water---when they're trying to sober him up...And then there's release/anger with Tom Cruise's tears at the bedside of his father, there's poor Claudia who has tears in her eyes the WHOLE movie, rain and water and tears and everything it represents plays a huge role in illustrating emotion.Okay, now for the magnolia. Whenever I'm trying to dissect something, I always go for etymological-scalpeling first. If that is unsatisfying, I go for the Bible, as most everything has Judeo-Christian values smeared all in it. If that's unsuccessful (which it was, as I don't remember any profound magnolia stories in the Bible), I go for World mythology. And I don't remember anything in it, either. Frustrating, because the image HAS to have been important---I mean, it's the $#%^&amp; title of the entire movie.Therefore, I figured that the magnolia (a tree exclusive to North America and particularly seen in the South) starts out with pure-white petals cast wide, kind of like we all start out: innocent and opened. Pure. But, if you've ever touched a magnolia, you know that the petal you touched turns brown and withers. I suppose this has something to do with being hurt by other people throughout life and experiencing things that take our innocence. Reminds me of Gerard Manly Hopkins' poem, "Spring and Fall." Also, the"Mag" prefix means something huge and bold, loosely.Anyway, those are my thoughts about the movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-23</date>
		<username>Malcolm Ian Connell (miconnell@ozemail.com.au)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Thank you, PTA.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Somewhere in amongst the Darwin Awards, the first four or five Talking Heads albums, Beck's cut and paste, Tool's songs and of course, the collaborations of Aimee Mann and Jon Brion lurks the magic of Paul Thomas Anderson's twisted and immensely compassionate imagination. And he, in turn, listened very carefully to himself to give us this beautiful film. Much of the crew of Boogie nights are here, many almost beyond recognition. Cruise, Moore and Robards earn their paycheque for working so damned hard and enjoying themselves. If you haven't seen it, see it. If you can't get hold of a copy, borrow mine. Better yet, nick one from somewhere. Not mine, though. I want to watch it again tomorrow for breakfast. If you don't like it, you're not alone. Go back to your Willy Wonka existence. For the rest of us, however, this movie is magic and I simply want to thank you, Paul Thomas Anderson, for flaming the embers on the dying Hollywood campfire.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-22</date>
		<username>Gary M. James</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Urban Legends: Believe It or Not</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I left the theater a moviegoer asked me how the film was. I hesitated and said that it was an ambitious failure. There were moments when I thought "Magnoila" soared: Tom Cruise, who played perhaps his least likable character in the movies, gave an angry, fiery, complex performance. It is interesting what Cruise can do when he's given the chance. Philip Baker Hall, William H. Macy and, in his final performance, Jason Robards, also gave fascinating portraits of people who are trying to come to grips with their past and having a hard time living with themselves in the present. Kudos also go to some other P.T. Anderson regulars: Philip Seymour Hoffman as the nurse aide to Robards' character and John C. Reilly as the helpful, well-intentioned L.A. beat cop.I also thought Aimee Mann's songs ("Wise Up", and especially, "Save Me") were well-incorporated in the film. It didn't distract, it was a little bit of a Greek chorus. The movie soundtrack on CD even sounds better on its own.I was disappointed with the performances of Juilanne Moore and Melora Walters. I though both women were way over the top. Both characters became annoying to me. **POSSIBLE SPOILER** I guess what put me on the side of disliking the movie was when the frogs started coming down from the sky. After almost three hours, I knew something odd was going to occur, especially since the movie started with several urban legends that may or may not have happened in real life. I was hoping for a strong payoff and what I said out loud in the theater was "OH, COME ON!!!!!" Writer/Director Paul Thomas Anderson did a better job in his previous film "Boogie Nights". "Magnolia" was just as ambitious but "Boogie Nights" was more focused, documentary-like movie on one man's life in the 70's porn industry. "Magnolia" had flashes of brilliance but in the end was an unfocused, pretentious and wildly uneven epic drama.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-16</date>
		<username>mkham6</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Powerful, searing reflection on life, death and redemption</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Truly an amazing movie. Paul Anderson takes the most serious of subjects: dying, guilt, and redemption and infuses them with so much understanding, perception, love, and yes, fun that the movie is a steady tour de force. Even the frogs was a touch of Mexican fantasism that no one blinked twice at. Performances are roundly powerful, and intense; and multiple threads of stories hurtle towards an agonizing climax. Anderson's love of the characters is evident throughout- they are tortured, damaged, losers- but... who isn't. I would have liked to have Cruise's conversation with my father before he went. Have no idea why this movie has an ill-deserved R rating- apart from alot of "f__"'s and a couple of flashes of sex- this isn't an R movie, and it's circulation was probably badly hurt by it. A long (3 hr.), but captivating and arresting film: harsh, brilliant, funny, sad, and hopeful. This isn't Cruise's movie- he's just one of an ensemble- but his pathological over-intensity was never used to better effect. 'Seduce + Destroy' Interesting concept. Mike Hammerschlag</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-06-15</date>
		<username>Jose E</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Could have been a masterpiece</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I needed to see this movie twice to get the whole history. It must have been real complicated to put together because of its twisting script - six stories that are somehow related to each other, though this only surfaces at the end.WARNING! - Stop reading if you have not seen it yet (Contains spoilers).Leaving aside the main fault of Magnolia - the excessive running time, about three hours, it's a well made movie, with an impressive job by Julianne Moore as Linda Partridge and Tom Cruise as Frank, among others. Though I usually don't like this guy's job I must admit he does a good one here. The vocabulary used in Magnolia can outrage people (I'm not one of them), but I think it's necessary, especially in Frank's character to give him a complete dimension. Tom Cruise's character is really mad as hell, with all that talk about taming the female thing and so on. How pathetic is when, asked to give an interview to that female reporter, he takes his shirt off and starts strutting to impress her, which he fails to succeed. And how he gets so upset and hostile when she raises the subject of his past.As commented above, Magnolia is TOO LONG. The scenes in deathbeds bore so much that you certainly yearn for them to end.The scenes which take place on that TV contest called "What Do Children Know?" are interesting to me. And what about Philip Parma (Philip Seymour Hoffman's character) getting so heavy in that bar repeating over and over again to the bartender he's got so much love to give? This part is large as well, but fortunately Supertramp's music helps bear it.The parts I like the most are those involving the cop, first in that old woman's house when he wants to search her closet and she keeps refusing. Later he comes to that junkie girl's house answering a complaint about noise. Weird enough both start to feel attracted to each other.One of the few scenes that can be considered as funny is the one when he pours the coffee the junkie girl's made on a plant. Sometimes I've wondered what is the meaning of the policeman losing his gun in the pouring rain.The question many people (Also me) are still wondering is what's the rain frogs supposed to mean? These scenes are impressive, but I'm clueless yet. Don't sit down to watch this movie if you're easily annoyed by offensive language and you like short and joyful stories, cause Magnolia is not either of them. This movie would be a masterpiece with a shorter running time (Twenty or thirty minutes less would have helped), less swearing and less and shorter agony scenes. Unfortunately it's not so and that's why I give it six out of ten.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>peeweefan</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Simply Magical ! !</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>1,000 word maximum doesn't begin to describe all the feelings of awe and wonder when seeing this movie for the first time. And I mention first time, because it is imperative to view it at least twice, if not more, to really GET this movie. From the opening sequence of 3 "urban legend" discussions about coincidences to the last half hour, which, in a word, was BREATHLESS, this film hit all the right notes.Jason Robards, Julianne Moore, Melinda Dillon, John C. Reilly, Bill Macy, and of course Tom... the cast was outstanding, and some gave possibly their best performances of their careers (Macy , Dillon, and Cruise come to mind).In a few words, the film, for those who have gotten this far, and still have no clue, is about 10 people whose lives intertwine at times, through the course of one day and night, in Southern California. These include a police officer, a self help guru, a game show host and their families. It may not sound like much, and I will describe nothing further, but rent this film, grab a chair, unplug the phone, send the spouse and the kids to Chuckee Cheese, and prepare for a film which will stay with you for many days, weeks and years to come.11 out of 10 -- need I say more?</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-05-19</date>
		<username>r-fischer</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Intelligent, stimulating film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is one of the best films to come out of the 90s, and Paul Thomas Anderson did a fantastic job with it. Albeit, the movie is not perfect, but considering Anderson wasn't even 30 when he made it, I foresee great things in the future for him. The different story lines, or as it should be more aptly named, character lines, were all intriguing and believable. It could have been more interesting if they had been a little more interconnected, but subtlety was the aim here, and it does work.This movie is engaging if you let it be, in that it requires some thinking on the part of the viewer in order to fully appreciate its value. This is a character study, but not in a traditional sense. I do not want to give away too much if you have not seen the movie, so I will limit my comments to merely that Magnolia is a very emotionally driven film.The directing is superb, although I think Paul Thomas Anderson could have done a bit better job of condensing some of the voice-overs towards the end--not because they were boring, but because he did such a good job of "showing" us things rather than just "telling" us for most of the film. It was almost like he got a bit lazy. Nevertheless, it remains very powerful, and the acting is absolutely great across the board. Tom Cruise is very good in it, but I feel the rest of the cast got shorthanded from all the attention Cruise received. Not to take anything away from his performance, but truly the entire ensemble did great, from frantic Cruise to subtle William H. Macy. Philip Seymour Hoffman and John C. Reilly also gave very memorable performances.All in all, some viewers simply will not like this film; its unique style, direction, storyline (or lack thereof in some eyes), parallel character development, and brief touches of surrealism will just not sit well with some. But I urge all who have not seen it to chance three hours and find out if you are perhaps not one of these people, because if you do enjoy Magnolia, it is well worth it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-05-14</date>
		<username>EyeDunno</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>If at first you don't understand it...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>...Try, try again. First of all, I noticed plenty of "Boogie Nights" lovers who generally panned "magnolia." I never saw "Boogie Nights," so I didn't have any expectations. I watched "magnolia" at the wrong moment (when I had pulled a 12-hour workday), so I decided to try watching when I had plenty of rest. It's a fascinating movie, and I became more intrigued the more times I viewed it. I thought at first that the characters at some stage would intersect directly. Although that didn't happen, I still enjoyed the plots and subplots. With several climaxes throughout, the film is a roller-coaster of emotions. It's very, very dark, tackling such things as drug abuse, terminal illness, molestation and other dramatic situations. But this seems to happen in many people's lives. Somewhere I read a comment saying that the movie should have had a brighter ending, some kind of hopeful conclusion. I think too many movies rely on the same hackneyed ending that "magnolia" avoided. Maybe PTA realized that such emotional issues in many cases can't expect a rosy ending. And as to the role of Frank T.J. Mackey (Tom Cruise) and Claudia Wilson Gator (Melora Walters), examine their characters. They are all victims in one way or another. Maybe Mackey has resorted to sexual conquering as his drug to hide the pain of abandonment by a father, forcing him to helplessly watch his mother die. Claudia resorts to drug use and sex to dampen her trauma of being molested by her father. They both are traumatized children, with the pain being inflicted by their fathers.Meanwhile three other children, Quiz Kid Donnie Smith (William H. Macy), Dixon (Emmanuel Johnson) and Stanley Spector (Jeremy Blackman) are riding that same path to their own destruction: Donnie Smith still has not grown up; Stanley Spector is being used by his father (I'm sure by name-dropping so that he can get a part in a movie), and Dixon has already witnessed at least one murder by his own father, "The Worm."Okay, so Linda Partridge (Julianne Moore) curses A LOT. She's a mental case, taking drugs to calm her own emotions. These things happen in real life all the time. A movie finally has taken a realistic (except the frogs, perhaps) look at those relationships. And there are bright spots. I never would have believed that Frank Mackey would actually go to help Linda Partridge...and Rose Gator and Officer Jim Kurring reach out to Claudia. So, okay, I love the movie. Watch it when you're open-minded and not sleepy!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-05-06</date>
		<username>panicwatcher (panicflyer@altavista.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Five scripts shuffled into one movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this movie yesterday, and I still don't know if I liked it. It is a three hour movie that is so tightly paced that the time goes by very quickly. It feels like someone took five movie scripts and shuffled the pages together into one script. It is a struggle to follow and make sense out of each plot line because the movie cuts between each plot line with the pace and music of an MTV video. At some point, you give up and just let the scenes wash over you faster than you can comprehend. On one hand viewing the movie is an amazing experience with great scenes and great actors. On the other hand, the plots do not really tie together and it does not have a conclusion or make any sense. The ending is particularly goofy and pointless. I would recommend this movie in spite of its flaws because it is so different from any other movie you are going to see and if you don't try to make sense out of it, it is very entertaining.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-04-05</date>
		<username>atuin31317 (atuin@chris.keme.co.uk)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Amazing film from hugely talented writer/director p.t anderson</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a film which seems to have spawned two groups of viewers, those who get it and those who don't. It is understandable P.T Anderson's follow up to the acclaimed Boogie Nights is a 3 + hour epic study of human emotion. Anderson has once again enlisted the services of his favourite group of actors (the excellent Reilly, Hoffman, Macy, Hall, Moore) with the much talked about addition of Tom Cruise as sex guru Frank TJ Mackay. The story takes place completly in L.A over the course of 1 long day. Essentially this could be considered Short Cuts 2 and Anderson produces flawless performances from his very talented cast. Even smaller roles are superbly acted and Cruise's turn as Mackay defies all expectations, frequently delievering quotable one liners (i'm quietly judging you). Anderson directs with great skill and like other budding directors (David O Russel, Guy Richie) really shows visual flair (the zooming cancer sequence). This film is extraordianly moving and deals with emotions we all face, depression, loss, desperation. Some have said this film is too depressing and hollow but that is life sometimes, and if this film is 'too depressing' guess what, that is what life is like sometimes. Anderson (29) shows confidence and skill switching between storylines. How many other directors would be brave enough to show his entire cast suddenly break out in song? but the gambit works and feels very appropriate for that moment in the film (however Mann's 'Save Me' would have been a better choice for this scene) This is a film that really requires repeat viewings to fully appreciate as i found the switching between charcters to be a little off putting at first. This is a film of few faults but Anderson does occasionally loose focus of the story at times. Every charcter is so well observed and acted and you can really empathise with many. In short this is frankly an unmissable film and is perhaps one of the greatest of the last decade. Based on this Anderson is destined for great things.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-04-01</date>
		<username>baby_floyd</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Pretty Darn Good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What else is a comment board but for the self-expression of those who enjoy "the sound of their own voice"? So here's my two cents...- The F-word is used so much because that's the way people talk, especially when they're in high-stress situations.- The script is pretty good but the movie is great because of the wonderful acting and the direction they received.- There was at least one comparison to American Beauty in all these comments, and I found myself almost thinking the same thing after viewing Magnolia for the first time. However, Magnolia still has a more big-budget feel than AB does despite the fact that AB has more "big name" actors (Tom Cruise notwithstanding). The subtlety in the AB script is recalled in the exquisite acting of Reilly (the cop), Hoffman (the nurse), Hall (the game show host) and Walters (the addict). I think what ties the two films is that the characters in both films could be considered stereotypical, until you look closer. (Guess which movie I prefer.)***SPOILER?***- The controversial singing scene was one of the most powerful, emotional scenes I've ever seen.... That and Claudia's parting smile made me sob aloud.</fullReview>
