	<review>
		<date>2002-05-12</date>
		<username>Ilker Catak (ethanvirus@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Only the smart ones will get the irony</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** Director P.T. Anderson's `MAGNOLIA' is the study of nine lifes in one day in San Fernando Valley, California. Brief: these nine stories are somehow connected and every figure seems to have one heavy character flaw or at least is in pain and trouble. The interconnected characters are shown in a way that reminds us of Robert Altman's `Short Cuts' where the stories come up teaser-like too.One of these stories is the one of Donnie Smith, played by William H. Macy. First Donnie's famous childhood is presented, which is remarkable because of a record he set up in a game show in 1968, as a child prodigy. The great amount of money he won at that time helped him with financing his life till now. The fact that he never had to work for his needs made him grow up to be a pathetic loser, who has abundant wants but doesn't know what to do when broke. As we can imagine, now Donnie has still wants, but no more money. He is in love with a bartender, wearing braces and in order to impress him, Donnie things he needs oral surgery too. (This is only one of tons of dreams floating around his head - how fitting it is, then, that singer Gabrielles' pop song `Dreams' recurs troughout the movie as his personal anthem.) But when he is fired from the company, that lets him work there only because of the atvertisement Donnie's famous name (`Donnie the Quiz Kid') provides, he decides to break into the office of his former boss.He steals the necessary money, leaves the company by getting into his car and suddenly realizes his ridiculous behaviour. We hear him saying "What am I doing?", before he decides to break another time into the office, but this time with the intention to put the stolen money back.Right at the moment when Donnie climbs up the ladder that leads into the office, it starts to rain. It rains not just water, as we are used to it, but it is a pour of bullfrogs. Millions of frogs start to fall from the sky, so that it is impossible for Donnie to escape. When he realizes the unusual phenomenon, he looks up into the sky (we see him look into the camera which is in a bird perspective). Then we are put into the perspective of Donnie's eyes and see a frog falling on us. When the frog reaches Donnie / us, the camera changes again to the bird perspective and we see Donnie seriously falling on the asphalt in a way that all of his (front) teeth break. There is a camera close up on his mouth and the realism is not only created by the blood, but also by the sound of the breaking teeth. This sound is stressed by the nonexistence of the backround music, which usually accompanies the scenes throughout the film. As already said, we see his face in a camera close up laying on the pavement. And it is the directors' scornfulness, that an ugly frog falls in between the camera and the face. While Donnie lays miserably on the ground - miserable as his whole life actually is - a police officer (another character out of the nine lifes) drags him out of the fatal rain. It seems to be great irony, that of all, especially his teeth are lost.It probably does not have to be discussed that Anderson refers to the bible with the fall of frogs. On a closer look we can see that there are a lot of hints guiding us to Exodus 8:2. For example, in one scene there is a suicide of a young man. The date of this incident is March 23rd, which is the 82nd day of the year. However, unlike the bible, Anderson's plague of frogs seems to have a catharsis-like effect on his people. Not only on Donnie Smith, but also on all the other characters.`Magnolia' may very well be a film that confuses more people than it strikes with admiration. Many people will probably have difficulties with accepting the form of narrative logic, which is so different from usual films they have got used to. Another difficulty is to find a movie that summarizes American society better than this piece of art. To me, it could even be compared with Sam Mendes' `American Beauty', not only because of its sharpness, but also because of the hidden irony. Though its length of 3 hours, I think `Magnolia' is a must see for people looking for a young, passionate and at the same time courageous director, that seems to ignore all possible critics, who do not want to accept these films, where logic has to be left at the door.9.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-28</date>
		<username>Andrew (a_drew321@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>So now then...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>To encapsulate a movie like MAGNOLIA for someone who hasn't seen it is...well...difficult. A film this daring and uncompromising in vision will be hated by some, loved by others. As for me, I loved it.It seems that director/writer Paul Thomas Anderson wasn't content with making a movie about just anything, so he made a movie about everything, as big as life itself. The characters are so real that we may feel we have met them before; their struggles and doubts are the same struggles and doubts as the human race. Their problems are, to them, huge and insurmountable. In the end, however, their problems are seen as small in the face of something so much bigger, so much more amazing.I'm not going to say any more, because half of the fun in watching this movie is being amazed by the unexpected. This is my all-time favorite movie. I'll never forget the first time I saw it.If you're about to watch Magnolia for the first time, I envy you the experience you are about to have.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-18</date>
		<username>Howard Kleinman (Howard.Kleinman@Oberlin.edu)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>But it did happen...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is just a wholly original and engrossing film that gets better with additional viewings. Paul Thomas Anderson has taken a page from Robert Altman and managed to somehow surpass the master of the large cast film with the memorability of the characters and the quality of their dialogue. It's difficult to describe exactly what it is about this film that makes me view it so frequently. I think a big part of the success of the film is its sensitivity to human frailty and seems to uncynically believe that what people truly need in life is just a little bit of compassion, understanding and someone to love. It sounds trite, but Anderson pulls it off incredibly well. Of course, the movie wasn't just touching thematically, it was filled with fantastic sequences, from the opening narration sequence displaying the bizarre "coincidences" of history to Tom Cruise's over the top male power seminar. Speaking of Tom Cruise, this is easily my favorite performance by him in any film and the other actors aren't slouches either. Just look at the cast: Julianne Moore, Jason Robards, Philip Seymour Hoffman, John C. Reilly, William H. Macy, Ricky Jay, Tom Cruise, Philip Baker Hall. All of these performances are well nuanced, funny and heartfelt. Magnolia is a movie that is just indescribably great for me. I own the DVD and have seen it around ten times, introducing as many friends to it as I can at any given time. When I look back at the 1990s in ten years, I imagine this will be near the top of my list of favorite films from that decade.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-03-01</date>
		<username>wicket177</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Hard to describe</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have seen this movie three times. I own it on DVD. I recommend it to people. But I have no idea if I like it or not. Isn't that weird? I am so caught in the middle that it makes it impossible for me to decide. There are a few factors that swing me both ways:The editing - Most people think that Magnolia needed to visit an editing room once or twice (at least), but I personally kind of like the un-cut style it has. It's very different, and it makes the movie quite long, but at least it's original.The length - 3 hours? It's long... but I think that in order to have the plot that it has, and the depth that it has, it needs an extra hour to fit everything. It does a pretty good job of using up the time it takes.The plot - I'm not usually the quickest person when it comes to following screwed up plots (although The Usual Suspects is one of my favorite movies) so this one took me a few viewings to understand. However, I think that finding the way people connect to each other and the hidden influences they have on each other makes the movie more fun than annoying.Overall I would have to give the movie an 8. The acting was excellent. William H. Macy is so... pathetic! And Tom and Julian are so beautifully... sadly... amazing. I don't know how many people will be able to stand the plot, length, and editing, but if you are able to, I highly suggest this movie. It will really make you think about people in your life and unresolved issues between you.********8 Frogs. Err... stars********</fullReview>

		<username>MovieMax416</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Nothing short of astonishing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" is definately one of the three best movies I've ever seen (outside of "The Godfather" and "Schindler's List"). There is so much I can say about it. When I first saw it, I didn't pay much attention. I saw it again a few months ago, and within a week, I had bought the DVD and seen it three more times.The direction is flawless. In fact, everything in this movie seems to be flawless. There is not a single word that could be cut without altering the movie as a whole. From the opening montage, set to Aimee Mann's haunting lyrics of "One" all the way through Julianne Moore's tantrum at the pharmacy, Jason Robards' deathbed regret speech, William H. Macy's breakdown at the bar, and Tom Cruise reduced to rage-filled tears at the bedside of a man he hates, "Magnolia" had me captivated.Yes, it is 188 minutes, but people please!! A baseball game is about that long, and they aren't boring. If you pay attention to the characters instead of length, this movie will have a serious impact on you.Of all the amazing performances here (just about every role was perfect), the two particular standouts for me were William H. Macy and Jason Robards. When you get a glimpse of a character's whole life through a few small gestures, you know you're watching a genius at work. Such was the case while I watched Quiz Kid Donnie Smith make a fool of himself in front of a bartender who he thinks he's in love with. And when Jason Robards sruggles to remember his son's name, it almost brought tears to my eyes. You can tell that so deeply regrets his past decisions that he'll do anything to feel loved again.This is the kind of movie that must be seen. Some people may think that "Magnolia" is a world of crazies and exaggerations. I beg to differ. These are normal people. Not many people can honestly say they've never made a bad decision. Paul Thomas Anderson is just showing the world as it is, tragic as it may be.10/10 (If I could rate any higher, I would!! This is not just a movie, it is a work of art)</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-28</date>
		<username>phswaddle (p.h.swaddle@dundee.ac.uk)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>the most positive review i could write.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is, without doubt, my favourite film. I first saw it on video about a year ago and I was blown away. Paul Thomas Anderson is an incredible writer, boogie nights is evidence of that, but from the first five minutes of the movie with its quirky prologues and the "one is the loneliest number" introduction (as you are introduced to all the characters over Aimee Mann's phenomenal soundtrack) I was hooked. I'm a fan of the writer Douglas Coupland and this film had a lot of similarities to his character and plot structures. A film where Tom Cruise is billed as a supporting actor to a perfectly tight cast is one in a million. He is not allowed to go beyond the boundaries of his character and Anderson never 'hollywoodises' his films purely for the benefit of finance or actors. Philip Seymour Hoffman is one of the best actors around today, (look at Almost Famous where he steals the show) and in this film he is again superb; along with Moore - "SHAME ON YOU!" brilliant! - and Macy. Anderson's excellent use of young versus old, relationships, spirituality and the impact of the visual image is sublimely used again in Magnolia. The attention to detail and to soundtrack is perfect. My only criticisms would be the amount of swearing - but that only creates a greater suspension of disbelief - and that it is perhaps too long, but this only provides more space for Anderson to work his magic. It is a film I could watch again and again and never tire of. It also has the most wonderfully tied together ending of anything I have watched. Ten out of ten.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-11-20</date>
		<username>Suresh Kumar (skumar@cyberdude.com)</username>

		<shortDescription>A rare gem..</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At first i was astounded at the breadth of opinions of this movie. Never have i known a movie to have such polarised views. But the more i think about it, the more it seems to make sense.This movie is all about heart, its about being in love, to be loved, about greed, emotion, pain, joy, respect, heartache, jealousy, suffering, redemption, and lastly hope.Anyone that has the humility and courage to truly look at their own lives, and the lives of those around them, their friends, their neighbours, their family, and the people they meet in their everyday lives, will have been able draw something personal from this movie.The storyline, superbly dense, weaves through the lives of nine characters, who are ultimately linked. Andersons's characters at times overly dysfunctional and psychotic, maybe its an insight as to where society is or is heading, at the least its a warning to all of us.The positive and negative reactions to this movie, is as much a reflection of the people and the world we live in, and ultimately tells us more about ourselves.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-10-23</date>
		<username>CAPTWillard</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>ONE OF THE BEST FILMS OF THE 90'S</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In a strong 1999 year, Magnolia stood at the top with movies Being John Malkovich and American Beauty. Like Being John Malkovich, it was virtually ignored by the Academy Awards except for a best supporting actor nomination for Tom Cruise. This is film blasphemy considering how well made and engrossing Magnolia is. Best picture and director nominations should have been automatic, as well as a supporting actress nomination for Moore. Sadly, none of these things happened and I have lost a lot of my faith in the Academy (even more so now that Gladiator has won best picture of 2000). Hopefully people didn't miss this movie because of the lack of awards, but if you did, I suggest checking this title out. Although that's not to say it's for everyone. If you are one of those ignorant fools that believe the Matrix and American Pie are all time great movies I suggest you check out Exit Wounds or something like that. That being said you also have to be in the mood to sit and watch for three hours. For me, and many others, the three hours flew by, but for some people with ADD, the length might be a problem. This movie was made on a $30 million budget, unbelievable when you consider the wealth of talent in the actors and expensive looking stage designs. When it's all said and done I believe this will go down in history as a sleeper classic that people will come to appreciate in the years to come.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-26</date>
		<username>Claus Krebs (ckrebs@geocities.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A fundamental film about the fundamental things</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(Warning: this comment contains spoilers)It has been a good many months now since I saw this movie, a circumstance that I find interesting after having read other user's comments, which often mention aspects of the plot that I had forgotten. Time tends to extract the details from our memory, and to leave behind only the fundamentals. And the fundamental aspects of this movie that I distinctly remember, and which --in my opinion-- make it such a valuable movie, are:It is deeply moving. This is a rare quality nowadays, when movies are so filled with visual effects and noise, in a desperate effort to thrill and catch the viewer's attention, that they are achieving quite the opposite effect: the audience gets number every day. 'Magnolia' is everything about humans and humanity, and precisely this is what makes it so interesting. I remember sitting and watching it without even breathing, as if I had been in a trance. I did not 'notice' the three hours at all!It has wonderful music. Apart from the songs, I liked the constant background music very much. It helped building up a wall of tension, which kept growing and growing during the entire movie, parallel with the development of the character's conflicts -- until it reaches a point when heaven falls down in the form of frogs.It is one of the most religious films ever. There may be some who like this aspect, and some who don't; as may be some who see the movie in this way, and some who don't. But I think that religion is everywhere in this movie, in every effort of the characters to overcome their worries and find true love (they are ALL in search of it, not just William H. Macey, who says so aloud), and of course in the symbolic 'frog rain'. Religion isn't really about intolerance and prejudice: it has to do with the search for happiness, the urge for transcendency -- and, yes, with morality, which in the end is nothing more than choosing 'good' over 'bad'. Why, if not for moral reasons, would Julianne Moore's character cry over the fact that she had 'had other men's c***s in my mouth'? After finding the love she had been searching for with whom she less expected --her own husband-- she repented for her past actions. And since such past actions obviously had been pleasurable, the one reason for repenting was a spiritual comparison between sheer sexual pleasure and the deeper joy of true love. I found this moral framework in Anderson's 'Boogie Nights', too: near the end, a title appears, which read something like 'the final step on the long way down' (I don't remember the exact wording anymore). But this little hint clearly revealed that Anderson is, indeed, very aware of what is 'up' and what is 'down'. Many people might say that there is no objective 'good' and 'bad', but I think that, if one sits down quietly (hard nowadays) and looks down to the bottom of one's soul, the difference will become evident -- and (maybe surprisingly to some) such conclusions will not differ that much from one person to another. For me, 'Magnolia' is in its entirety about a soul-search of this kind.It is a desperate movie. This is the one word that comes to my mind when trying to describe the film: 'desperate'. Everybody is drowning in remorse, in guilt, in fear, in the unbearable desire of breaking loose from pain and finding peace of mind. I felt like being on a ship that is fighting all the way through a thunderstorm, trying to arrive at a sunny, warm and quiet harbour (again a religious metaphor?). Maybe this is why it rains so much all the time.It has an encouraging ending. Unlike what some viewers think, this movie has a very clear ending. It doesn't just unexpectedly come to a halt. I experienced it like this: after the tension of the plot has raised to an almost unbearable point, the frogs start falling out of the sky. For me, this represented the turning point, the purging punishment for everybody's sins, after which one can start anew. The slowly developing smile on Claudia's face (the last scene) is nothing but a sign of hope. After all, if it wasn't for hope, would the world still be worth living in, with all of its troubles?I sincerely wish to congratulate and thank Mr. Anderson for bringing out such an excellent film. It touched my very soul.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-16</date>
		<username>Al Rogerson (Neo0682@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A film that everyone alive should see.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is a real film. And I mean that in the most literal sense. Every movement of every character, every word uttered, and every situation in this movie is truly believable. You and I have been through the emotions that are in this film, and Paul Thomas Anderson knows it.Firstly, this is ensemble acting to drool over. There is not one bad performance in this film. I'm an avid 'Usual Suspects' fan, and not since that movie have the cast impressed me as much as they do here.Julianne Moore is outstanding as the rich, deceiptful wife at the end of her teather, rattled with guilt. William H. Macy gives a heartfelt performance too as a boy genius with nothing but his fading reputation and a whole lotta love to offer. Jason Robards (RIP) is superb too. I've never seen a dying man played with such bitterness and regret, it was truly an eye opener to see such an honest portrayal. John C. Reilly boosts his growing reputation by outdoing his turn in 'Boogie Nights' and showing his softer side to heartwrenching effect. But my two heroes in this movie are, inevitably, Philip Seymour Hoffman and Tom Cruise. Hoffman is rapidly becoming my favourite 'natural' actor of these last few years. His performance here is so subtle, yet so capturing. Just watch the phone conversation sequence, you'll see what I mean. It's true what they say too, this is Cruise's finest EVER performance. At first I considered his character to be a little simple. A sexist, arrogant creator of 'Seduce And Destroy', men's guide to 'trapping' women. However, what Anderson does best in this movie is unravels each character's past both gradually, and painfully. And Cruise's narcissistic character is no exception. I'll give you one line to look out for; "I'm quietly judging you." At that point, you'll realise that Cruise has used the barnstorming dialogue supplied to his character to it's absolute full effect.Overall then, from beginning to end this movie will touch you, make you laugh, make you cry, make you smile with glee, make you drool at the sheer talent that's on screen. But most of all, this movie will make you want to become a writer. Just so that you can write about people's lives with as much empathy as Anderson does.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-07-02</date>
		<username>Brian Goulbourn (fastasu@pacbell.net)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Monument in Film Originality</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** A bold, solid, heart-wrenching film from writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson is loaded with gritty dialogue, strong language and some emotional moments. The characters, if you get involved with them throughout the course of the movie, will really prove that, "Hey, this is like real life." There's lonely LAPD Officer Jim Kurring, dying TV mogul Earl Partridge, Earl's trophy wife Linda Partridge, Earl's estranged, masculinity-motivational speaker/infomercial host Frank T.J. Mackey, Earl's heavenly home-care nurse Phil Parma, TV game show host/cancer victim Jimmy Gator(who molested his daughter 10 years ago), Jimmy's caring wife Rose Gator, their estranged daughter; a coke-addicted, high-strung woman named Claudia Wilson Gator, Quiz Kid Stanley Spector:who's forced to perform on the game show "What Do Kids Know?" so his father Rick, a failed actor, can keep? steal! his money, and 1968's former Quiz Kid Donnie Smith, a loser who's about to be fired from his appliance-salesman job at Solomon Solomon Electronics and who's yearning for the love of a braces-wearing, gay bartender named Brad against older bar patron Thurston Howell. So many characters, so little space to write.The movie starts off with coincidence oddities, then spins around the main characters' lives to the sound of Aimee Mann's "One." The movie goes on, where Jim meets Claudia and asks her for a date, where Linda drugs herself to near-death, where Phil calls Frank to reconcile with Earl, where Stanley wets his pants on the show and refuses to keep playing, where Jimmy has a stroke on the show, and where Donnie and Thurston battle word-wits over drinks at the bar. The way every character has to deal with their pasts is really touching and emotionally fragile.If you're reading this and you haven't seen "Magnolia" yet, this could be a SPOILER...but I digress...after the characters are pushed to their limits and nerve endings, the climax arises. It's the middle of the night/early morning on Magnolia Boulevard in the San Fernando Valley, California. The rain has cleared. As Jim Kurring drives down Magnolia after his failed date with Claudia, he U-turns after seeing Donnie Smith climb a telephone pole to steal money from his work. As he turns, a large green frog SLAMS on the windshield and another on the hood. Scared s***less, he looks up and around, only to find more and more frogs falling from the sky. Pretty soon all nine main characters are met with the frog rain. In this time, Rose Gator crashes her car, which happened to be near Claudia's apartment:where she seeks shelter; Jimmy Gator's suicide attempt is thwarted when a frog falls through the skylight and sets the gun off at the TV, causing a fire (assumed that Jimmy burns to death); Donnie Smith falls off the telephone pole, which causes him to fall and bust his teeth; and Earl Partridge finally dies, Frank at his side.So Now Then"Magnolia" is a great, great, great movie and sorely overlooked by the Oscar Academy. The film as I said is a monument in cinema creativity and originality because no other film has frogs falling from the sky, which is truly a grand moment in the film's climax. I hope that after you see this movie you feel the way I did--I left thinking about how screwed up my life is too, and maybe you can find an escape from what harm might come, like to the characters in "Magnolia." The best film of all time is what suits "Magnolia" the best. **** out of 4.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-01-13</date>
		<username>Coolio Chicken</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Respect this film!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is possibly the best film of 2000! At first I was put off by the running time, but it goes by in a flash. The film starts with a series of 'coincidental' events, which is followed by a quick look at all the characters. Then the film starts properly, where we are plunged into 6 stories set across L.A in one day. First there is the story of TJ Mackey, a sex therepist who hasn't spoken to his father for 15 years. His father is on his deathbed, trying to find his son to say a few last words to him. His wife, (who at first married him for money) is realising that she now loves him, but is feeding him the morphine, that while kepping the pain low, is killing him quicker. There is a cop who starts going out with a coke addict, whose father is the host of a TV gameshow called what do kids know? On his show, there is a child genius who is being bullied into doing the show by his father, and there is the man who was a child genius on the show 30 years before. These all are connected, by the ending which brings L.A to a halt, and all the characters together. There is a central theme in this movie, and it is about how children can be ruined later on in life, by what their parents do to them as children. As a film, the acting is flawless, the camerawork superlative, and the writing better than anything else last year (except American Beauty). Well worth watching. Again, and again, and again...</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-01-05</date>
		<username>Dylan Biles (alvin-tostig@email.msn.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Blooming of a Great Director</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia", Paul Thomas Anderson's third film is by far his most mature and most intimate film. After the out-of-nowhere success of "Boogie Nights", this is a well scripted, INCREDIBLY acted film about the relationships between fathers and sons, husbands and wives, men and women, stranger to stranger, and a society that tells us that none of them are important anymore.In an interview, Anderson once said that "Magnolia" was one of the first times that he just made himself sit down, and write, and when he wrote, he wrote without concern of boundaries or limitations. It serves the script well. The disjunct and highly kinetic film allows for the moments of clarity and stillness to be more acutely emphasized. The points that he makes are subtle, about family, television, religion, etc. But through their subtleness they are made very powerful.In the best ensemble cast in years, it is hard to pick the stand outs. Tom Cruise has gotten quite a bit of well-deserved attention for his role as a male infomercial guru. William H. Macy comes through again in another staggering character, something this has become par for the course. Jason Robard's portrayal of a dying man (fortuitous, considering it was his last film role) is breathtakingly piercing. But perhaps the most important role of all is the role of a hospice nurse, played by Phillip Seymour Hoffman. His scenes radiate with an intensity that lends absolute credence to the scenes that will play out later in the film (Watch how Anderson frames him in the background of scenes in which other people are playing, almost as a greek chorus, a technique also used by Anderson with Hoffman in "Boogie Nights").In the end, Anderson has succeeded in making a dramatic, touching, strange and wonderful film. His vision is clearly established on the screen, and without saying it, his point is made. Anderson is on the verge of becoming one of America's most important filmmakers, but, even if his career should fizzle out from this point on, he has managed to make at least one important film. "Magnolia" is a testament to what film can be, if only allowed.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-01-04</date>
		<username>orpheus-6</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Close to overall perfection.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie truly amazes me the more often I watch it. Seldomly have I discovered more unique camera and editing styles combined with classic suspense. Magnolia has a flow to it which makes the viewer really enter the movie and move and breathe in it. After three hours, a time which usually seems incredibly long for a movie, the viewer just screams: "How can this be over already? There´s still so much to tell!" From beginning to end the camera style underlines the story. As soon as we get deeper into the characters and their problems, we move to extreme close ups of their faces during monologues/dialogues, so close that, with every movement, the faces move out of sharpness. What in other movies might have been a technical mistake is here an element of a very unique filming style. Throughout Magnolia, there seldomly is a moment without music. Music, which always fits perfectly into the scene. And as the stories of the different characters begin to overlay and the suspense increases, we even hear two pieces of music and score at once. Anderson proves in Master-Hitchcock-style, that Suspense does not necessarily require shoot-outs and corpses. Simple human stories are thrilling enough, everything is a matter of putting it in scene. And as the thrilling storylines all gather together to one high-voltage peak, the story provides us with the most strange, surprising, maybe even disturbing plot-twists I´ve ever seen. Also outstanding are the acting abilities of the cast. Every role is as perfectly played as it is perfectly casted. I think I´ll have to stop writing now. Now that I´ve written so much about this masterpiece, I think I´m watching a certain video for the next three hours...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>ickyptang</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>This film is just astounding</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" is one of those films that will hopefully be appreciated fully at some point in time, because now is certainly not good enough. Definitely the best film of 1999, "Magnolia" is just one of the best films ever made. It is everything that a movie can be and should be. It follows the rules and makes some of it's own, and it is just marvelous. Completely original, yet familiar at the same time, the story and plot could be found anywhere. It follows ordinary people, who live extraordinary lives without even knowing it. Which can be said of anyone. Life is so vast and strange that it is hard to see what is truly important. But "Magnolia" writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson seems to know. The stories all have something for everyone, something that is funny, sad, cool, enlightening, whatever it may be. As a film-maker, his style is also amazing. His pacing is perfect, taking a whopping three hours and making it feel like one. The movie flows beautifully and stays consistently entertaining. In some ways there are no words to describe how wonderful this movie is, it has to be experienced. Hopefully one day it can receive fully the attention it deserves, and become one of the defining films of the decade, if not ever. A true masterpiece.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>interesting but flawed movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie had a lot of great acting and character development but I still did not enjoy it. For one thing it dragged on too long. Also the characters were not portrayed with any subtlety. The scenes where Julianne Moore screamed at the pharmacist and where Claudia yelled at her father to get out of her apartment were particularly bad. I had difficulty feeling Moore's love for her husband because she was constantly screaming obscenities at people. I have no problem at all with bad language but in this film, everyone used it, every other word. It got to be a bit silly actually, especially Moore's scene with the lawyer. I was overloaded by all the obnoxious behavior by all the characters, especially Tom Cruise's character (although Cruise did a great acting job).Also I lost track of a number of the plot lines. Who stole the drugs? Who killed the body in the closet? What happened to the rapping kid? At the end I didn't know and didn't care, I was just glad it was over.As for the frogs.. They didn't work for me at all. That was the last straw for me. The frogs seemed like too much of a contrivance. I groaned as soon as I realized they were a reference to Exodus.I stayed the full three hours because I thought "it would all make sense in the end", but it didn't..</fullReview>

		<username>ike-21 (diacconi@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>As Clear As Quantum Physics</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Unpredictable... Yes! Understandable... As clear as quantum physics.How could you not love a movie that has the greatest, most unpredictable scene of all time?The answer: Because this movie was a "long, drawn-out, plotless, no-direction-in-sight" movie.Why critics from newspapers, magazines, and TV glorify movies that really don't entertain the audience is beyond me!I was fortunate to view "Magnolia" in a crowded theatre. Practically everyone there had the same impression halfway through this film -- "Where is this movie going?" And when the credits started rolling up at the end of the last drawn-out scene, the audience was looking around to the other victims whispering in confusion, "Did I miss something?"The audience, then, broke out into a cheer -- praising that the movie was finally over. This is not an exaggeration by any means. At that point, I finally felt compensated that I wasn't the only one in that theatre that felt I just wasted these last three hours of my life.For viewers who love Tom Cruise, this movie will leave you having second thoughts about his morals and why he would choose such a sexist, foul-mouthed role."Magnolia" contains enough up-close-and-personal drug scenes that'll leave you scratching your nose. And enough foul language that makes Eddie Murphy's standup routines seem like a Sunday sermon.There are some redeeming qualities to this movie, but there's only a few. The opening story depicting urban legends was interesting; and of course, the misrepresented biblical reference was surprising. I couldn't help think of an old episode of 'WKRP in Cincinnati'.By all means, don't take younger viewers to this movie. I really believe it's a horrible outlook on life, and nobody should expose sponge-like brains to this mayhem. This movie is a total disappointment and leaves you wondering if you missed the plot. I guess the only intriguing aspect of this movie was I couldn't wait to get home and look up Exodus 8:2.</fullReview>

		<date>2000-01-17</date>
		<username>MadBadMovieman</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Flying Frogs meet Boogie Nights with a Thud.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia. Interesting name but somehow everyone we've talked to has never figured out what the name had to do with the movie. Paul T. Anderson did such an outstanding job with Boogie Nights but it appears he didn't want to use any new methods, pacing, editing, cinematography, etc on Magnolia. Majority of the same cast doesn't guarantee you anything. Each story was worth telling but not quite this way.We had high expectations and most of the Cast did an excellent job on an individual basis. Julianne went over the top as the pissed off, scared, exhausted, foul mouthed recently loving wife. Tom Cruise especially was great and stands out above all. The Male nurse was excellent in in empathy and desire to help and stay with his patient to the very end. John Reilly was very good too.People started to really lose interest when all characters in all situations &amp; conditions started to sing the same song. There was an audible sigh of relief in the crowd when the singing was over. The scene had a message but it went too far and lost most of us for totally lack of credibility.The rain of frogs was believable at first because this has really happened and the intro to the movie set you up for this kind of coincidental event. It just went too far, too wide and too long. Especially since there was only a rain storm early that night. No nearby tornado, hurricane, cyclone or other noted weather event could be tied to where all the frogs came from. Bizarre effect but like some of the acting, too much.Paul, Now P.T., Anderson needs to move on beyond the techniques in Boogie Nights. He has the talent to draw so much talent from his Cast and create multiple events in real time but this was too much in too little real time. Making the movie longer is not the answer either. After 2 hrs 45 minutes half of the audience that was left said- "That's it? We waited for this?" The other half said- "Thank God it's over!" We were just disappointed.In the case of Magnolia, more is not less. More was just more. I hope his next movie is not Boogie Nights meets the Game Show Flying Frogs at just under 3 hours. We won't bother.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-01-14</date>
		<username>nocabout</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Film was over-rated and painful to watch</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I respect Anderson's work. I do not, however, think it is genius. In fact, it seems more acutely to me...angst. In some cases it is well-developed angst in others it is tedious, drawn-out, unsubstantiated and unbelievable angst. I believe Anderson's strong suit is depicting suffering, but the characters are so bizarre and off the wall, I found it difficult to sympathize with them at all. I enjoyed Cruise's performance and Ramsey's performance. The film was too long and the ending left much to be desired. I imagine the frogs were Anderson's nod to Magical Realism. I wish he hadn't.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-01-11</date>
		<username>fairchildm</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Anderson has created a masterpiece that surpasses the field</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The method of the rapid cut/dialogue film has been used excessively since the early Tarintino successes. Magnolia is an example of that genre at its best. The method used is similar to mixing the sense of movement used in Three Kings with the messaging attempts of American Beauty, but here the product is not simply additive. Where American Beauty suggests, Magnolia boldly declares in some of the best writing that I have ever experienced, if not the best. The cuts are so well interwoven that every scene is fresh and inviting. Julianne Moore and Tom Cruise are breath taking, while the rest of the cast combines very enjoyable acting with the well supplied dialogue. Oscars are well deserved for Cruise and Moore, and are a must for Anderson's screenplay. Easily the best movie of the year, it makes my second choice, American Beauty, seem sophomoric.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2000-01-10</date>
		<username>CLAW-6</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Ambitious and lazy all at once; definitely a step backwards</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While I can't say I either loved or hated Magnolia, I certainly appreciated it. The film occasionally transcended its mundane theme and thin characters, hitting its stride in a scene or two. However, Anderson, not displaying the wonderful directorial maturity he used to great result in BOOGIE NIGHTS, moves once too often to the gimmick bag, mostly notably at the climax, where obfuscation and imagery serve as poor substitutes for genuine substance.The reason? Magnolia is a lazy film, and a bit cowardly, as Anderson avoids the rigors of crafting a full story from start to finish, choosing instead to write six or so short films, stringing them together with a common theme. No matter what any critic may say, these stories do NOT intertwine in any significant manner...or at least, any more than ANY stories with similar themes do. Unfortunately, this theme, which bares an unfair burden in this film, is the fairly mundane, "We may be done with the past, but the past isn't done with us." Well...yes, okay, but stating a theme isn't enough. We need to FEEL the impact of that theme, and in Magnolia, that theme is repeated endlessly and diluted over several stories, none of which really hit home.The acting is uneven, with exciting turns (Cruise), subtle and classy performances (Riley, Hoffman), and then the not-so-good; the otherwise stellar Julianne Moore seems to be punching the "hysterical woman" button on her AutoAct device, and Jason Robards' overwrought deathbed scenes ought to be used in a PSA for euthanasia. Then again, these characters, like practically ALL the characters, seem to have nothing to them. It's as if Anderson wanted to keep practically everything of interest about these people in backstory, leaving us with people as scabs...nothing left to see here but the RESULTS of interesting things. Okay, but that's boring.What shocked me was the uneven writing! Anderson, who brilliantly kept all characters on the level in Boogie Nights, goes wildly over the top in Magnolia with an outrageously shitty father of a quiz kid. Similarly, in a shrill scene in which a daughter is confronted by her estranged and dying father, all we get is an endless repetition of "Get the fuck out! Get the fuck out!" It's melodrama, and he's done better.However, Anderson does have a way of connecting scenes, even when they don't have anything to do with each other, and he's also got a natural style that favors moments and emotion over technical obsessions with focus and coverage. He's so stylish, he almost fooled me into thinking this movie worked. But after only a few minutes of reflection, it seemed pretty clear that it didn't.Magnolia is a good effort with some beautiful moments, but it's also an insecure film made by a writer/director who should rely less on tricks and contrivances.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>1999-12-28</date>
		<username>Diego-77</username>

		<shortDescription>Altman did it better</shortDescription>

The film starts out interesting enough with all the overlapping of peoples lives and their interaction. But then the film just gets slower and slower without any new information just rehashing everything we have seen in the first hour and a half. The director gives the impression that he was going to make a three hour movie weather or not he had three hours worth of story to tell. Robert Altman does this type of film much better</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>1999-12-27</date>
		<username>iago-6 (scott@cinemademerde.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>CRAP. C R A P. Ambitious, well-cast, CRAP. CRRRRRRAAAAAPPPP.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Where to begin?You get thirty characters--ALL ON THE BRINK OF SUICIDE. All of them are miserable. All of them are having THE VERY WORST DAY OF THEIR LIVES. All of them are varying degrees of reprehensible, and not ONE nice thing happens to ANY of them during the ENTIRE movie. It's all misery, misery, misery for three LONG LONG hours.Misery in itself is not a problem, but what Anderson does is jury-rig the entire movie and attempt to ratchet up its seeming importance by having every character on their last emotional nerve. Much of the misery rings EXTREMELY false--some of these characters are smart enough to do SOMETHING to leaven the unpleasantness of their everyday existences--but if they did we wouldn't be so "drawn in" and it might be a little more difficult or complex to bring them to the "redemption" the movie drops in our laps during the final reel. What it is is a massive COP-OUT. When you start a movie at the very bottom where the only way to go is up and keep the emotional level cranked up to eleven for the entire THREE HOURS it strikes me as an extremely MANIPULATIVE way to get an audience reaction without having to actually WRITE WELL or create SHADED characters with somewhere to GO. Guess what, PT? Life is NOT that bad! It may be for some people, it may be for a FEW characters, but creating characters this unrelievedly miserable is just a bare attempt to APPEAR to be plumbing the dark recesses of the human condition while playing in a rigged game. It renders the point of the entire film moot, undercuts whatever authorial integrity he might have established, leaves the audience feeling bamboozled, and makes Anderson look like a BIG FAT FAKE.The interrelatedness of most of the characters goes NOWHERE. There are some characters you don't even realize are related until you see their last names in the credits, and then when you try to think of what it might signify, it comes to absolutely nothing but another GIMMICK to make the writing seem expansive and wide-reaching.The huge plot contrivance about the frogs IS audacious, but again, pointless. Save it for a film where it might have some resonance. But at least it did spice up an otherwise bland and predictable trip down misery lane.It was the very SWEETNESS of the last half hour of BOOGIE NIGHTS that saved it from the very kind of manipulated misery that this film succumbs to. Life became a bit more bearable, illuminating how those characters made compromises and found a way to live with tragedy and make the most of it. And that was moving. But inventing characters who are all very falsely contrived to be on the very last strand of their sanity and then inviting us to be moved by their courage as they struggle to hold it together is just out and out manipulation. It's NOT GOOD WRITING. It's CHEATING.And if you are considering seeing this movie, just be warned. Or just... don't see it. I assure you you're life will be just as full (if not more so) without sitting through this.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2012-03-12</date>
		<username>sashank_kini-1</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Beneath all the 'c?ks----rs','s--tb?ls' and 'f?ks', there's tender love</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is indeed quite a film, it has all the tears, joy, pain, suffering, compunction, regret, fear, and trouble, and pressure, dejection that a melodrama usually does and still does not lose its grip and become a superficial sob saga. It careens through every emotion above and even more, narrating the lives of many characters intertwining within 24 hours and causing twists in their lives and miracles in the weather. The film also uses a lot of close-ups and background music to support the emotions , the most defining song being the street rap sung by the kid which defines the entire film. And everything is said within three hours, keeping a religious reference in the picture too (the director-writer Paul Thomas Anderson, maker of the superb There will be Blood wasn't apparently aware when about the bible reference when he wrote the film). Magnolia can be a tour de force novel, and it's almost a miracle that has made it a great film, since people nowadays don't favor overload of emotions.Magnolia tells about many lives crossing paths in a single day, leading to newfound relations between them and a few tragedies too. Like Ebert said, there are too many stories to contain in a single review but the major ones are those of Cruise's, Melora's, and Flynn's. Cruise's Frank Mackey has a strained relationship with his father and now is a successful, cocky, arrogant sex adviser who gets grilled in an interview leading to certain events. Jason Robart's Earl is bedridden and shares his desires to meet his son. Julianne's Jane is a virulent and temperamental lady who actually behaves like that because of the guilt welling in her. Macy's Donnie is a gay man who was a child prodigy and had won a contest but now struggles to make a living. There are many others which I won't mention here but all of them go through changes and this tests their hardened exterior, making many break down and confess their sins, guilt, fears and sorrows. Everything moves like a game show, with an accelerated start, a slowdown with a breakdown, then getting back to an accelerated finish.The story is startlingly honest and endearing; if only George Scott could see beyond the profanity? Almost all the stories strike the right chord and it is only at certain moments the drama goes overboard, for example, Stanley breaking down on national TV. Personally, I felt that maybe if the Jim's story had been trimmer or if they had done away with or truncated either Donnie Smith's or Neil Flynn's story it would've had more impact but again, without these stories the film may be incomplete. But I do think the three hour and eight minute duration was quite long, and at times the message became convoluted since so many story lines were to be followed. But the more important thing was that these stories touched me in one way or the other and had a collaborative impact on me in the end, and after a day of watching the film, the impact of the film and my respect for Paul Tomas Anderson's vision deepened.All the actors support and never upstage the film, something that happens when great actors are cast. The music is terrific, and when everyone actually sings a song that's playing on the radio, I was reminded of the 'Fort Minor' music video, the group that sang that rap song whose name I don't recollect. The frog scene was in tune with the film since there have been such weird incidents, but fewer frogs, please. Mulholland Drive is similar to Magnolia except that the former is more surrealistic, but having seen both the films, I can say that Mulholland is more concise and made with a very clear and impactful, singular vision, while Magnolia is more swelling in its plot, with multiple themes and a more heartfelt ending. Out of the two, Mulholland is a better film but Magnolia is something that is more accessible to the audience in general. Thomas Anderson's approach here is similar to the great Leo Tolstoy's, both have many journeys running parallel each with their own redemption.Do not be put off by the run length mentioned behind the DVD case or the poster that looks gooey and maudlin or the amount of profanity in the film like George C Scott was or even the title 'Magnolia' that may seem weird or too artsy to some. Take your seat and experience this wonderful ride, you will surely not be disappointed.My Rating: 8.4 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The Work of P.T. Anderson: "Magnolia" (1999), a day in the life</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's a little difficult to make a summary of "Magnolia" because could be confused due to all the different names. Let's just say that it a compiled of strange stories with characters that are related from each other. Basically every character have something similar with another and the two main families of the film have the same problem: the father was a terrible person and now that is dying is feeling regret. And we can see the consequence of that in the sons and wives. The other characters are similar too: two good persons that are witness and are always helping the others (the police officer and the nurse) and the two "quiz kids" who suffers problems with their respective father too. And the rapper kid who is a very strange character, like a prophet. All are great and complex characters and you need to watch every story to understand the behavior of all the characters because of the great narrative style.Paul Thomas Anderson touches universal themes, like in most of his films, so for me all the characters are believable and you will feel them. I love specially one part of the film, the part of the quiz show, because on that sequence you feel worry about two persons that must hide their feelings just for an stupid TV show and how in that specific moment to know that you have terminal cancer and to need to urinate are problems with the same magnitude because two persons are really suffering, each for they problem.The situations in the film are really strange with all those "coindidences", just as the three stories at the beginning, but the situation with the rain of frogs is just amazingly bizarre . I love how that scene looks, because it was a downpour and it's sounds amazing. The rain of frogs can be related to the Bible but as the narrator said: "that strange things happen all the time. And so it goes, and so it goes". I think he is right because after all the world must go on. And i say that because after the rain of frogs everybody go on with their lives in a normal way.The cast is just superb, from the great and touching performance of Julian Moore to the very little but amazing performance of Alfred Molina. Well everybody did a terrific work just as memorable as the day of their characters. The music is another terrific aspect of the film mostly composed by Aimee Mann. I really love how the film start with my favourite song of the film "One", it's perfect just as the memorable scene with "Wise Up", a really powerful song.Conclusion: i love this film. It's long (188 minutes) but it goes very fast and in the humble opinion of this writer you must watch this film more than 2 times. When i watch it for the first time i really enjoy it but it was until the second view that i stop and think about every character's day and how is really memorable for everyone. It's "a day in the life" that nobody will forget and not just for the rain of frogs."Magnolia" is a film that i'm not going to forget and is my favourite of the great Paul Thomas Anderson. 10 out of 10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2008-01-12</date>
		<username>bkoganbing</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Biblical Plague</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was enjoying Magnolia right up to the part where a biblical type of plague came down upon all the characters in the film and I was then wondering what it was all about.Magnolia is an episodic, along the lines of director/writer Paul T. Anderson's previous success, Boogie Nights. A whole bunch of people, tied to each other by a successful long running quiz show have a lot of life altering events happen to them within 24 hours. The problem was that in Boogie Nights you followed a community of people from the pornography industry over a period of years. In Magnolia this all happens over 24 hours, more like Crash, although I think Crash was better handled.Some parts are better than the whole. Several characters for me really stood out.Tom Cruise took a daring career move in playing a motivational speaker for hedonism and male supremacy. How he arrived at this particular doctrine he preaches and makes money off is his story. His hedonism is covering up a very deep hurt from childhood.I liked William H. Macy as a has been celebrity made by that quiz show as a child. He's come to the end of his rope being able to cash in on that celebrity. Now he's a forty something gay man, mooning over a young and humpy bartender at his local watering hole and thinking he could nail the guy with a little cosmetic improvement on his part.Magnolia was the last theatrical film of Jason Robards, Jr. who plays the producer of the quiz show, Kids Know Best. The idea was to match whiz kid type geniuses against grownups in some sort of academic bowl situation. It actually sounded like a good idea for a real quiz show, I'm surprised no one thought of it in real life. Robards is dying of cancer and he's made a mess of his life as well as his sons's. Their reunion is painful to say the least.But of all the performances in the film by the grownups, I liked young Jeremy Blackman as one of the current kids on the show. He's being pushed by a stage father, Stanley Spector, who's living vicariously through his kid.All these good performances and others just somehow don't come together in the way Boogie Nights or Crash does. And the ending with the plague of frogs descending on Los Angeles was really too much and unnecessary.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2006-07-07</date>
		<username>blink90000</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"It's not going to stop, until you wise up..."</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ever since Magnolia was released, audiences everywhere have been divided by those who love it, and those who hate it. Some think it's pretentious and pointless, while others find it to be cinema genius. I'm someone who love's Magnolia.Magnolia is an epic mosaic set in California's San Fernando Valley. We follow the various stories of various conflicted characters, and how they will all connect by the end of the day. There's Jimmy Gator, a successful T.V. show host for the game show "What Do Kids Know?", and has recently found out that he is terminally ill with cancer. His daughter, Claudia Wilson Gator, is troubled, and is falling deeper and deeper into a cocaine addiction. Then there's Earl Partridge, a terminally ill, guilt driven man who would do anything to see his son, and to be forgiven in his final hour of life. His son, Frank T.J. Mackey (Tom Cruise in his finest performance), is a charismatic sex guru, who offers silly advice to struggling men. Earl's wife, Linda Partridge, has about the same amount of guilt as her husband, claiming to slept around with other men. But, of all the years of infidelity, she is finally starting to love her husband, just as he is reaching death. Jim Curring, a modest police officer, is a struggling man who just wants to love someone, and for someone to love him back. He soon immediately falls in love with Claudia. On the T.V. show, "What Do Kids Know", there's Stanley Spector, a boy who has to deal with the grueling mental pressure of being on the show, and his father's abuse. The old winner of the show, the now middle aged Quiz Kid Donnie Smith, is a struggling man who, like Jim, just wants to be loved. All of these characters and stories will soon connect by a bizarre and biblical event. In the end, Magnolia is film of raw emotion. It's about forgiveness, redemption, humanity, morality, death, loss... The film deals with things that happen every day, and things that happen rarely. The film is also beautifully crafted by writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson, who has proved to be one of the finest filmmakers of his generation. Along with his brilliant screenplay and direction, Magnolia also features one of the best ensembles I've ever seen in any film. Magnolia gives thought provoking themes, and tons of powerful scenes, including when all of the characters sing Aimee Mann's "Wise Up". "We may be through with the past, but the past ain't through with us."Rating: **** / ****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>reverb_88</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrific!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Magnolia" is a three-hour "epic" movie that is so ambitious it should have failed miserably, but it doesn't. It passes with flying colors. There are so many layers to this movie, but it never becomes bogged down by them. Writer/Director P.T Anderson gracefully weaves together five or so deeply complex stories that weave in and out of each other, all dealing with a the same basic themes: the sins of fathers being passed on to their children, love, tragedy, pain, hate, and ultimately, forgiveness. Anderson isn't afraid to take risks in his films and he takes plenty of them here, but they all pay off big time. This is a great movie. I loved it.</fullReview>

		<username>Delme J (delmejones@yahoo.co.uk)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Style Over Substance</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really wanted to like this film - I had heard good things from people whose opinions I trust; I had seen and enjoyed Boogie Nights; I thought that the cast list was extremely promising; and I tend to go for darker films.However, Magnolia just didn't do it for me. Yes, the acting - for the most part - is top drawer if a little OTT in places, but you would expect that from the actors/actresses involved.The sweeping nature of the cinematography is also impressive, though there's nothing in there that I haven't seen before from a number of other directors (Altman and Scorsese spring to mind) in a number of other films. Some things really did not work at all - in my opinion, the scene when all the characters are singing the same song as the camera pays a visit to all of them is particularly jarring.Parts of the film were undoubtedly moving/amusing/depressing/inventive, but ultimately the film didn't really have anything new to say, and what it did try to say did not really necessitate the three-hour duration.This is not to say that I would advise someone not to watch it, just that I would warn them that they might feel a little short-changed at the end.</fullReview>

		<username>Lt Wolf Maker</username>

		<shortDescription>What's with all this existential crap?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is no ingenious and life-changing philosophy behind Magnolia. Actually most of the stories had a dry prosaism that altogether COULD have been shortened. [Magnolia: The never-ending movie?]The director's a kid, barely out of his 20s, with an ego probably rivaling Spielberg. He extracts what little wisdom there is out of those 20 someodd years, and tells ME about what I should get out of life? A topic too large for a kid, that in effect is only some generalized concept to have no regrets and talk to your old man before he crusts over on his deathbed.The actors [Tom Cruise, ever the opportunist] were involved because P.T. had some leverage and momentary status after Boogie Nights [notice how he's on vacation from the face of the Earth in 2001] and thought it'd be pretty cutting edge to have characters that swear a lot. [There's nothing wrong with the F-word, but notice how irritatingly repetitious it becomes as the hours drag....the english language is vast and could have been used with much more color regarding insults than just breathing out f--- every other second.]The movies gestating our society today were made by directors who knew a few people rather than being chosen out of raw talent. Back in the day movies were actually ABOUT something. Movies used to have plot. Today the high culture bracket like Ebert and his kind get some rise out of the wandering cancer/suicide/loneliness set-up, as over used as it is.Sure, go ahead and do the intersecting-story thing, it's the fad nowadays. But it was done much better with Go -- which was funny, interesting, had much less severely pathetic characters, and although not a classic it at least didn't have that "wing-it" script quality. It was much tighter and vastly more clever. Magnolia is nothing more than an arrogant high schooler's perception into adult life. [The IQ factor must be low in 2001 for Magnolia to get 8.1 on the IMDb tracker.] People today just eat this s--- up.Because that's basically all it is.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-27</date>
		<username>djweaksauce</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>overrated, overblown</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The actors in Magnolia bypass playing characters entirely, instead ending up as overly familiar, two-dimensional character types - overbearing chauvinist, plucky child genius, perpetually addled speed freak, and so on. Writer/director PT Anderson, who balanced satire and pathos so well in the mostly good (and undeniably entertaining) Boogie Nights, here vastly overreaches his abilities: in attempting to present characters at the edge of desperation, he instead gives us caricatures of adults that could have been written by an over-eager adolescent. Every prominent woman in the film is hysterical; every man is either unbelievably overbearing or cartoonishly pathetic; nearly every epiphany necessarily follows a steady barrage of alcohol or drugs.Anderson squanders the promise of the movie's brilliant, enigmatic opening sequence, as well as the sizeable talents of generally excellent actors such as William H. Macy, with an "auteurism" as heavy-handed as that of Welles, without any trace of the latter's genius.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-09</date>
		<username>adamk-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The horror, the horror...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is probably the most arrogantly bad film I've seen this year -- Paul Thomas Anderson cannot write a decent line, reduces his characters to nothing more than hysterical or moronic cyphers, and -- apart from a knicker-wetting desire to be Robert Altman, cannot direct. Standout questions: The film revolves around a children's quiz show going out live. What quiz shows since the 1950's have gone out live? Why don't they, after 30 years on the air and dealing with kids, know what to do when someone needs to go to the toilet? Julianne Moore's character, in one of her more unusual speeches (she doesn't say "f***" for more than five words at a time) declares that she loves her husband. How does this manifest itself? Apart from saying goodbye to him in her first scene, she never relates to him in any way whatsoever (great "character development", by the way: She wears a fur coat to show she's rich, but swears to show she's "common" -- geddit? This, as long as I'm being parenthetical, rates up there with the Quiz master when we first meet him: During a breathless voiceover listing his family-value credentials, we get to see him humping a young woman who is not his wife, with jaded look on his face. Geddit? Anderson seems to scream. This is character development at its most 101). How brain damaged is the cop not to notice his date is coked out of her head? What happens about the gunshots fired at him that caused him to drop his gun? We saw someone pick the gun up and run inside a house, but later on (Spoiler alert, here:) It drops from the sky. Heh? When the genius kid breaks into the library: No alarm system? Isn't anyone looking for him? The film is riddled with inconsistencies like these, all wrapped up in a self-conscious, indulgent style that drags on for far too long. Anderson doesn't even know how to use music on the soundtrack, either drowning out the dialogue (and I LIKE Aimee Mann!) or cramming every scene with intrusive music, continually promising a crescendo that never arrives....until, about 3/4 of the way through, it just stops. As if he'd used up his entire music budget. Over on a "bad movie" sight, they list a couple of criteria for "bad movies" -- Ebert's "Stupid Movie" (when the action can only progress -- such as the kids wetting himself -- when people act like idiots) and "IITS", or:"It's In The Script!". This fulfills both criteria, and then blazes a path of its own.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-06-06</date>
		<username>Jeremy Bristol</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>The road to (movie) hell is paved with good intentions.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie tries ever so hard to be a great movie, so I really think it's a shame that it turned out to be so fundementally flawed. The problem is that miracles (or even miraculous coincidences) should never (or at least rarely) be in movies. A movie is a construction, therefore can be manipulated in any way the moviemaker chooses for religious, secular, monetary, or artistic goals (I prefer the latter). As such, any miracle is simply a contrivance and of no use in any kind of didactic sense (do you really think any intelligent people were convinced to change their beliefs because of Stigmata, Left Behind, The Ten Commandments, or even The Virgin Spring? or South Park, The Exorcist, Love and Death, or any other "sacriligious" movie with satiric miracles? Either way, it's preaching to the choir). Emotionally--well, there are people who fall for everything from television psychics (if they're so psychic, why don't they call you?) to tele-evangelists ("Praise Jesus for the suckers born every minute!"), so why shouldn't it make them feel good that God will forgive or that there are other people who are disillusioned enough by religious hypocrisy to make fun of it by having God pelt those same sinners with frogs.Simply put, miracles are lazy writing, and movies are not the proper venue for preaching for (or against) religion through these supernatural forces.Think about it. If you favor the Christian side: how do you know that the first three examples of coincidences aren't just some urban legends, exaggerations of real events, or something Anderson just made up (obviously the ending is bogus)? Doesn't that undermine the miraculous forgiveness aspect of the ending, to know that everything leading up to it is a construction instead of a "miracle"? But on the other hand, if you favor the secular side, if you take the opening vignettes as satirically as they are presented, then the ending is being heavy-handedly satirical--leaving God as the ultimate prankster, sparing those who to us don't deserve it by pelting them with one of the seven plagues he unleashed on Egypt. If that is the case, then it is merely silly and amateurish humor without purpose or real meaning (i.e. it doesn't do anything to prove that God is malicious or whether he exists or not, it merely angers Christians).Either way, it undermines what might have been good in the middle two+ hours (not a whole lot, really, so it doesn't really matter).</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Three Words: Mag-suck-la!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was such a monumental waste of time. I feel much dumber for having viewed it. All I could think, walking out of the theater was, "I want those three hours of my life back." Tom Cruise was uncharacteristically horrible in his role, and the only likeable character was the nurse, played by Phillip Seymour Hoffman. The only part of this movie worth watching is the first 5 or so minutes, which deals with the interesting coincidences in life, such as the man who jumps off a building to kill himself and, as his passes his own window, is accidentally shot by his mother, who is firing a gun that he loaded. This is the only part of the movie that is at all intellectually stimulating. Alas, though it is an excellent set-up for what might have been a great film, there is no follow through, and no connection in the actual movie to the concept set up at the beginning. Don't waste your time on this steaming pile of bad acting and bad writing.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>...I'll tell you how. Magnolia is one of those films that people seem to confuse with being "good" simply because it's long, full of false emotion and drama, and is chock full of big words (women seem to love this kind of movie, not surprisingly). To say that sitting through Magnolia is painful is an understatement. Picture a movie where every scene contains:1. Actors giving overly dramatic near-monologues.2. Repeated use of the f-word to make the dialogue seem more tense and dramatic. Now imagine that the f-word is used so much that you can TELL that the dialogue is scripted (note that this doesn't happen in GOOD movies).3. Tension so thick you could cut it with a knife; every scene seems like it's leading to some sweeping conclusion.Now imagine that the scenes change about twice a minute FOR THREE AND A HALF HOURS. It quickly becomes unbearable, literally. This movie is just plain depressing for NO REASON WHATSOEVER. I really wish people knew what makes a movie GOOD; a good movie has soul, gives you insight. Magnolia does neither... it simply force-feeds the audience emotion in the hopes of provoking a strong reaction.</fullReview>

		<date>2000-08-05</date>
		<username>Dr.X</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Whatever happened to subtlety?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Magnolia is a very interesting film laced with great performances. Unfortunately, it is also laced with overly embellished emotional scenes in which the characters directly tell the audience what the point of the scene rather than letting them figure it out on their own. Most scenes go about 2-3 minutes too long, with the final minutes immense overkill. Anderson has some good ideas but apparently he thinks little of the audience's intelligence and feels compelled to hammer every point home. The two infamous controversial scenes are great examples--overkill. We can easily understand the points about synchronicity and unpredictable interconnectedness without them. Though I enjoyed the film and was highly involved and even moved by many scenes, this film would have been much more effective with about 40 minutes edited out in a way that would preserve some subtlety. I felt like the director was standing behind me smacking me with a frying pan every 5 minutes and saying "Do you get it? Huh? Do you get it?" Well, yes, Mr. Anderson I got it a long time ago and don't need you to spoonfeed everything to me, thank you very much! Still well worth watching. I give it a 7 out of 10 overall. Too bad, it could have and should have been a 9.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2012-05-11</date>
		<username>Marius Holman Penney</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A mad, magnificent masterpiece.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me start this review with a set-up of how high my expectations were for this movie. I was 15 when I first saw There Will Be Blood (my first PT Anderson film) and I can safely say it completely sandblasted my brain. It was so big and bold and brilliant, I instantly bought every other PT Anderson film and watched them all. First Hard Eight, which I found a little disappointing, but it was his debut and I saw his distinctive styles bubbling and maturing beneath it's surface. Then Boogie Nights, a beautiful, humane piece, and then Punch-Drunk Love - less ambitious than the others, but so wonderful in it's own little world. By this time, I had begun to understand that PT Anderson was something special - a true trailblazer in modern cinema, and one who always pushed himself and brought something new to the table as oppose to rehashing the same movie again and again. But nothing, nothing, could have prepared me for Magnolia. It held me like no other film ever had done, digging into my heart and clinging on for a three-hour ride through a world of true pain, of true emotion and, occasionally, such shockingly true and raw beauty it practically opens the gates for what cinema can be. It is unlike anything else I have ever seen, and yet so much like things that everyone has felt. It is a true living breathing work of art, a stunning blend of ballsy absurdism and painfully real human drama that truly knit together into something new, rich and utterly fantastic. An array of fantastic characters and their bizarre, richly tragic lives intertwine and reflect one another in a typically wonderful Anderson script, and his distinctive directorial eye is as graceful, probing and delightfully obsessed with long-takes as always. Please see this film. It is a masterpiece.</fullReview>
	</review>
